text: Venezuela’s beleaguered government appeared prepared to go ahead with a vote on Sunday that critics at home and abroad have warned will seal the demise of the oil-rich nation’s democracy. At least five <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>people</role> were <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger> last week after the opposition stepped up its protests against the controversial vote that will elect a 545-member constituent assembly with the power to rewrite the constitution and dissolve state institutions. A government ban on public <trigger id='trigger-2'>demonstrations</trigger> in the run-up to the election reduced turnouts for nationwide <trigger id='trigger-3'>protests</trigger> called by <role id='role-3-Demonstrator'trigno='3'>the opposition</role>, but sporadic looting and <trigger id='trigger-4'>clashes</trigger> between <role id='role-4-Demonstrator'trigno='4'>protesters</role> manning barricades of tree branches and barbed wire were reported in several cities on Friday night. Q & A Why is there unrest in Venezuela? Show • At the heart of the crisis is a cratering economy and acute shortages of medicine and food, coupled with rising anger at a soaring <trigger id='trigger-0'>crime</trigger> rate and an increasingly authoritarian government • The president, Nicolás Maduro, won a general election in 2013 on a platform of continuing his predecessor Hugo Chávez's socialist policies of using the country's oil riches to reduce inequality and lift people out of poverty, but falling oil prices have forced the government to curtail social programmes • <role id='role-5-Demonstrator'trigno='5'>Opposition</role> activists have been staging unrelenting <trigger id='trigger-5'>protests</trigger> against <role id='role-5-Target'trigno='5'>the government</role>. Despite the continuing <trigger id='trigger-6'>threat</trigger> of repression, <role id='role-7-Demonstrator'trigno='7'>the opposition</role> coalition, known as MUD, called for mass <trigger id='trigger-7'>demonstrations</trigger> in Caracas on Sunday while voting takes place. “Tomorrow we rebel,” tweeted Freddy Guevara, vice-president of the opposition-held national legislature, whose power to legislate was hamstrung by a supreme court decision in April, prompting the protests. At least <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>113 people</role> have been <trigger id='trigger-8'>killed</trigger>, and more than <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>2, 000</role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>wounded</trigger>, in constant street <trigger id='trigger-10'>protests</trigger> since April, triggering President Nicolás Maduro’s decision to create the assembly. <role id='role-11-Communicator'trigno='11'>Maduro</role> has <trigger id='trigger-11'>said</trigger> the assembly will help bring peace to the sharply divided country where, despite its oil wealth, many Venezuelans are going hungry because of food shortages and spiralling inflation. But the opposition said it is little more than a power grab to consolidate the ruling socialist party’s grip. It is boycotting the assembly and demanding general elections instead. “On 30 July, the constitutional assembly will happen,” <role id='role-20-Participant'trigno='20'><role id='role-20-Participant'trigno='20'>Maduro</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-20'>said</trigger>. “I’ve been loyal to Chávez’s legacy. Now it’s your turn.” An attempt at brokering an agreement by the former prime minister of Spain, José Luis Rodriguez Zapatero, to avert the increased tensions appeared to have failed. Zapatero issued a statement on Saturday tacitly acknowledging that the constituent assembly vote would be held, but calling on the assembly’s powers to be limited and for firm dates for local and presidential elections to be set. “Today and tomorrow are transcendental for Venezuela,” <role id='role-12-Communicator'trigno='12'>Zapatero</role> said in the <trigger id='trigger-12'>statement</trigger>. He called on the government to make “new gestures” to help ease tensions but did not call for the vote to be cancelled. The opposition also appeared resigned to seeing the vote take place. “But we are not backing down because our problem is not the constituent assembly, it is the dictatorship,” said <role id='role-13-Communicator'trigno='13'>Guevara</role> in a <trigger id='trigger-13'>statement</trigger>. “What comes after Sunday will not be easy for us,” he said, adding however that the “deepening of the crisis will affect those in government much more” . But polls show that 70% of Venezuelans do not want a constituent assembly, although turnout on Sunday may not reflect that. To avoid an embarrassingly low turnout, government officials and pro-government neighbourhood committees have been warning that people who do not show up for the vote may lose their jobs, essential food subsidies or homes. <role id='role-14-Recipient'trigno='14'>Delcy Leonor Medina</role>, a 52-year-old housekeeper, said she and her neighbours in a working-class district of Caracas face the <trigger id='trigger-14'>threat</trigger> of armed muggings and murders. Now <role id='role-15-Recipient'trigno='15'>they</role> face an added <trigger id='trigger-15'>threat</trigger> of losing their government-subsidised homes if they don’t vote. But she remained defiant. “I’m not giving that bastard anything. If the constituent assembly is voted in, I may have to leave here,” she said. Many of Venezuela’s 2. 8 million state workers have reported getting text messages, phone calls and being required to attend political rallies during work hours, according to Reuters. Early on Saturday, the opposition coalition’s website appeared to have been hacked, showing a message saying “Yanquis, leave our America” with a photo of the US president, Donald Trump. Hours later, the site showed a message reading “Democracy cannot be hacked.” Cilia Flores, Maduro’s wife and a candidate for the assembly, said the new body with supra-legislative powers would create a commission to punish those responsible for the political upheaval. They will “pay and learn their lesson” , she said, playing on the fears of the opposition that they will suffer further persecution. <role id='role-19-Participant'trigno='19'><role id='role-19-Participant'trigno='19'>Diosdado Cabello</role></role>, the first vice-president of Venezuela’s socialist party, <trigger id='trigger-19'>said</trigger> the assembly will strip legislators in the opposition-controlled National Assembly of their immunity from prosecution. <role id='role-24-Participant'trigno='24'><role id='role-24-Participant'trigno='24'>He</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-24'>said</trigger> the office of Venezuela’s chief prosecutor, who recently became one of Maduro’s most outspoken critics, would be “turned upside down” . The US has led other nations in imposing targeted sanctions against 13 current and former officials close to the government. They were followed by similar measures by Mexico and Colombia. US vice-president Mike Pence spoke by phone with opposition leader and political prisoner <role id='role-16-Defendant'trigno='16'>Leopoldo López</role>, <trigger id='trigger-16'>sentenced</trigger> to 14 years for inciting violence, charges human rights groups have said were trumped up. Pence told <role id='role-17-Detainee'trigno='17'>López</role>, who was transferred to house <trigger id='trigger-17'>arrest</trigger> earlier this month, that the United States “stands with the Venezuelan people” . The Trump <role id='role-18-Communicator'trigno='18'>administration</role> has <trigger id='trigger-18'>threatened</trigger> further measures if the vote goes ahead, which may target the country’s oil industry, one of the few economic lifelines left in <role id='role-18-Recipient'trigno='18'>Venezuela</role>. Colombia’s president Juan Manuel Santos, who is often the target of Maduro’s public rants of an international conspiracy against him, said he would not recognise the constituent assembly, which he called “spurious” . In a tacit recognition of the growing humanitarian and political crisis, the Colombian government said on Friday it was granting a special permit for Venezuelans already in the country to remain for up to two years. And more than one Venezuelan is preparing to pack his bags and join the growing number of people fleeing. <role id='role-21-Participant'trigno='21'><role id='role-21-Participant'trigno='21'>Carlos</role></role>, a 24-year-old student at the Metropolitan University in Caracas, <trigger id='trigger-21'>said</trigger> most of his friends are leaving the country. His parents have said that if the constituent assembly is voted in, they want him to join them. “I would lose my family, my home, my friends, my university,” <trigger id='trigger-22'>said</trigger> <role id='role-22-Participant'trigno='22'><role id='role-22-Participant'trigno='22'>Carlos</role></role>, who declined to give his real name. But he also holds another fear. “I’m afraid of losing my country,” <role id='role-23-Participant'trigno='23'><role id='role-23-Participant'trigno='23'>he</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-23'>said</trigger>. Additional reporting by Ana Sofia Romero in Caracas.

text: <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>1</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>killed</trigger>, <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>4</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>hurt</trigger> in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Maguindanao</role> roadside bombing A MARINE <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>soldier</role> was <trigger id='trigger-2'>killed</trigger> while four <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>others</role> were <trigger id='trigger-3'>wounded</trigger> in a roadside bombing in the province of Maguindanao, officials said Saturday, September 19, 2020. Major General Juvymax Uy, 6th Infantry Division commander, said the incident happened around 10 p. m. Friday in Lipongo village, Datu Hoffer, Maguindanao. Uy did not release the identities of the slain and wounded soldiers, but said they belong to the 5th Marine Company of the Marine Battalion Landing Team-5 (MBLT-5). Uy said the troops were in a convoy traversing the road along Lipongo village when one of the three vehicles tripped on an improvised explosive device (IED) that was fashioned as a landmine, <trigger id='trigger-4'>killing</trigger> the <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>soldier</role> and <trigger id='trigger-5'>injuring</trigger> four <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>others</role>. The <role id='role-6-Artifact'trigno='6'>vehicle</role> was also <trigger id='trigger-6'>damaged</trigger>. Uy said it is highly possible that the Daesh-inspired Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters (BIFF) are behind the roadside <role id='role-7-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='7'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>attack</trigger>, as the explosive bore the signature of the BIFF. Newly promoted Lieutenant General Corleto Vinluan Jr. , Western Mindanao Command chief, condemned the terror group responsible for the incident. “This horrendous act perpetrated by the terrorists is simply unacceptable,” Vinluan said. He vowed to exhaust every available resource to bring the perpetrators to justice.

text: <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>2</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>killed</trigger> in roadside <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>IED</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>blast</trigger> in <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>Bajaur</role> At least two <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>people</role> were <trigger id='trigger-2'>killed</trigger> when a roadside <role id='role-3-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='3'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-3'>exploded</trigger> near a vehicle in <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>Bajaur</role> tribal district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa on Wednesday evening, a district <role id='role-18-Participant'trigno='18'><role id='role-18-Participant'trigno='18'>official</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-18'>said</trigger>. An improvised explosive device (<role id='role-4-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='4'>IED</role>) planted along the road by unidentified miscreants <trigger id='trigger-4'>went off</trigger> as the vehicle passed through the Charmang <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>area</role> of Bajaur's Nawagai tehsil, an official in the district's political administration told DawnNewsTV. Two <role id='role-20-Transporter'trigno='20'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-20'>riding</trigger> the <role id='role-20-Vehicle'trigno='20'>vehicle</role>, <trigger id='trigger-19'>identified</trigger> as Amanullah and <role id='role-19-IdentifiedRole'trigno='19'><role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>Gul Badin</role></role>, <trigger id='trigger-5'>died</trigger> as a result of the <trigger id='trigger-6'>explosion</trigger>. Their <role id='role-7-Artifact'trigno='7'>vehicle</role> was also <trigger id='trigger-7'>totalled</trigger> by the impact. Security <role id='role-9-Investigator'trigno='9'>forces</role> sealed the area — which lies close to the Pakistan-Afghanistan border — after the <trigger id='trigger-8'>blast</trigger> and started a <trigger id='trigger-9'>search operation</trigger>. This is the second reported incident of violence today, when Eid Miladun Nabi is being celebrated across the country. An <role id='role-10-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='10'>IED</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>explosion</trigger> at a <role id='role-10-Place'trigno='10'>mosque</role> in Balochistan's Chaman area left nine <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-11'>injured</trigger>, also in the evening. The <trigger id='trigger-12'>blast</trigger> in Bajaur comes days after a tribal <role id='role-13-Victim'trigno='13'>elder</role> was seriously <trigger id='trigger-13'>wounded</trigger> in a roadside <role id='role-14-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='14'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>blast</trigger> in <role id='role-14-Place'trigno='14'>Nawagai</role> tehsil. Fencing of hundreds of kilometres of border areas along with Afghanistan’s Kunar province has been underway in Bajaur to secure Pakistan from cross-border terror <trigger id='trigger-15'>attacks</trigger>. The number of <trigger id='trigger-16'>attacks</trigger> in the <role id='role-16-Place'trigno='16'>country</role> has fallen by around 70 per cent due to a combination of military offensives against Taliban bases along the Afghan border and government initiatives to tackle militancy, but <trigger id='trigger-17'>attacks</trigger> on <role id='role-17-Target'trigno='17'>security</role> and civilian targets continue to occur occasionally.

text: Report says <role id='role-1-Killer'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>CIA</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>attacks</trigger> led to <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>civilian</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>deaths</trigger> and casualties and says US protocols are'hurdle to transparency'A United Nations investigation has so far identified 33 drone strikes around the world that have resulted in civilian casualties and may have violated international humanitarian law. The report by the UN's special rapporteur on human rights and counter-terrorism, Ben Emmerson QC, calls on the US to declassify information about operations co-ordinated by the CIA and clarify its positon on the legality of unmanned aerial attacks. Published ahead of a debate on the use of remotely piloted aircraft, at the UN general assembly in New York next Friday, the 22-page document examines incidents in Afghanistan, Yemen, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Pakistan and Gaza. It has been published to coincide with a related report released earlier on Thursday by Professor Christof Heyns, the UN's special rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions, which warned that the technology was being misused as a form of"global policing". Emmerson, who travelled to Islamabad for his investigation, said the Pakistan ministry of foreign affairs has records of as many as 330 <role id='role-2-Instrument'trigno='2'>drone</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>strikes</trigger> in the <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>country</role>'s north-western tribal areas since 2004. Up to 2, 200 people have been <trigger id='trigger-3'>killed</trigger>–of whom at least 400 were <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>civilians</role>–according to the Pakistan government. In Yemen, Emmerson's report says that as many as 58 civilians are thought to have been killed in attacks by UAVs (unmanned aerial vehicles)."While the fact that civilians have been killed or injured does not necessarily point to a violation of international humanitarian law, it undoubtedly raises issues of accountability and transparency,"the study notes. Reaper UAVs, used by the RAF in Afghanistan, have a range of 3, 700 miles (5, 900 km), a maximum airspeed of 250 knots and can ascend to 15, 300 metres (50, 000 feet), the document explains. Their missions can last up to 18 hours. The Reaper carries three cameras as well as laser-guided bombs. Three communication networks relay information between the RAF ground station in the UK and the UAV:"a secure internet-based chat function, a secure radio routed via satellite and a secure telephone system"."The United Kingdom has reported only one civilian casualty incident, in which four civilians were killed and two <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>civilians</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>injured</trigger> in a remotely piloted <role id='role-5-Instrument'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-Instrument'trigno='4'>aircraft</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>strike</trigger> by the <role id='role-5-Attacker'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-Injurer'trigno='4'>Royal Air Force</role></role> in <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>Afghanistan</role> on 25 March 2011,"Emmerson's report states. An RAF inquiry found that"the actions of the [ground] crew had been in accordance with the applicable rules of engagement". The special rapporteur said that he was informed that during RAF operations in Afghanistan, targeting intelligence is"thoroughly scrubbed"to ensure accuracy before authorisation to proceed is given. RAF strikes, he points out, are accountable in the UK through the Ministry of Defence and parliament. By contrast, Emmerson criticises the CIA's involvement in US drone strikes for creating"an almost insurmountable obstacle to transparency". He adds:"One consequence is that the United States has to date failed to reveal its own data on the level of civilian casualties inflicted through the use of remotely piloted aircraft in classified operations conducted in Pakistan and elsewhere."Recent prounouncments from Barack Obama, however, have stressed that"before any strike is taken, there must be near-certainty that no civilians will be killed or injured". Emmerson acknowledges that:"If used in strict compliance with the principles of international humanitarian law, remotely piloted aircraft are capable of reducing the risk of civilian casualties in armed conflict by significantly improving the situational awareness of military commanders."But, he cautions, there is"no clear international consensus"on the laws controlling the deployment of drone strikes. The special rapporteur concludes by urging:"the United States to further clarify its position on the legal and factual issues … to declassify, to the maximum extent possible, information relevant to its lethal extraterritorial counter-terrorism operations; and to release its own data on the level of civilian casualties inflicted through the use of remotely piloted aircraft, together with information on the evaluation methodology used."

text: On 19 September 2019, a suicide car <trigger id='trigger-0'>bombing</trigger> occurred outside a <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>hospital</role> in Qalati Ghilji, Zabul Province, Afghanistan. At least 20 <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>people</role> were estimated to be <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger> and over 90 <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>others</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>injured</trigger>. By 20 September the <trigger id='trigger-3'>death</trigger> toll had risen to <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>39</role>, with most of the victims being doctors and patients. More than 140 <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>people</role> were also <trigger id='trigger-4'>injured</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-5'>attack</trigger>, although the true number is believed to be higher. The Taliban later claimed that they meant to bomb the National Directorate of Security, a governmental intelligence building next door to the hospital, but were unable to park there so they ended up parking in front of the hospital instead. Governor Rahmatullah Yarmal later said that the <role id='role-6-Artifact'trigno='6'>hospital</role> had been <trigger id='trigger-6'>destroyed</trigger>. The hospital was the main health facility in Zabul Province before the <trigger id='trigger-7'>bombing</trigger>. == References ==

text: Lawyers for the coroner in charge of inquests into the 1974 <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Birmingham</role> <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>pub</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>bombings</trigger> have said the <trigger id='trigger-1'>hearings</trigger> will not resolve the “enduring injustice” for victims and their families. Sir Peter Thornton QC is challenging a High Court ruling which ordered him to reconsider his decision to exclude an enquiry into the identities of those who “planted, planned, procured and authorised the bombs” . The <trigger id='trigger-2'>bombings</trigger> in two <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>city</role> centre <role id='role-2-Target'trigno='2'>pubs</role>, widely believed to be the work of the <role id='role-2-Attacker'trigno='2'>IRA</role>, <trigger id='trigger-3'>killed</trigger> 21 <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>people</role> and <trigger id='trigger-4'>injured</trigger> <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>182</role>–making it the deadliest peacetime attack in the UK at the time. For the reasons the coroner gave. . . these inquests cannot resolve the enduring injustice. Peter Skelton QC, for the coroner Outlining his submissions to the Court of Appeal, Peter Skelton QC said: “The 21 <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>people</role> who <trigger id='trigger-5'>died</trigger> in the bombings and their families have suffered an enduring injustice. “So too have <role id='role-14-Victim'trigno='14'>those</role> who were <trigger id='trigger-14'>injured</trigger> and their families, and countless others who have been affected. “The pain and grief they have borne has been exacerbated by the fact no-one has ever been held accountable in law. “But, for the reasons the coroner gave … these inquests cannot resolve the enduring injustice.” Mr Skelton, representing the coroner, added that the victims, their families and the public interest “cannot be served” by a promised resolution that “cannot be delivered” . Two High Court judges quashed a decision by Sir Peter to exclude the “perpetrator issue” from the new <trigger id='trigger-6'>hearings</trigger> following a judicial review brought on behalf of the bereaved families by Julie Hambleton, whose sister <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>Maxine</role> was 18 when she was <trigger id='trigger-7'>killed</trigger> in the bombings. Ten of the families were in court on Tuesday to hear the appeal before the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Burnett, Lady Justice Hallett and Lord Justice McCombe. They are also arguing it is necessary for the inquests to investigate the perpetrator issue because the <role id='role-15-Investigator'trigno='15'>police</role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>investigation</trigger> into the bombings resulted in a “notorious miscarriage of justice” . Six <role id='role-9-Killer'trigno='9'><role id='role-8-Detainee'trigno='8'>men</role></role>, known as the Birmingham Six, were <trigger id='trigger-8'>imprisoned</trigger> for the <trigger id='trigger-9'>murders</trigger> and served 17 years behind bars in one of Britain’s most infamous miscarriages of justice before their convictions were quashed. Five West Midlands Police <role id='role-13-Defendant'trigno='13'>officers</role> were <trigger id='trigger-13'>charged</trigger> with perverting the course of justice in connection with the original criminal investigation, but a judge ruled in 1993 that a fair trial would be impossible. There has never been an effective and independent investigation into who was responsible for the atrocity Hugh Southey QC, for the familes <role id='role-16-Participant'trigno='16'><role id='role-16-Participant'trigno='16'>Hugh Southey QC</role></role>, representing the families, <trigger id='trigger-16'>said</trigger> there was the “most pressing need for a thorough investigation” . He <trigger id='trigger-17'>told</trigger> the <role id='role-17-Participant'trigno='17'><role id='role-17-Participant'trigno='17'>court</role></role>: “The actions of West Midlands Police <role id='role-10-Investigator'trigno='10'>officers</role> in the <trigger id='trigger-10'>investigation</trigger> and subsequent criminal <trigger id='trigger-11'>convictions</trigger> are often considered to be the worst miscarriage of justice in British legal history. “There has never been an effective and independent investigation into who was responsible for the atrocity. “There is no prospect of such an investigation occurring, apart from within the inquest. “Despite that, the appellant decided not to investigate the issue of who was responsible.” Mr <role id='role-18-Participant'trigno='18'><role id='role-18-Participant'trigno='18'>Southey</role></role> later <trigger id='trigger-18'>added</trigger>: “There is the utmost public interest in the proper investigation of who was responsible for the Birmingham bombings. “The families of the deceased said to the appellant that the investigation of this issue was so important to them that if it did not form part of the scope of the inquest ‘ we may as well not have an inquest at all’.” Speaking before the hearing, Mrs <role id='role-19-Participant'trigno='19'><role id='role-19-Participant'trigno='19'>Hambleton</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-19'>said</trigger>: “It will be utterly redundant to have the inquests unless the perpetrators, their associates and those who prepared and planted the bombs are included.” <role id='role-20-Participant'trigno='20'><role id='role-20-Participant'trigno='20'>She</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-20'>said</trigger> supporters of the families’campaign group Justice4the21 have so far raised £ 75, 000 for the case after Mrs Hambleton was refused legal aid. The <role id='role-12-Demonstrator'trigno='12'>group</role> held a <trigger id='trigger-12'>demonstration</trigger> outside the Royal Courts of Justice in London in February, supported by members of the Football Lads Alliance. The <trigger id='trigger-21'>hearing</trigger> is due to finish on Tuesday afternoon and the <role id='role-21-JudgeCourt'trigno='21'>judges</role> are expected to give their ruling at a later date.

text: Indonesian <role id='role-39-Recipient'trigno='39'>Police</role> Receive <role id='role-39-Communicator'trigno='39'>Terrorist</role> <trigger id='trigger-39'>Threat</trigger> Targeting Bali JAKARTA — In Indonesia there are growing concerns that more deadly attacks could follow last week’<trigger id='trigger-0'>bombings</trigger> in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Jakarta</role> by Islamist <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>militants</role>. Bali police Tuesday say <role id='role-1-Recipient'trigno='1'>they</role> received an anonymous letter <trigger id='trigger-1'>warning</trigger> that the resort Island will be the next target for a terrorist assault."The letter was <trigger id='trigger-2'>sent</trigger> by an anonymous <role id='role-2-Communicator'trigno='2'>individual</role> to <role id='role-3-Recipient'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Recipient'trigno='2'>Buleleng district</role></role>, and the <role id='role-4-Investigator'trigno='4'>police</role> are still conducting an <trigger id='trigger-4'>investigation</trigger>, and trying to find out <role id='role-3-Communicator'trigno='3'>who</role> <trigger id='trigger-3'>sent</trigger> the letter. But again, I urge <role id='role-5-Recipient'trigno='5'>people</role> in Bali not to be afraid, but they should stay alert,"<trigger id='trigger-5'>said</trigger> Bali Police Chief <role id='role-5-Communicator'trigno='5'>Sugeng Priyanto</role>. Authorities say they've increased security at shopping malls and other locations that draw crowds in Bali. In 2002, the popular resort <role id='role-40-Target'trigno='40'>island</role> was <trigger id='trigger-40'>targeted</trigger> by <role id='role-40-Attacker'trigno='40'>Jemaah Islamiyah</role> (JI), an Indonesia-based terrorist group with links to al-Qaida. The <trigger id='trigger-6'>bombing</trigger> of a <role id='role-6-Target'trigno='6'>club</role> in <role id='role-7-Place'trigno='7'><role id='role-6-Place'trigno='6'>Bali</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>killed</trigger> 202 <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>people</role>, mostly foreigners. The Bali <trigger id='trigger-8'>bombing</trigger> severely hurt Indonesia’s tourism industry, and began a decade of deadly plots in Indonesia carried out by Southeast Asian militants affiliated with al-Qaida. <role id='role-9-Victor'trigno='9'>Indonesia</role> successfully <trigger id='trigger-9'>combated</trigger> the JI related <role id='role-9-Defeated'trigno='9'>terrorist</role> threat through police action, intelligence operations and high profile criminal prosecutions. However, after last week's <trigger id='trigger-10'>attack</trigger> in the center of <role id='role-10-Place'trigno='10'>Jakarta</role> that <trigger id='trigger-11'>killed</trigger> eight people, including four militants, Indonesian security forces are raising concerns that more and deadlier attacks could follow, carried out by groups inspired by Islamic State. Indonesian Special Police patrol at Ngurah Rai Airport in Denpasar on Indonesia's resort island of Bali on Jan. 15, 2016, one day after a series of <trigger id='trigger-12'>explosions</trigger> hit the Indonesian capital <role id='role-12-Place'trigno='12'>Jakarta</role>. The <role id='role-13-Place'trigno='13'>Jakarta</role> <trigger id='trigger-13'>attack</trigger> was the first of its kind in Southeast Asia to be attributed to Syria-based militant Islamists. Authorities say about 500 <role id='role-14-PassengerArtifact'trigno='14'>Indonesians</role> have <trigger id='trigger-14'>travelled</trigger> to the <role id='role-15-Origin'trigno='15'><role id='role-14-Destination'trigno='14'>Middle East</role></role> to join the extremist group. About <role id='role-15-PassengerArtifact'trigno='15'>100</role> are believed to have <trigger id='trigger-15'>returned</trigger>, although experts say only about 15 have combat experience. Jakarta back to normal So far the renewed threat of terrorism has not instilled any widespread sense of panic or fear amongst Indonesians. A security personnel stand guard inside train carriage for women at Manggarai train station in Jakarta, Jan. 8, 2016. Life in Jakarta has quickly returned to normal, less than a week after the deadly <trigger id='trigger-16'>attacks</trigger>. On Tuesday the Starbucks coffee <role id='role-17-Place'trigno='17'>shop</role> that was <trigger id='trigger-17'>bombed</trigger> remained closed and boarded up for repairs, but the memorial of flowers had been removed. Other shops have reopened and traffic at the busy intersection was congested as usual.'Ojek'hero The “ojek” motorcycle taxi drivers were again gathered at the intersection where the <trigger id='trigger-18'>attack</trigger> took place, waiting for their next fares. One of the “ojek” drivers back at work is Muhamad Yunus, who has received widespread praise for the selfless courage he exhibited during the <trigger id='trigger-19'>attack</trigger>. The militant <role id='role-20-Attacker'trigno='20'>attackers</role> last Thursday (January 14) <trigger id='trigger-20'>set off</trigger> two <role id='role-20-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='20'>bombs</role>, the first at the Starbucks and the second at a police traffic <role id='role-20-Place'trigno='20'>station</role> in the middle of the intersection, near Jakarta's oldest department store, Sarinah. After the second <trigger id='trigger-21'>explosion</trigger> <role id='role-22-PassengerArtifact'trigno='22'>Yunus</role> <trigger id='trigger-22'>rushed</trigger> to the police <role id='role-22-Destination'trigno='22'>station</role> to help the wounded even though the <role id='role-23-Attacker'trigno='23'>assailants</role> were <trigger id='trigger-23'>shooting</trigger> at <role id='role-23-Target'trigno='23'>anyone</role> in the <role id='role-23-Place'trigno='23'>area</role>. He said <role id='role-25-Transporter'trigno='25'>he</role> found a <role id='role-24-Victim'trigno='24'>woman</role> whose legs were severely <trigger id='trigger-24'>injured</trigger> and <trigger id='trigger-25'>brought</trigger> <role id='role-25-PassengerArtifact'trigno='25'>her</role> to safety, away from the <trigger id='trigger-26'>firefight</trigger>. “I got that woman and I <trigger id='trigger-27'>told</trigger> <role id='role-27-Participant'trigno='27'><role id='role-27-Participant'trigno='27'>her</role></role>, don’t cry. Please be strong. Be strong. Please don’t be sad,” <role id='role-28-Participant'trigno='28'><role id='role-28-Participant'trigno='28'>Yunus</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-28'>said</trigger>. Yunus said he found out later that the woman and her nephew were stopped by the police for a traffic violation at the time of the <trigger id='trigger-29'>blast</trigger>. Her <role id='role-30-Victim'trigno='30'>nephew</role> <trigger id='trigger-30'>died</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-31'>explosion</trigger>. Kami tidak takut After the Jakarta <trigger id='trigger-32'>attack</trigger> there have been <trigger id='trigger-33'>demonstrations</trigger> by Indonesian <role id='role-34-Communicator'trigno='34'><role id='role-33-Demonstrator'trigno='33'>Muslims</role></role> to denounce terrorism and <trigger id='trigger-34'>call</trigger> for the <role id='role-34-Recipient'trigno='34'>government</role> to eradicate radical militants and supporters of Islamic State in the country. A"Pray for Jakarta"message (top) is displayed on a screen as Indonesians gather outside the <trigger id='trigger-35'>damaged</trigger> Starbucks coffee <role id='role-35-Artifact'trigno='35'>shop</role> in central Jakarta on Jan. 17, 2016 following the deadly gun and bomb <trigger id='trigger-41'>attacks</trigger> that rocked the city on Jan. 14. Indonesians also have started to use hashtags like"PrayforJakarta"and"Kamitidaktakut"or"Wearenotafraid"in English, on social media. Yunus’s act of heroism has been held up as an example of Indonesia’s resolve to stand up against terrorism. “I am not afraid. We won’t be scared any more,” <role id='role-42-Participant'trigno='42'><role id='role-42-Participant'trigno='42'>he</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-42'>said</trigger>. Dismantling terror networks Meanwhile Indonesian <role id='role-36-Participant'trigno='36'><role id='role-36-Participant'trigno='36'>authorities</role></role> have <trigger id='trigger-36'>promised</trigger> to intensify their efforts to monitor radical networks in the country. Police believe the alleged mastermind of the Jakarta attack, an Indonesian fighting with Islamic State in Syria called Bahrun Naim, used social media to <trigger id='trigger-43'>communicate</trigger> his radical <role id='role-43-Topic'trigno='43'>ideas</role> to <role id='role-43-Participant'trigno='43'><role id='role-43-Participant'trigno='43'>followers</role></role> in Indonesia. In December police say <role id='role-44-Impeder'trigno='44'>they</role> successfully <trigger id='trigger-44'>disrupted</trigger> plans by militants to launch a string of deadly attacks on Christmas and New Year celebrations, as well as against the country's Shia Muslim minority. Prior to last week, the last major <trigger id='trigger-37'>attack</trigger> in the world's most populous Muslim nation was the twin <trigger id='trigger-38'>bombing</trigger> of luxury <role id='role-38-Target'trigno='38'>hotels</role> in <role id='role-38-Place'trigno='38'>Jakarta</role> in 2009. Ade Irma in Jakarta contributed to this report.

text: THE TWIN TOWERS; Deadly Bomb Was Cheap and Easily Made, Experts Say The <role id='role-1-Artifact'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='0'>bomb</role></role> that <trigger id='trigger-0'>savaged</trigger> the <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>World Trade Center</role>, investigators and explosive experts said yesterday, apparently was <trigger id='trigger-1'>put together</trigger> with ordinary <role id='role-1-Components'trigno='1'>chemicals</role> that are widely and cheaply available at chemical supply houses and gardening centers throughout the country. Experts now estimate that the bomb weighed about 1, 000 pounds and that the <role id='role-2-AcquiredEntity'trigno='2'>chemicals</role> to make it were <trigger id='trigger-2'>bought</trigger> for a little more than <role id='role-2-PaymentBarter'trigno='2'>$400</role>. Though a young chemical <role id='role-3-Detainee'trigno='3'>engineer</role> was <trigger id='trigger-3'>arrested</trigger> yesterday in connection with the explosion, the experts say that such a bomb could have been made by almost anyone with the help of one of scores of manuals, obtainable in bookstores and libraries, that provide step-by-step instructions."It's very easy to <trigger id='trigger-4'>make</trigger> one of these things,"said Edward M. Roy, an explosives expert at the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology in Socorro, N. M."I tell my students, a lot of <role id='role-5-Artifact'trigno='5'>explosives</role> I can <trigger id='trigger-5'>make</trigger> in my wastebasket."A Jumble of Chemicals Following the trail of <role id='role-6-Detainee'trigno='6'>Mohammed A. Salameh</role>, the ﬁrst suspect <trigger id='trigger-6'>arrested</trigger> in the bombing, <role id='role-7-Investigator'trigno='7'>investigators</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>discovered</trigger> a jumble of chemicals, chemistry implements and detonating materials stacked in a storage locker at 69 Mallory Avenue in Jersey City that they say may also have served as the bomb laboratory. The day before the <trigger id='trigger-9'>explosion</trigger> that <trigger id='trigger-8'>killed</trigger> at least ﬁve <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>people</role> and <trigger id='trigger-10'>injured</trigger> more than 1, 000 <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'>others</role>, Mr. Salameh and several other men made"numerous trips"to the locker, which Mr. Salameh had rented for $97 a month late last year, the authorities say. <role id='role-11-Transporter'trigno='11'>The suspects</role> <trigger id='trigger-11'>traveled</trigger> in a yellow Ford <role id='role-11-Vehicle'trigno='11'>van</role>, the investigators say, which has been identiﬁed as the vehicle that carried the explosive into the underground garage of the World Trade Center. A Thick Paste The investigators and experts say that after <trigger id='trigger-12'>mixing</trigger> the three main <role id='role-12-Components'trigno='12'>chemicals</role>--nitric and sulfuric acids and urea, a common ingredient in fertilizers--into a thick paste, the bombers are believed to have <trigger id='trigger-13'>packed</trigger> the <role id='role-13-Components'trigno='13'>material</role> into half a dozen or so cardboard boxes. <role id='role-14-Transporter'trigno='14'>They</role> simply loaded the boxes loosely into <role id='role-14-Vehicle'trigno='14'>the van</role>, without using a special container for them, the investigators believe, and <trigger id='trigger-14'>drove</trigger> across the <role id='role-14-Origin'trigno='14'>Hudson River</role> to <role id='role-14-Destination'trigno='14'>the trade center</role>. <role id='role-16-Attacker'trigno='16'><role id='role-15-Attacker'trigno='15'>The bombers</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>ignited</trigger> their <role id='role-15-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='15'>concoction</role>, investigators believe, with several smaller nitroglycerine <role id='role-15-Instrument'trigno='15'>bombs</role>, which <role id='role-16-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='16'>themselves</role> were <trigger id='trigger-16'>touched off</trigger> with the kind of <role id='role-16-Instrument'trigno='16'>blasting cap</role> routinely used at construction and mining sites across the country. The blasting cap is the only ingredient in the deadly mix, the experts and law-enforcement ofﬁcials say, that requires a license or permit for purchase, and most probably was stolen. Manuals Were Found The investigators said they found manuals for bomb making in one of the apartments that <role id='role-17-Jailer'trigno='17'>they</role> raided after <trigger id='trigger-17'>arresting</trigger> Mr. <role id='role-17-Detainee'trigno='17'>Salameh</role>. Neil C. Livingstone, the president of the Institute on Terrorism and Sub-National Conﬂict in Washington, said that as a test of how easy it was to obtain such guides to destruction, he recently wrote to a publishing house using a child's lined notepad and a crayon. Three of the bomb-making <role id='role-18-PassengerArtifact'trigno='18'>manuals</role> were promptly <trigger id='trigger-18'>delivered</trigger> to the <role id='role-18-Destination'trigno='18'>address</role> Mr. Livingstone had given, he said, no questions asked. Though building the bomb was relatively easy, the experts say, it was not by any means free of danger. The bulkiest part of the bomb, they say, was extremely stable and could only have been touched off with a tremendous kick, like that provided by nitroglycerine. Making the nitroglycerine, by <trigger id='trigger-19'>blending</trigger> some of the <role id='role-19-Components'trigno='19'>chemicals</role>, was the trickiest part of the process. As the <role id='role-20-Components'trigno='20'>chemicals</role> are <trigger id='trigger-20'>mixed</trigger> to form this <role id='role-20-Artifact'trigno='20'>compound</role>, said Dr. Per-Anders Persson, the director of the center for explosives research at the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, they get hot and may explode. Often, he said, beakers are packed in dry ice to keep the chemicals at a safe temperature. A Dangerous Mix The nitroglycerine could have also exploded prematurely with any jolt or sharp change in temperature, the experts said. The bombers risked blowing themselves up as well, the experts said, when <role id='role-21-ManufacturerAssembler'trigno='21'>they</role> <trigger id='trigger-21'>hooked up</trigger> the wires connecting the <role id='role-21-Artifact'trigno='21'>bomb</role>'s trigger with the <role id='role-21-Components'trigno='21'>blasting cap</role>. Dr. Robert H. Kupperman, a senior adviser for science and technology at the Center for Strategic and International Studies at Georgetown University, said that perhaps the greatest skill in making the bomb came in rigging the chain of triggering explosives so they all tore into the bulk of the bomb for maximum effect, as investigators at the World Trade Center say apparently happened. So far, in more than a week of <trigger id='trigger-22'>searching</trigger>, <role id='role-22-Investigator'trigno='22'>they</role> have not found a single grain of the main explosive material. Sulfuric Acid Widely Sold William Lazor, a senior technical consultant at the Du Pont Company in Wilmington, Del. , said that sulfuric acid is the most widely sold chemical in the United States, used in the manufacture of everything from battery acid to detergents and shampoos. Dale Ladysh, another consultant at Du Pont, said that nitric acid is only slightly behind in popularity. It is used, he said, in the electronics industry and for <trigger id='trigger-23'>making</trigger> stainless steel and many industrial dies and <role id='role-23-Artifact'trigno='23'>pigmentations</role>. Both acids are commonly used metal cleaners. According to Rick Amberg of Amberg Perennial Farm and Garden Center in Westﬁeld, N. J. , urea is often scattered over lawns to make them grow lustrously, and is also used in making plastics. Mr. <role id='role-24-Giver'trigno='24'>Amberg</role> <trigger id='trigger-24'>sells</trigger> a plastic 50-pound bag of urea for <role id='role-24-PaymentBarter'trigno='24'>$20. 99</role>. In Newark, the <role id='role-25-Giver'trigno='25'>Dooner & Smith Chemical Company</role> <trigger id='trigger-25'>sells</trigger> a 15-gallon drum of <role id='role-25-AcquiredEntity'trigno='25'>sulfuric acid</role>, weighing 172 pounds, for <role id='role-25-PaymentBarter'trigno='25'>$41. 28</role>. The same size container of nitric acid costs $44 and weighs 220 pounds."<role id='role-27-Damager'trigno='27'><role id='role-26-ManufacturerAssembler'trigno='26'>Whoever</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-26'>put</trigger> <role id='role-26-Artifact'trigno='26'>that thing</role> together really intended to do a lot of <trigger id='trigger-27'>damage</trigger>,"said Mr. Roy."This kind of explosive device is often used to fracture and move rock. It expands slowly with great force."

text: An ISIS-inspired <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Utah</role> <role id='role-0-Detainee'trigno='0'>teen</role> has been <trigger id='trigger-0'>arrested</trigger> after bringing a homemade bomb to his high school and attempting to detonate it, <role id='role-0-Jailer'trigno='0'>police</role> said. The <role id='role-2-Transporter'trigno='2'>student</role>, whose identity was not released, <trigger id='trigger-2'>brought</trigger> the homemade <role id='role-2-PassengerArtifact'trigno='2'>explosive</role> to <role id='role-2-Destination'trigno='2'>Pine View High School</role> in St. George inside of his backpack on Monday. An alleged would-be bombing at the 1, 100-student school was ultimately thwarted when concerned classmates notified faculty and a school resource officer of the boy’s “suspicious” backpack that had smoke coming out, cops said. The <role id='role-1-Detainee'trigno='1'>suspect</role> was <trigger id='trigger-1'>arrested</trigger> after the <role id='role-3-Origin'trigno='3'>school</role> was <trigger id='trigger-3'>evacuated</trigger> and authorities, including the bomb squad and <role id='role-4-Investigator'trigno='4'>FBI</role>, <trigger id='trigger-4'>investigated</trigger>. “Based on <role id='role-5-Investigator'trigno='5'>our</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>investigation</trigger> we can confirm this was a failed attempt to <trigger id='trigger-6'>detonate</trigger> a homemade <role id='role-6-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='6'>explosive</role> at the school,” the St. George Police Department said, adding that after <trigger id='trigger-7'>examining</trigger> the explosive <role id='role-7-ObservedEntity'trigno='7'>device</role> “bomb squad members indicted that if it had detonated; the device had the potential to cause significant <trigger id='trigger-8'>injury</trigger> or <trigger id='trigger-9'>death</trigger>.” The department noted that “it was also determined that the male had been researching information and expressing interest in ISIS and promoting the organization.” Authorities said additional <trigger id='trigger-10'>charges</trigger> may be brought. The teen is also being eyed as a suspect who raised the Islamic State group’s flag on a pole at another Utah high school last month — one day after the deadly Valentine’s Day shooting rampage at a Florida high school. Police Officer Ken Thompson told the Associated Press that when the search warrant was executed at the teen’s home “there was evidence taken from the house that tied him to the Feb. 15 flag case at Hurricane High School. <role id='role-12-Victim'trigno='12'>No one</role> was <trigger id='trigger-12'>hurt</trigger> during the Monday incident at the high school and no <role id='role-11-Artifact'trigno='11'>property</role> was <trigger id='trigger-11'>damaged</trigger>. Washington County School District spokesman Steve Dunham said: “I think it is a shock to all of us that something like this has happened in one of our schools.” The police department hailed the students who notified faculty of the smoking backpack. “Their immediate action played a large role in this incident ending with no <trigger id='trigger-13'>injuries</trigger>,” the St. George Police Department said. text: Friend of Boston Marathon Bomber Faces Up to 7 Years BOSTON — A college friend of Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev might have prevented a university police officer's shooting death by helping authorities find Tsarnaev instead of helping him, the officer's family said in a court filing Wednesday. Massachusetts Institute of Technology Officer <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>Sean Collier</role> was <trigger id='trigger-0'>killed</trigger> in an encounter with Tsarnaev and his brother, <role id='role-0-Killer'trigno='0'>Tamerlan Tsarnaev</role>, in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Cambridge</role> hours after authorities publicly released photographs and videos of them as suspects in the April 2013 bombing, which killed three people and injured more than 260. <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>Tamerlan</role> later <trigger id='trigger-1'>died</trigger> after a shootout with <role id='role-1-Killer'trigno='1'>police</role> in <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>Watertown</role>, and Dzhokhar was found hiding in a covered boat docked in a backyard there. Federal prosecutors filed the statement by Collier's stepfather, Joseph Rogers, along with a recommendation for a seven-year sentence for Tsarnaev's friend Dias Kadyrbayev. That <trigger id='trigger-2'>sentence</trigger> is the maximum agreed to when <role id='role-2-Defendant'trigno='2'>Kadyrbayev</role> pleaded guilty last year to impeding the bombing investigation. Kadyrbayev is being sentenced June 2. A message seeking comment from his attorney wasn't immediately returned Wednesday. Prosecutors said there's no evidence Kadyrbayev knew about the plot to detonate two pressure cooker bombs loaded with shrapnel near the marathon's finish line. They said he recognized Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's photo when authorities released it and he removed Tsarnaev's laptop and backpack from his dorm room at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth."Had the defendant done the right thing, and called the police,"Rogers said,"the Tsarnaev brothers'murderous rampage across Cambridge and Watertown may have been prevented."<role id='role-3-Defendant'trigno='3'>Tsarnaev</role>'s lawyers acknowledged his role in the deadly bombings, and <role id='role-3-JudgeCourt'trigno='3'>he</role> was <trigger id='trigger-3'>convicted</trigger> of many criminal charges. A jury last month sentenced him to death. Two more of his friends--Azamat Tazhayakov and <role id='role-4-Defendant'trigno='4'>Robel Phillipos</role>--have been <trigger id='trigger-4'>convicted</trigger> of impeding the investigation. They are to be sentenced June 5.

text: DUESSELDORF, Germany (Reuters)-A court on Monday <trigger id='trigger-0'>sentenced</trigger> a <role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>German man</role> to life in prison for an attempted <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>attack</trigger> on a train station in 2012, attempted murder of the <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>leader</role> of a far-right anti-Muslim party and for founding a terrorist organization. Marco G. shouted “Allahu Akbar!” (God is greatest) as he entered the courtroom. Three others were <trigger id='trigger-2'>convicted</trigger> in the same case, a German, a <role id='role-2-Defendant'trigno='2'>German-Turkish citizen</role> and an Albanian. <role id='role-4-Defendant'trigno='4'><role id='role-3-Attacker'trigno='3'>They</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>received</trigger> prison sentences of between 9-1 / 2 years and 12 years for membership of the terrorist group and for the plan to <trigger id='trigger-3'>kill</trigger> <role id='role-3-Target'trigno='3'>Markus Beisicht</role>, head of Pro NRW, a small far-right party in the western state of <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>North Rhine-Westphalia</role>. “The <role id='role-7-JudgeCourt'trigno='7'>court</role> has <trigger id='trigger-7'>sentenced</trigger> the <role id='role-7-Defendant'trigno='7'>main suspect</role> to life in prison for attempted murder, attempted <role id='role-6-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='6'>explosives</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>attack</trigger>, the founding of and membership in a terrorist organization and the attempted <trigger id='trigger-5'>murder</trigger> of the <role id='role-5-Target'trigno='5'>head of ‘ Pro NRW’</role>,” said Peter Schuetz, spokesman for Duesseldorf’s higher regional court. The court did not name the terrorist organization. The court said in a statement that <role id='role-8-Attacker'trigno='8'>Marco G. </role> had tried on Dec. 10, 2012 to <trigger id='trigger-8'>detonate</trigger> a homemade <role id='role-8-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='8'>bomb</role> hidden in a sports bag on a platform of <role id='role-8-Target'trigno='8'>Bonn</role>’s central train station. It said the bomb could have killed many people but never went off because its fragile detonator was damaged. The court said Marco G. had, along with the three other defendants, planned several other attacks. “The defendants are inhuman terrorists with an extremely high willingness to commit violence,” said Duscha Gmel, senior public prosecutor. “The fact that nothing happened is not thanks to them. In the case of the Bonn bomb it was merely a lucky coincidence that no explosion with devastating consequences took place.” The sentences could still be appealed at the federal supreme court.

text: Boston Bombing Suspect was on CIA, FBI Watch List U. S. officials say the oldest of the two brothers suspected in the Boston Marathon bombings was placed on a counterterrorism list in late 2011. The officials say the CIA asked that Tamerlan Tsarnaev's name be placed on the list after it was contacted by the Russian government with its concerns that he had become a radical Islamist. Moscow also issued a similar warning to the FBI on Tamerlan Tsarnaev earlier in 2011. Officials say the agency launched an investigation, but eventually concluded he posed no threat. Information sharing U. S. lawmakers have raised concerns about information sharing between law enforcement and intelligence agencies in the aftermath of the April 15 twin bombings that left three people dead and 264 others injured-including at least 14 who lost limbs. Authorities will brief the full U. S. Senate on the investigation into the bombing. Investigators say Tamerlan, 26, and his brother Dzhokar, 19, placed the bombs near the finish line of the Boston Marathon. <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>Tamerlan</role> was <trigger id='trigger-0'>killed</trigger> in a shootout with <role id='role-0-Killer'trigno='0'>police</role> last Thursday, while Dzhokhar was captured a day later. Dzhokhar has been charged with using a weapon of mass destruction. He is in federal custody in a Boston hospital. Russia visit Several months after he first came to the attention of U. S. federal agents, Tamerlan Tsarnaev left the U. S. in January 2012 for a six-month visit to Russia. When he returned, his name generated an alert by a screening system used by U. S. Customs agents. But Republican Senator Lindsey Graham said the FBI told him it was not aware at the time of Tsarnaev's trip to Russia. U. S. investigators have questioned the suspects'parents in the Russian republic of Dagestan to determine if Tamerlan had contacts with Islamic extremists during his 2012 visit. The family is originally from Chechnya, where Muslim insurgents have been engaged in a bloody conflict with Russia for decades. Memorial service U. S. Vice President Joe Biden denounced the suspects Wednesday in Boston. Biden spoke at a memorial service for a university police <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>officer</role> allegedly <trigger id='trigger-1'>gunned down</trigger> by the <role id='role-2-Killer'trigno='2'><role id='role-1-Killer'trigno='1'>suspects</role></role> just days after the bombings."Why, whether it’s al-Qaida central. . . or two twisted, perverted, cowardly, knock-off jihadists here in Boston. Why do they do what they do?” he asked. Several thousand mourners gathered at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to remember the <trigger id='trigger-2'>slain</trigger> policeman, <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>Sean Collier</role>. Biden said the United States must keep its values in the face of threats from terrorists. Boston authorities on Wednesday reopened Boylston Street to the public. It is the city thoroughfare where the explosions occurred. Images of Boston Bombing Suspects

text: July 29, 2011 --When Army Pfc. <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>Naser Jason Abdo</role>, accused of plotting planning a deadly <trigger id='trigger-0'>bombing</trigger> and shooting attack on <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>soldiers</role> at <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Fort Hood</role>, made his first appearance in court in Waco, Texas, today, he yelled the name of accused Fort Hood shooter Major Nidal Hasan. Hasan is facing the death penalty for allegedly killing 13 people and wounding more than 30 in an assault on Fort Hood in November 2009. Like Hasan, Abdo may have taken some of his inspiration from Anwar al-Awlaki, a radical American-born Islamic cleric who is among the leaders of the Yemen-based al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP). One senior U. S. official <trigger id='trigger-24'>told</trigger> <role id='role-24-Participant'trigno='24'><role id='role-24-Participant'trigno='24'>ABC News</role></role> that after <role id='role-23-Detainee'trigno='23'>Abdo</role> was <trigger id='trigger-23'>arrested</trigger> at a Killeen, Texas <role id='role-23-Place'trigno='23'>hotel</role> Wednesday, Abdo mentioned the name of al-Awlaki. <role id='role-1-Participant'trigno='1'><role id='role-1-Participant'trigno='1'>Nidal Hasan</role></role> had exchanged <trigger id='trigger-1'>emails</trigger> with Awlaki, according to U. S. authorities. Al-Awlaki is believed to have inspired several other terror plots in the U. S. as well, including the bungled Christmas Day <role id='role-25-Instrument'trigno='25'>underwear</role> <trigger id='trigger-25'>bombing</trigger> of Northwest <role id='role-25-Target'trigno='25'>flight 253</role>. According to senior law enforcement officials, when <role id='role-2-Observer'trigno='2'>police</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>searched</trigger> <role id='role-2-ObservedEntity'trigno='2'>Abdo</role>'s hotel <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>room</role>, in addition to firearms, ammunition and bomb-making materials, they also found an article from a jihadi magazine produced by al-Awlaki's organization, al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula. The officials told ABC News Abdo had apparently stashed in the room an article from the first issue of al Qaeda's"Inspire"magazine called"How to Build a Bomb in the Kitchen of Your Mom."AQAP, a media-savvy affiliate of al Qaeda, has produced six issues of"Inspire"so far, each featuring praise for martyrs and instructional sections on firearms and explosives for the prospective terrorist. <role id='role-3-Defendant'trigno='3'>Abdo</role> was <trigger id='trigger-3'>charged</trigger> Friday with the federal crime of <trigger id='trigger-26'>possession</trigger> of a non-registered firearm in addition to previous charges of possession of <role id='role-28-Victim'trigno='28'>child</role> <trigger id='trigger-28'>pornography</trigger> and <trigger id='trigger-29'>going</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-27'>AWOL</trigger> from <role id='role-27-Perpetrator'trigno='27'>his</role> unit. As <role id='role-4-PassengerArtifact'trigno='4'>he</role> was being <trigger id='trigger-4'>led</trigger> from the <role id='role-4-Origin'trigno='4'>courtroom</role>, <role id='role-30-Communicator'trigno='30'>he</role> <trigger id='trigger-30'>yelled out</trigger>,"Nidal Hasan!","Fort Hood!", and"<role id='role-30-Topic'trigno='30'>2009</role>!". READ: <role id='role-5-Detainee'trigno='5'>Soldier</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>Arrested</trigger> in Alleged <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>Fort Hood</role> Plot <role id='role-31-Perpetrator'trigno='31'><role id='role-6-PassengerArtifact'trigno='6'>Abdo</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>Went</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-31'>AWOL</trigger> July 4 <role id='role-32-Demonstrator'trigno='32'>Abdo</role>, a Muslim soldier who was in the 101st Airborne Division at Fort Campbell more than 800 miles away in Kentucky, attempted to leave the military in 2010 after <trigger id='trigger-32'>protesting</trigger> the <role id='role-32-Target'trigno='32'>U. S</role>.'s involvement in Iraq and <role id='role-32-Topic'trigno='32'>Afghanistan</role>. In August 2010 he told ABC News he should not have to participate in what he called an"unjust <trigger id='trigger-33'>war</trigger>"."Any Muslim who knows his religion or maybe takes into account what his religion says can find out very clearly why he should not participate in the U. S. military,"Abdo said then. READ: Devout <role id='role-7-PassengerArtifact'trigno='7'>Muslim</role> Hopes to Avoid <trigger id='trigger-7'>Deployment</trigger> to <role id='role-7-Destination'trigno='7'>Afghanistan</role> The <role id='role-8-PlaceOfEmployment'trigno='8'>Army</role> approved <role id='role-8-Employee'trigno='8'>Abdo</role>'s request to be <trigger id='trigger-8'>discharged</trigger> as a conscientious objector, but just days later the <trigger id='trigger-34'>discharge</trigger> was put on hold and <role id='role-9-Defendant'trigno='9'>he</role> was <trigger id='trigger-9'>charged</trigger> with having child <trigger id='trigger-35'>pornography</trigger> on <role id='role-35-Perpetrator'trigno='35'>his</role> government-issued computer. Military <role id='role-10-Observer'trigno='10'>investigators</role> had been <trigger id='trigger-10'>looking</trigger> at <role id='role-10-ObservedEntity'trigno='10'>Abdo</role>'s computer files after he made"radical statements,"law enforcement sources told ABC News. After he was told <role id='role-11-Defendant'trigno='11'>he</role> would <trigger id='trigger-11'>face</trigger> a <role id='role-11-JudgeCourt'trigno='11'>court</role> martial, <role id='role-36-Perpetrator'trigno='36'><role id='role-12-Transporter'trigno='12'>Abdo</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>went</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-36'>AWOL</trigger> from <role id='role-12-Origin'trigno='12'>Fort Campbell</role> on July 4. Though vocal in <role id='role-13-Communicator'trigno='13'>his</role> <trigger id='trigger-13'>protestations</trigger> against the mission in the Middle East, <role id='role-14-Communicator'trigno='14'>Abdo</role> did not make any public <trigger id='trigger-14'>threats</trigger> against the <role id='role-14-Recipient'trigno='14'>military</role>. But when he was discovered Wednesday, <role id='role-37-Attacker'trigno='37'>Abdo</role> was apparently in the final planning stages of a deadly <trigger id='trigger-37'>attack</trigger>. He was caught in part because a wary local gun store <role id='role-16-Participant'trigno='16'><role id='role-16-Participant'trigno='16'>owner</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-16'>called</trigger> police after <role id='role-15-Giver'trigno='15'>Abdo</role> visited the store to <trigger id='trigger-15'>buy</trigger> ammunition and <role id='role-15-AcquiredEntity'trigno='15'>gunpowder</role>. <role id='role-17-Topic'trigno='17'>He</role> was acting"suspicious,"Guns Galore owner <role id='role-17-Participant'trigno='17'><role id='role-17-Participant'trigno='17'>Greg Ebert</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-17'>told</trigger> ABC News."There was clearly something wrong with him,"Ebert said."<role id='role-18-Participant'trigno='18'><role id='role-18-Participant'trigno='18'>We</role></role> made a decision to <trigger id='trigger-18'>call</trigger> the police and fortunately it worked out."After <role id='role-19-Detainee'trigno='19'>his</role> <trigger id='trigger-19'>arrest</trigger>, Abdo admitted <role id='role-39-Attacker'trigno='39'><role id='role-38-Attacker'trigno='38'>he</role></role> planned to <trigger id='trigger-39'>plant</trigger> two <role id='role-39-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='39'>bombs</role> at a local <role id='role-39-Place'trigno='39'>restaurant</role> frequented by Fort Hood <role id='role-39-Target'trigno='39'>soldiers</role> and hoped to <trigger id='trigger-38'>gun down</trigger> any <role id='role-38-Target'trigno='38'>survivors</role> of the dual <trigger id='trigger-40'>blast</trigger>, according to law enforcement documents obtained by ABC News. According to the documents, military officials believe the incident"was likely isolated to the Fort Hood area and the <role id='role-41-Detainee'trigno='41'>suspect</role> in <trigger id='trigger-41'>custody</trigger>, and that <trigger id='trigger-20'>arrest</trigger> of the <role id='role-20-Detainee'trigno='20'>suspect</role> has mitigated any further threats related to this incident."Abdo's former lawyer, James M. Branum, declined to comment for an <role id='role-21-Participant'trigno='21'><role id='role-21-Participant'trigno='21'>ABC News</role></role> report except to <trigger id='trigger-21'>say</trigger> Thursday he hasn't <trigger id='trigger-22'>spoken</trigger> with his <role id='role-22-Participant'trigno='22'><role id='role-22-Participant'trigno='22'>client</role></role>"in a long time."ABC News'Sarah Netter, Luis Martinez and Lee Ferran contributed to this report. text: LISTEN TO ARTICLE 5: 16 SHARE THIS ARTICLE Share Tweet Post Email This past April, a number of Venezuelan military dissidents were holed up in neighboring Colombia plotting to overthrow the government of President Nicolas Maduro when they were approached by a group with similar plans. The second group, mostly civilians, wanted to assassinate Maduro and suggested joining forces. They showed videos of armed drones shipped from Miami and being tested on a Colombian farm. Maduro attends a ceremony prior to explosion on Aug. 4. Photographer: Juan Barreto / AFP via Getty Images The military dissidents declined to participate. They found the civilians unprofessional and weren’t interested in killing Maduro. Their goal was to capture him and put him on trial. Two weeks ago, when <role id='role-7-Target'trigno='7'>Maduro</role> was speaking at a military parade in Caracas, drones packed with plastic <role id='role-7-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='7'>explosives</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>detonated</trigger> nearby in a failed assassination attempt. A <role id='role-15-Participant'trigno='15'><role id='role-15-Participant'trigno='15'>participant</role></role> in the April Bogota <trigger id='trigger-15'>meeting</trigger> said in an interview that he believes the people his group met with were the perpetrators. Infiltrated His group, which included members of all four armed-service branches, was later infiltrated by the Venezuelan security services. <role id='role-8-Detainee'trigno='8'>Several</role> dozen were <trigger id='trigger-8'>arrested</trigger>, breaking up the most serious attempt to overthrow Maduro in his five years in office. The plan was called Operation Constitution. The man remains abroad. His theory about who was behind the drone <trigger id='trigger-9'>attack</trigger> is one of several clues emerging about the <role id='role-6-Attacker'trigno='6'>perpetrators</role> of the Aug. 4 <trigger id='trigger-6'>assault</trigger>. The government also knows some things about the plotters. It says their financier is Osman Delgado, a Venezuelan living in Miami who is linked to a 2017 attack on a military base. Delgado couldn’t be reached for comment. The government has released audio recordings of what seem to be the attackers on the day of <trigger id='trigger-10'>the assassination attempt</trigger>. The recordings reveal a chaotic group bickering and scolding one another for failing to report in or not speaking loudly enough or announcing that the military ceremony being attacked was underway. Security forces check a building after an explosion during the ceremony on Aug. 4. Photographer: Juan Barreto / AFP via Getty Images “Say Something!” At one point, one of the alleged conspirators can be heard giving a series of instructions on how to operate the drone. Later, another demands the status of the rest of the group after one drone is airborne. “Updates please. Say something! Everything is quiet!” she is heard to say. The government appears to be using the plot to pursue political opponents who may have nothing to do with it, an approach it has used in the past. <role id='role-12-Prosecutor'trigno='12'><role id='role-11-Jailer'trigno='11'>It</role></role> has at times <trigger id='trigger-11'>arrested</trigger> <role id='role-11-Detainee'trigno='11'>opponents</role> and <trigger id='trigger-12'>accused</trigger> <role id='role-12-Defendant'trigno='12'>them</role> of sabotage as the economy and basic services have collapsed. In the past, the plots were mostly invented for political purposes; now they’re increasingly real. In the past two weeks, <role id='role-13-Jailer'trigno='13'>the government</role> has <trigger id='trigger-14'>announced</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-13'>the arrests</trigger> of two high-ranking national guardsmen, a congressman and almost a dozen <role id='role-13-Detainee'trigno='13'>other people</role>, many younger than 30. The Venezuelan Justice Organization, a human-rights watchdog, says there are currently about 150 <role id='role-16-Detainee'trigno='16'>servicemen</role> and women <trigger id='trigger-16'>behind bars</trigger>. Soldiers in T-Shirts One group claiming responsibility for this month’s attempt is a network of online activists called Soldados de Franela, or Soldiers in T-Shirts, named after the way street protesters hide their faces. The escaped plotter, however, doesn’t think they are the people he met with in Bogota. What is clear is the depth of despair spreading across <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Venezuela</role> as it descends into a lawless failed state where <trigger id='trigger-0'>crime</trigger> is rampant, those who can are leaving and hunger gnaws away at many of the nation’s remaining 30 million inhabitants. For at least a year, there have been multiple <trigger id='trigger-17'>small-scale rebellions</trigger>, largely unconnected. Officials say as many 34 people, including opposition leaders and former student protesters, conspired in the drone <trigger id='trigger-18'>attack</trigger>. The president was unharmed, but much of the country watched on live television as hundreds of soldiers scattered following the off-camera explosions, deeply embarrassing the government. Juan Requesens Source: AFP TV / AFP via Getty Images Among the detainees are a general and colonel of the national guard and the congressmen, Juan Requesens. <role id='role-5-Defendant'trigno='5'>He</role> has been <trigger id='trigger-5'>charged</trigger> with <trigger id='trigger-19'>attempted homicide</trigger> and <trigger id='trigger-20'>treason</trigger>. The government has released a video of Requesens, 29, that shows him apparently answering an interrogator and acknowledging participating in the plot. His party says he was coerced and drugged. Another video his supporters leaked shows him in a state of ruin, almost naked in what appears to be soiled underwear. 20 More Suspects Authorities are now seeking an additional 20 suspects, including a lawmaker in exile, who are at large across Latin America and in the U. S. The government has named as one of the leaders Julio Borges, the former head of Venezuela’s opposition-led congress, who fled to Colombia earlier this year. Borges has denied involvement and said the attacks were perpetrated from within the government’s own ranks. Soldiers in T-Shirts formed following a wave of anti-government unrest in 2014. Its website and social-media accounts have been popular among demonstrators and resistance groups for updates on protests and news critical of the government. In 2017, Soldiers in T-Shirts began <trigger id='trigger-4'>disseminating messages and videos</trigger> of Oscar Perez, an elite police officer who commandeered a helicopter and called upon Venezuelans to rise up against the government. Security forces <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger> <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>him</role> in January in an hours-long <trigger id='trigger-2'>shootout</trigger> that was, in part, broadcast across social media. One of the Soldiers in T-Shirts leaders, who gave his name as Gregory, confirmed Perez’s <trigger id='trigger-3'>death</trigger> the day of the raid in an interview with CNN en Espanol. Whatever their role in the most recent attack, he said, the group is growing. “This is not a defeat,” he said. “The government wants to view it as a trophy, but there are more of us. We are thousands.” — With assistance by Fabiola Zerpa, and Noris Soto

text: The Islamic Society of Boston, in Cambridge (Joe Spurr / WBUR) We're learning more about the <role id='role-0-IdentifiedObject'trigno='0'>brothers</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>suspected</trigger> of the Marathon <trigger id='trigger-1'>bombing</trigger>. The older of the alleged Marathon bombers, Tamarlan Tsarnaev, started attending Friday prayers at the Islamic Society of Boston, in Cambridge, about a year-and-a-half ago. Anwar Kazmi, a member of the executive board of the Islamic Society of Boston, addresses reporters Monday. (Fred Thys / WBUR) Tsarnaev called attention to himself during one prayer service earlier this year. It happened on Jan. 18 — the Friday prayers just before Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day."The theme of the <trigger id='trigger-4'>sermon</trigger> was about great men like Dr. Martin Luther King, like the prophet, what drove them, their sense of mission, what we could learn from their lives and how we could be inspired by their example, and so when the person <role id='role-2-Communicator'trigno='2'>who</role> was giving the <trigger id='trigger-2'>sermon</trigger> began to talk about King, [Tsarnaev] got up and objected and raised his voice, which is against the etiquette of the <trigger id='trigger-5'>sermon</trigger>,"Anwar Kazmi, a board member of the Islamic Society of Boston Trust, told reporters Monday in front of the small mosque on busy Prospect Street in Cambridge. Kazmi said different people have different memories of what Tsarnaev said that day. Kazmi said some people reported Tsarnaev objected to comparing King to the prophet Mohammed. Others have reported he called the speaker a hypocrite. Kazmi said after the incident, people sat down with Tsarnaev and explained to him that he could not interrupt the <trigger id='trigger-3'>sermon</trigger>."And he seemed to understand and nothing happened after that,"Kazmi said."He continued to come to the mosque even after the incident."Kazmi said one man remembers a positive experience with Tsarnaev. The man ran out of gas, and Tsarnaev ran over to his apartment, got a gas can, filled it up, and brought it to the man. Kazmi said Tsarnaev's younger brother, Dzhokhar, only came once to Friday prayers."And I have been told that on occasion, they would also come here for the dawn prayers, and that the younger one sometimes came accompanied by his older brother,"Kazmi said."The younger one never came here by himself."Kazmi said several members of the congregation are still being interviewed by the FBI about the brothers. He said he doesn't know what the FBI is asking.

text: MUMBAI: A series of <trigger id='trigger-0'>blasts</trigger> took place at Matunga, Khar, Santacruz, Jogeshwari, Borivali and Bhayendar suburban railway <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>stations</role> on Tuesday. All the <trigger id='trigger-1'>explosions</trigger> took place in first class <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>compartments</role> of trains at a time when a majority of Mumbaikars were returning home from office, railway control sources said. Eyewitnesses said a large number of <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>people</role> were seriously <trigger id='trigger-2'>injured</trigger> and all trains on the <role id='role-3-Artifact'trigno='3'>Western line</role> route had been <trigger id='trigger-3'>suspended</trigger>. A PTI reporter at Santa Cruz station said a <trigger id='trigger-4'>blast</trigger> rocked <role id='role-4-Target'trigno='4'>Borivali</role>-bound local at 1824 hours and <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>seven to eight</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>injured</trigger> were taken to nearby hospitals. The <trigger id='trigger-6'>explosion</trigger> occurred in the first class <role id='role-6-Target'trigno='6'>compartment</role> of the train and several passengers were jumped out of the speeding train in panic. Around 12 to 15 <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>injured</trigger> at Santa Cruz station were taken to nearby V N Desai hospital and the entire first class <role id='role-8-Artifact'trigno='8'>bogey</role> had been <trigger id='trigger-8'>emptied</trigger>. All local phones, including mobile services, in the city had jammed apparently due to congestion in the system as anxious people tried to reach their loved ones. Another <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>20</role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>injured</trigger> were admitted to the KEM hospital in Central area of Parel, hospital sources said. Police cordoned off all railway stations on the Western line and strict frisking and checking were carried out at the Central and Harbour sections of local trains services.

text: On 22 July 2019, at least 18 <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>people</role> were <trigger id='trigger-0'>killed</trigger> after a car <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>exploded</trigger> on the road of Aden Adde International Airport and near the Afrin Hotel in <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Mogadishu</role></role>, Somalia. Dozens others were <trigger id='trigger-2'>injured</trigger>, <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>17</role> critically. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for the attack. == Attack == On 22 July 2019, a vehicle laden with <role id='role-3-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='3'>explosives</role> <trigger id='trigger-3'>detonated</trigger> at a <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>checkpoint</role> on the same road as the city's <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>airport</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>killing</trigger> <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>17</role> and <trigger id='trigger-5'>injuring</trigger> 28 <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>others</role> including some who were in critical condition. Witnessed stated that the <trigger id='trigger-6'>explosion</trigger> knocked <role id='role-6-Target'trigno='6'>them</role> off their feet and <trigger id='trigger-7'>damaged</trigger> many <role id='role-7-Place'trigno='7'>buildings</role>. == Reaction == This <trigger id='trigger-10'>attack</trigger> and the <trigger id='trigger-9'>attack</trigger> two days later that <trigger id='trigger-8'>killed</trigger> the <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>Mayor</role> of Mogadishu and six <role id='role-9-Target'trigno='9'>others</role> shocked and were strongly condemned by many countries. == References ==
