text: French police are hunting a suspect believed to have deposited a paper bag containing a device that exploded on Friday, wounding 13 people on a busy pedestrian street in the city of Lyon. France’s counter-terrorism prosecutor, Remy Heitz, said an investigation has been opened for an “attempted murder in relation with a terrorist undertaking” and “criminal terrorist association” . He said no group had yet claimed responsibility for the explosion. Regional authorities said 13 people had suffered mostly minor injuries but 11 were still in hospital on Saturday morning. On Friday, the French president, Emmanuel Macron, called the explosion an “attack” . Heitz described video surveillance that showed the suspect heading toward the centre of Lyon by bike on Friday afternoon. The man was seen arriving on foot, pushing his bike along the pedestrian-only Victor Hugo street, then leaving a paper bag on a concrete block in the middle of the street near a bakery. French police issued this photo from CCTV showing a man wanted in connection with the explosion. Photograph: Police National / Handout / EPA The suspect immediately returned to his bike and left by the same path. One minute later, the explosion shattered the glass of a refrigerator in the bakery, Heitz said. Investigators at the scene have found screws, metallic balls, batteries, a triggering device that can be used remotely and plastic pieces that may come from the explosive device. Police issued an appeal for witnesses on Saturday with a photo of the suspect from video surveillance. They described the man as dangerous. The man was wearing a cap and sunglasses that partially hid his face. Local authorities said security has been enhanced in France’s third-largest city, including more police and military patrols. The Women’s Football World Cup is scheduled to start in France on 7 June. Lyon will host the semi-finals and then the 7 July final. After the explosion, the interior minister, Christophe Castaner, sent instructions for Lyon authorities to strengthen security for “public sites and sporting, cultural and religious events” . On Victor Hugo street, police removed the cordon around the explosion area and the atmosphere on Saturday was almost back to normal, with people doing their shopping–the only oddity being the chalk lines drawn by forensics on the ground. “It was scary,” said Gisele Sanchez, owner of a haberdashery close to the bakery. Large wood planks covered her shop window, which was damaged by the blast. Police found in her shop screws, metallic balls and batteries believed to be from the device, yet Sanchez was able to reopen on Saturday morning. France is jittery over a spate of attacks in recent years, some of them deadly, carried out by people ranging from extremist attackers to mentally unstable individuals. Five people were killed on 11 December in an attack on the Christmas market in Strasbourg, eastern France. The alleged killer, Chérif Chekatt–shot dead by police–had pledged allegiance to Islamic State.

The <role id='role-2-JudgeCourt'trigno='2'>Tokyo District Court</role> handed down <trigger id='trigger-2'>a suspended sentence</trigger> Tuesday to the <role id='role-2-Defendant'trigno='2'>man</role> who landed a drone on the rooftop of the Prime Minister’s Office last April. <role id='role-3-Defendant'trigno='3'><role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>Yasuo Yamamoto</role></role>, 41, was <trigger id='trigger-0'>sentenced</trigger> to two years in prison, <trigger id='trigger-3'>suspended</trigger> for four years. Presiding Judge Mihoko Tanabe also <trigger id='trigger-1'>ordered</trigger> the drone confiscated. According to the complaint, <role id='role-5-Transporter'trigno='5'>Yamamoto</role>, a resident of Obama, Fukui Prefecture, <trigger id='trigger-5'>flew</trigger> the <role id='role-5-Vehicle'trigno='5'>drone</role> out of <role id='role-5-Origin'trigno='5'>a parking lot</role> near the Prime Minister’s Office in Chiyoda Ward on April 9 and intentionally landed it on the <role id='role-5-Destination'trigno='5'>roof</role> of the government building. The <role id='role-4-IdentifiedObject'trigno='4'>drone</role>, equipped with flares and a container filled with radioactive soil and affixed with a radiation sticker, was <trigger id='trigger-4'>discovered</trigger> by <role id='role-4-Identifier'trigno='4'>officials</role> nearly two weeks later on April 22. Although his action did not endanger anyone, his intention to interrupt official duties at the office was clear, Tanabe said in handing down the sentence. Yamamoto had pleaded not guilty. His lawyers said <role id='role-7-Demonstrator'trigno='7'>he</role> intended to <trigger id='trigger-7'>challenge</trigger> the Abe <role id='role-7-Target'trigno='7'><role id='role-6-Target'trigno='6'>administration</role></role>’s <role id='role-7-Topic'trigno='7'><role id='role-6-Topic'trigno='6'>policy on nuclear energy</role></role>, and that as a form of <trigger id='trigger-6'>protest</trigger> the move did not break any laws. Prosecutors had demanded a three-year prison term for Yamamoto as well as the confiscation of his drone. They said his actions were premeditated and clearly intended to interfere with official duties. An expressionless Yamamoto, who appeared at the court in a gray sweatshirt and sweatpants, sat with his head down as the sentence was read out. The incident ignited a heated discussion about the need for regulations for drones. In September, the government revised the Aviation Law to set the first restrictions on how to operate drones. The law, which has been in effect since December, bans drones from areas near airports and above densely populated areas, including all 23 wards in central Tokyo, unless granted government permission. Violators can face a fine of up to ¥ 500, 000.

text: Third London Attacker Named as British PM Faces Mounting Criticism LONDON — British Prime Minister Theresa May is being forced to defend her past record as the country’s interior minister, and the political architect of Britain’s counter-terror system, as more details emerge of the three attackers and what security agencies knew about them before their van-and-<role id='role-0-Instrument'trigno='0'>knife</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>rampage</trigger> Saturday in the heart of <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>London</role>. Ahead of Thursday's vote in a snap post-Brexit parliamentary election, which May called with the expectation of securing a landslide victory, the terror <trigger id='trigger-1'>attack</trigger> is undermining the air of dogged competence May carefully crafted as the country's <role id='role-2-PlaceOfEmployment'trigno='2'>home</role> secretary, a post <role id='role-3-Employee'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Employee'trigno='2'>she</role></role> held for six years and <trigger id='trigger-2'>relinquished</trigger> on <trigger id='trigger-3'>becoming</trigger> prime minister last year. Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May speaks outside 10 Downing Street after an <trigger id='trigger-4'>attack</trigger> on London Bridge and <role id='role-4-Target'trigno='4'>Borough Market</role> left 7 <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>dead</trigger> and <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>dozens</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>injured</trigger> in London, June 4, 2017. Foreign Minister Boris Johnson conceded Tuesday that there were questions to answer about how the three militants slipped through the intelligence net. He was speaking as police named the third attacker as 22-year-old Italian-Moroccan Youssef Zaghba, who was on an Italian watchlist and suspected of being a foreign fighter. Born in Fez, Morocco, in 1995 to an Italian mother and a Moroccan father, Zaghba was stopped by Italian police at the Bologna airport on March 15 of last year after arousing suspicions he was going to join the Islamic State terror group to fight in Syria. Italian officials say he had a one-way ticket to Istanbul and was carrying just a small backpack. His cell phone, which was seized, contained jihadist content, including pictures and videos, and he was placed on a watchlist as a suspected foreign fighter. Italian officials say they shared intelligence on him with both the British and Moroccan security agencies. Lived in Britain The last few years Zaghba lived in Britain, where he worked on and off at a restaurant and a hotel near Regents Park, traveling back and forth to visit his mother, who lives in Bologna. The naming of the third Islamic militant came after it emerged earlier Tuesday that the ringleader of Saturday’s attack, 27-year-old British-Pakistani Khuram Shazad Butt worked for a man accused of helping to <trigger id='trigger-7'>train</trigger> the Islamic <role id='role-7-Learner'trigno='7'>extremists</role> responsible for the July 7, 2005 underground <role id='role-8-Target'trigno='8'>train</role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>bombings</trigger> in <role id='role-8-Place'trigno='8'>London</role>, Britain’s first Islamist suicide attack. Fifty-two <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>people</role> were <trigger id='trigger-9'>killed</trigger> across Britain’s capital in the coordinated <trigger id='trigger-11'>strike</trigger> and more than 700 <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'>others</role> were <trigger id='trigger-10'>injured</trigger>. This is undated three photo combo handout photo issued by the Metropolitan Police on Tuesday June 6, 2017 of Khuram Shazad Butt, left, Rachid Redouane, centre and Youssef Zaghba who have been named as the suspects in Saturday's <trigger id='trigger-12'>attack</trigger> at <role id='role-12-Target'trigno='12'>London Bridge</role>. Counterterror analysts say they are surprised that Butt remained a"low priority"for the security services despite his close connections to Sajeel Shahid, a 41-year-old who ran an all-Muslin gym in east London and was named in a New York court case as having helped to set up weapons <trigger id='trigger-13'>training</trigger> in Pakistan for the July 7 suicide bombers. “It was a blunder to have downgraded the terror threat in Britain so quickly after the <role id='role-14-Place'trigno='14'>Manchester</role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>bombing</trigger>,” said Olivier Guitta, managing director at GlobalStrat, a security and geopolitical risk firm. He says with election campaigning under way coinciding with Ramadan, the Muslim holy month, the chances of attacks were always high. Guitta, who has advised government in the past on counterterrorism, said, “No one should be surprised by the terrorism wave and which is linked to a policy of laissez-faire policy toward extremists.” The main charge leveled against May by Labour politicians and the leaders of the country’s smaller parties is the large cuts she introduced on funding for Britain’s police. Those cuts resulted in police personnel being drawn down from 2010 to 2016 by more than 20, 000 officers. Uncertain election impact On Monday, the opposition parties received support for their criticism from an unlikely quarter. Conservative insider Steve Hilton, the policy guru of former Prime Minister David Cameron, demanded May resign over what he termed “security failures,” which he said led to Saturday’s <trigger id='trigger-15'>attack</trigger> and the <trigger id='trigger-16'>bombing</trigger> of a concert last month in <role id='role-16-Place'trigno='16'>Manchester</role>. He said May should be “resigning, not seeking re-election.” Pollsters are wary of predicting how the terrorist attacks — three in the past 10 weeks — will impact the voting on Thursday, but Labour leaders say they have renewed hope at the very least of reducing the ruling Conservative’s majority as they seek to recast their campaign message in the final hours before voting as “investment versus cuts.” On Sunday, May promised to review Britain's counterterrorism strategy, holding out the prospect of enhanced powers for the security services and longer prison sentences for extremists. May said she wants to take a tougher line with internet providers and social media businesses that allow extremist material on their sites. She warned there has been “far too much tolerance of extremism” in Britain and promised to step up the fight against Islamist terrorism after the <role id='role-17-Target'trigno='17'>London Bridge</role> <trigger id='trigger-17'>attack</trigger>, saying “enough is enough.” Video size width x height pixels Britain PM May:'Enough is Enough'Share this video 0: 00: 30 ▶ 0: 00: 00 / 0: 00: 30 ▶ ▶ Direct link 270p | 1. 5MB 360p | 1. 8MB 480p | 10. 5MB British counterterror chiefs say that while <role id='role-18-Defendant'trigno='18'>Butt</role> was <trigger id='trigger-18'>investigated</trigger> in 2015, he was deemed a low risk. According to Assistant Police Commissioner Mark Rowley, he had seen “nothing to show that a poor decision has been made” in 2015 and that police had no evidence Butt was planning anything. Police, however, confirm they received several warnings from neighbors and associates about Butt. British police and MI5 set up in 2013 an early warning system, known as Project Danube, to help them spot when low-priority suspects might be re-engaging in violent extremism. That program appears to have failed, say critics, as it did not help them identify <role id='role-19-Attacker'trigno='19'>Khalid Masood</role>, the militant responsible for the <role id='role-19-Target'trigno='19'>Westminster Bridge</role> <trigger id='trigger-19'>attack</trigger> in March that <trigger id='trigger-20'>killed</trigger> five <role id='role-20-Victim'trigno='20'>people</role>. Nor did it alert them to the Manchester Arena bomber, British-Libyan Salman Abedi.

text: Venezuela crisis: Maduro to raise fuel prices to <trigger id='trigger-7'>combat</trigger> smuggling Venezuela’s heavily subsidised domestic fuel prices should rise to international levels to avoid billions of dollars in annual losses as a result of smuggling, <role id='role-11-Participant'trigno='11'><role id='role-11-Participant'trigno='11'>Nicolás Maduro</role></role> has <trigger id='trigger-11'>said</trigger> in a televised address."Gasoline must be <trigger id='trigger-8'>sold</trigger> at an international price to <trigger id='trigger-13'>stop</trigger> smuggling to Colombia and the Caribbean,"the <role id='role-12-Participant'trigno='12'><role id='role-12-Participant'trigno='12'>president</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>said</trigger>. Like most oil-producing countries, Venezuela has for decades subsidised fuel as a benefit to consumers. But its fuel prices have remained nearly flat for years despite hyperinflation that the International Monetary Fund has projected would reach 1 million per cent this year. That means that for the price of a cup of coffee, a driver can fill the tank of a small SUV nearly 9, 000 times. Recently, the average price of a coffee with milk was 2. 2m bolivars, or about 50 cents, local media has reported. <role id='role-9-Giver'trigno='9'>Smugglers</role> do brisk business <trigger id='trigger-9'>reselling</trigger> fuel in neighbouring countries. Quick guide Why is Venezuela in crisis? Show Hide Under the late Hugo Chávez, who ushered in Venezuela’s socialist revolution in 1999, a new constitution and numerous elections placed nearly all government institutions under the control of the ruling Socialist party. This concentration of power was aided by a feuding opposition which carried out ineffectual campaigns and electoral boycotts. After <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>Chávez</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>died</trigger> of cancer in 2013, he was succeeded by Nicolás Maduro who is even less tolerant of dissent. Growing political authoritarianism has coincided with greater state dominance over the economy. But expropriations, price controls and mismanagement have led to a 40% contraction of the economy in the past five years. Oil accounts for 96% of Venezuela’s export income but many foreign companies have been driven out and production has dropped to a 30-year low. The resulting fiscal crisis has prompted the government to print more money, which has led to hyperinflation and a collapse of the currency. It also means that the government can’t import enough food and medicine to meet demand. Maduro has rejected economic reforms out of loyalty to socialism and because many government <role id='role-10-Giver'trigno='10'>officials</role> are allegedly getting rich off the economic distortions–through exchange rate scams and by <trigger id='trigger-10'>selling</trigger> scarce <role id='role-10-AcquiredEntity'trigno='10'>food</role> on the black market. Was this helpful? Thank you for your feedback. <role id='role-14-Participant'trigno='14'><role id='role-14-Participant'trigno='14'>Maduro</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>said</trigger> the government would still provide direct subsidies to citizens holding the"fatherland card", a state-issued identification card that the government uses to provide bonuses and track use of social services. <role id='role-15-Participant'trigno='15'><role id='role-15-Participant'trigno='15'>He</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>said</trigger> the subsidy was only available to those who registered their cars in a vehicle census being conducted by the state. Venezuela has dirt-cheap fuel, so why is driving nearly impossible? Read more On Friday, the <role id='role-16-Participant'trigno='16'><role id='role-16-Participant'trigno='16'>UN</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-16'>said</trigger> that more than half a million <role id='role-1-Transporter'trigno='1'>Venezuelans</role> had <trigger id='trigger-1'>crossed</trigger> into <role id='role-1-Destination'trigno='1'>Ecuador</role> this year as part of one of the largest mass <trigger id='trigger-17'>migrations</trigger> in Latin American history. About 547, 000 <role id='role-2-Transporter'trigno='2'>citizens</role> have <trigger id='trigger-2'>entered</trigger> <role id='role-3-Destination'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Destination'trigno='2'>Ecuador</role></role> since January–mostly through its northern border with Colombia–to <trigger id='trigger-3'>escape</trigger> rampant crime and political violence, a collapsing economy and severe shortages of food and medicines. More than 1 million <role id='role-4-Transporter'trigno='4'>Venezuelans</role> have also <trigger id='trigger-4'>crossed</trigger> into <role id='role-4-Destination'trigno='4'>Colombia</role> since the exodus began in 2015. <role id='role-6-Transporter'trigno='6'>Others</role> have <trigger id='trigger-6'>fanned out</trigger> across Latin American and <role id='role-6-Destination'trigno='6'>Caribbean</role> nations including Mexico, the Dominican Republic and Trindad and Tobago. Tens of <role id='role-5-Transporter'trigno='5'>thousands</role> have <trigger id='trigger-5'>hiked</trigger> into <role id='role-5-Destination'trigno='5'>Brazil</role> down a remote Amazon road known as the Hunger Highway.

text: Blast also <trigger id='trigger-0'>injured</trigger> more than 20 people, but authorities have yet to suggest who was behind the <trigger id='trigger-1'>attack</trigger> At least nine <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>people</role> have been <trigger id='trigger-2'>killed</trigger> and another <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>24</role> <trigger id='trigger-3'>injured</trigger> in a car <trigger id='trigger-4'>bombing</trigger> at a Colombian police academy in <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>Bogotá</role>, recalling the high-profile <trigger id='trigger-5'>attacks</trigger> associated with the bloodiest chapters of the country’s guerrilla and drug conflicts. The scene outside the General Santander police academy was chaotic after the mid-morning <trigger id='trigger-6'>explosion</trigger>, with <role id='role-7-Vehicle'trigno='7'>ambulances</role> and helicopters <trigger id='trigger-7'>rushing</trigger> to the normally tightly controlled <role id='role-7-Destination'trigno='7'>facility</role>. Witnesses said they heard a loud <trigger id='trigger-8'>explosion</trigger> that <trigger id='trigger-9'>destroyed</trigger> <role id='role-9-Artifact'trigno='9'>windows</role> in adjacent <role id='role-9-Place'trigno='9'>buildings</role>. Pictures on social media showed a charred vehicle surrounded by debris on the academy’s campus. The defence ministry said at least nine <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'>people</role> were <trigger id='trigger-10'>killed</trigger> and <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>24</role> <trigger id='trigger-11'>injured</trigger>. Among the dead were a Panamanian and an Ecuadorian national. Alcaldía de Bogotá (@ Bogota) #Atención El alcalde @ EnriquePenalosa se encuentra en la Escuela General Santander acompañando a la @ PoliciaColombia. En breve entregaremos más información. #BogotáCondenaElTerrorismo pic. twitter. com / HBekT48yYi Rafael Trujillo said <role id='role-12-Transporter'trigno='12'>he</role> was <trigger id='trigger-12'>delivering</trigger> a care <role id='role-12-PassengerArtifact'trigno='12'>package</role> to his son Gerson, who entered the school two days ago, when he was stopped in his tracks by the <trigger id='trigger-13'>blast</trigger> a block away from the school’s heavily fortified entrance. “I’m sad and very worried because I don’t have any information about my son,” said Trujillo, standing outside the facility, where police officers had set up a taped perimeter. “This reminds me of some very sad days in the past.” President <role id='role-14-PassengerArtifact'trigno='14'>Iván Duque</role>, who was visiting a western state, was <trigger id='trigger-14'>rushing</trigger> back to the <role id='role-14-Destination'trigno='14'>capital</role> to oversee the <role id='role-15-Investigator'trigno='15'>police</role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>investigation</trigger> into what he called a “miserable” <trigger id='trigger-16'>attack</trigger>. “All of us Colombians reject terrorism and are united in confronting it,” Duque said in a tweet. “We won’t bend in the face of violence.” For decades, residents of Bogotá lived in fear of being caught in a <trigger id='trigger-17'>bombing</trigger> by leftist rebels or Pablo Escobar’s Medellín drug <role id='role-17-Attacker'trigno='17'>cartel</role>. But as Colombia’s conflict has wound down, and the nation’s largest rebel group disarmed under a 2016 peace deal, security has improved and <trigger id='trigger-18'>attacks</trigger> have become less frequent. Facebook Twitter Pinterest Smouldering remains of car bomb are seen in this screengrab outside Bogotá police academy. Authorities have yet to suggest <role id='role-19-Attacker'trigno='19'>who</role> was behind the <trigger id='trigger-19'>attack</trigger>, but attention has focused on leftist rebels from the National Liberation Army, ELN, <role id='role-20-Attacker'trigno='20'>which</role> has been stepping up <trigger id='trigger-20'>attacks</trigger> on police targets in Colombia amid a standoff with the conservative Duque over how to restart stalled peace talks. Colombian <role id='role-21-Killer'trigno='21'>rebels</role> blamed for <trigger id='trigger-21'>killing</trigger> spree 400 miles inside Venezuela Read more The group known was long considered a lesser military threat than the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc), whose 7, 000 guerrilla fighters disarmed as part of a 2016 peace accord. But in the wake of the peace deal, the Cuban-inspired insurgency has been gaining strength, especially along the eastern border with Venezuela, where <role id='role-23-Attacker'trigno='23'><role id='role-22-Perpetrator'trigno='22'>it</role></role> has carried out a number of <trigger id='trigger-22'>kidnappings</trigger> and <trigger id='trigger-23'>bombings</trigger> of oil <role id='role-23-Target'trigno='23'>pipelines</role>. That has hardened Duque’s resolve in refusing to resume peace talks that have been stalled since he took office last August. Thursday’s <trigger id='trigger-24'>bombing</trigger> was the deadliest in the <role id='role-24-Place'trigno='24'>capital</role> since an <trigger id='trigger-27'>explosion</trigger> at the upmarket Andino shopping <role id='role-27-Place'trigno='27'>mall</role> in June 2017 <trigger id='trigger-28'>killed</trigger> three <role id='role-28-Victim'trigno='28'>people</role>, including a French woman, and <trigger id='trigger-29'>injured</trigger> another <role id='role-29-Victim'trigno='29'>11</role>. Police later <trigger id='trigger-25'>arrested</trigger> several suspected <role id='role-25-Detainee'trigno='25'>members</role> of a far-left urban guerrilla group called the People Revolutionary’s Movement for the <trigger id='trigger-26'>bombing</trigger>. But it has been more than a decade since a police or military installation in the <role id='role-30-Place'trigno='30'>capital</role> has suffered a major <trigger id='trigger-30'>bombing</trigger>. A <trigger id='trigger-32'>blast</trigger> at military <role id='role-32-Place'trigno='32'>university</role> in 2006 left almost two dozen <role id='role-31-Victim'trigno='31'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-31'>injured</trigger>. Ariel Ávila, an analyst who tracks violence, said that in the last four years, there have been 28 <trigger id='trigger-33'>attacks</trigger> in the <role id='role-33-Place'trigno='33'>capital</role> with <role id='role-33-Instrument'trigno='33'>explosives</role>. While the majority has been carried out with low-grade homemade materials and <role id='role-34-Instrument'trigno='34'>grenades</role> that have <trigger id='trigger-34'>damaged</trigger> property but left no casualties, he said police intelligence and checkpoints surrounding the city need to be reinforced to prevent more <trigger id='trigger-35'>attacks</trigger>.

FBI Looking for 2 Men Who Allegedly Found Explosive Device in NYC The U. S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is asking the public for help in locating two men who allegedly found a piece of luggage on a New York sidewalk that contained an explosive device that may be tied to the suspect in Saturday's <trigger id='trigger-0'>bombings</trigger> in New York and <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>New Jersey</role>. On Wednesday the FBI issued a statement and a photo of two men that was taken on Saturday, September 17, in the same hour an explosive <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>device</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>detonated</trigger>. The FBI said the men took the luggage, which was located only four blocks or so from the New York <trigger id='trigger-2'>bombing</trigger> <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>site</role>, and left the device behind. That <role id='role-3-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='3'>device</role> did not <trigger id='trigger-3'>detonate</trigger>. Federal investigators said during a news conference Wednesday the men are wanted as witnesses only. Federal investigators said earlier the <role id='role-4-Defendant'trigno='4'>suspect</role> in Saturday's <trigger id='trigger-5'>bombings</trigger> in New York and <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>New Jersey</role> has been <trigger id='trigger-4'>charged</trigger> with use of a <role id='role-7-Instrument'trigno='7'><role id='role-6-Instrument'trigno='6'>weapon</role></role> of mass <trigger id='trigger-6'>destruction</trigger> in the weekend <trigger id='trigger-7'>attacks</trigger>. Investigators said <role id='role-11-Recipient'trigno='11'>he</role> <trigger id='trigger-11'>bought</trigger> <role id='role-11-AcquiredEntity'trigno='11'>components</role> on <role id='role-11-Giver'trigno='11'>eBay</role> and used as triggering devices <role id='role-10-AcquiredEntity'trigno='10'>cell phones</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>purchased</trigger> from a <role id='role-10-Giver'trigno='10'>store</role> 500 meters from an address he once listed as his home. Evidence <role id='role-12-Investigator'trigno='12'>teams</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>investigate</trigger> at the scene of Saturday's <trigger id='trigger-13'>explosion</trigger> on <role id='role-13-Target'trigno='13'>West 23rd Street</role> in Manhattan's Chelsea <role id='role-13-Place'trigno='13'>neighborhood</role> in New York, Sept. 19, 2016. Ahmad Khan Rahami, a U. S. <role id='role-8-Defendant'trigno='8'>citizen</role> of Afghan descent has been <trigger id='trigger-8'>charged</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-9'>bombing</trigger>. Multiple federal <trigger id='trigger-14'>charges</trigger> The details are contained in criminal complaints made public Tuesday spelling out multiple federal <trigger id='trigger-15'>charges</trigger> against 28-year-old <role id='role-15-Defendant'trigno='15'>Ahmad Khan Rahami</role>. Most of the <trigger id='trigger-16'>charges</trigger> carry a maximum <trigger id='trigger-17'>sentence</trigger> of life in prison. Authorities <trigger id='trigger-18'>arrested</trigger> <role id='role-19-Attacker'trigno='19'><role id='role-18-Detainee'trigno='18'>Rahami</role></role> on Monday after an exchange of <trigger id='trigger-19'>gunfire</trigger> with <role id='role-19-Target'trigno='19'>police</role> that left <role id='role-20-Victim'trigno='20'>him</role> and two officers <trigger id='trigger-20'>wounded</trigger>. According to the court documents, investigators believe Rahami used an eBay account with the username"ahmad rahimi"to buy citric acid, a circuit board, electric igniters and hundreds of ball bearings between June 20 and August 10. The <role id='role-21-PassengerArtifact'trigno='21'>items</role> were <trigger id='trigger-21'>shipped</trigger> to a business in <role id='role-21-Destination'trigno='21'>Perth Amboy</role>, New Jersey, where Rahami worked until September 12. Ball bearings were found in two pressure cooker bombs placed four blocks apart in the Chelsea neighborhood of New York late Saturday. <role id='role-23-Instrument'trigno='23'>One</role> of them <trigger id='trigger-22'>exploded</trigger>, <trigger id='trigger-23'>injuring</trigger> 29 <role id='role-23-Victim'trigno='23'>people</role>, while the other was recovered intact. Investigators said the second bomb had"numerous"electric igniters. That second device was tested for fingerprints, and the criminal complaint said all 12 prints found were matches for Rahami. The documents say his prints were also found on items inside of a backpack that was discovered late Sunday at a train station in Elizabeth, New Jersey, just outside of New York. The bag contained multiple explosive devices, including one <role id='role-24-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='24'>that</role> <trigger id='trigger-24'>blew up</trigger> as police tried to disarm it with a robot. Authorities also tied Rahami to a bomb <role id='role-25-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='25'>that</role> <trigger id='trigger-25'>blew up</trigger> in a trash can in <role id='role-25-Place'trigno='25'>Seaside Park</role>, New Jersey, early Saturday. That link involved one of the cell <role id='role-26-PassengerArtifact'trigno='26'>phones</role> that investigators said were <trigger id='trigger-26'>shipped</trigger> last year to a <role id='role-26-Destination'trigno='26'>store</role> in Perth Amboy near the address that Rahami provided as his home in a 2012 passport application. They said a second <role id='role-27-PassengerArtifact'trigno='27'>phone</role> <trigger id='trigger-27'>shipped</trigger> to the same <role id='role-27-Destination'trigno='27'>place</role> was used in the <role id='role-28-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='28'>bomb</role> that <trigger id='trigger-28'>blew up</trigger> in <role id='role-28-Place'trigno='28'>Chelsea</role>. A third phone, one found with the other Chelsea bomb, was once registered to one of Rahami's family members, the documents said. A still image captured from a video from WABC television shows <role id='role-29-Place'trigno='29'>New York</role> <trigger id='trigger-29'>bombing</trigger> suspect <role id='role-30-Attacker'trigno='30'>Ahmad Khan Rahami</role> being loaded into an ambulance after a <trigger id='trigger-30'>shoot-out</trigger> with <role id='role-30-Target'trigno='30'>police</role> in <role id='role-30-Place'trigno='30'>Linden</role>, New Jersey, Sept. 19, 2016. Surveillance video Investigators also said they used surveillance video to tie Rahami to the Chelsea bombs, with cameras putting him near the <trigger id='trigger-31'>explosion</trigger> <role id='role-32-Place'trigno='32'><role id='role-31-Place'trigno='31'>site</role></role> about 37 minutes before the <trigger id='trigger-32'>blast</trigger> and near where the other bomb was found two minutes after the first <role id='role-33-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='33'>one</role> <trigger id='trigger-33'>went off</trigger>. That second video, they said, showed him pulling a suitcase and then a short time later walking without it. The documents contain some pieces of writing from a journal found on Rahami when <role id='role-34-Detainee'trigno='34'>he</role> was <trigger id='trigger-34'>arrested</trigger>. The messages include praise of American-born cleric Anwar al-Awlaki, <role id='role-35-Victim'trigno='35'>who</role> was <trigger id='trigger-35'>killed</trigger> by a U. S. <role id='role-36-Instrument'trigno='36'>drone</role> <trigger id='trigger-36'>strike</trigger> in <role id='role-36-Place'trigno='36'><role id='role-35-Place'trigno='35'>Yemen</role></role> in 2011, and"Brother Osama Bin Laden,"the former head of al-Qaida <role id='role-37-Victim'trigno='37'>who</role> was <trigger id='trigger-37'>killed</trigger> by U. S. <role id='role-37-Killer'trigno='37'>forces</role> in <role id='role-37-Place'trigno='37'>Pakistan</role> in 2011."Inshallah the sounds of the bombs will be heard in the streets. Gun <trigger id='trigger-38'>shots</trigger> to your police. Death To Your OPPRESSION,"one message reads. The FBI said Tuesday it assessed Rahami's activities in 2014 after his father told agents he was concerned about his son's possible involvement with extremists. The <role id='role-39-Investigator'trigno='39'>agency</role> found insufficient evidence to warrant further <trigger id='trigger-39'>investigation</trigger>. Rahami was born in Afghanistan, came to the U. S. at age 7 and became a naturalized American citizen.

text: Iraq: Improvised <role id='role-0-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='0'>explosive device</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>targets</trigger> British <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>vehicles</role> in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Baghdad</role> An improvised <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>explosive device</role> has <trigger id='trigger-1'>targeted</trigger> British diplomatic <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>vehicles</role> in Iraq’s capital <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>Baghdad</role>. The British <role id='role-5-Participant'trigno='5'><role id='role-5-Participant'trigno='5'>embassy</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>said</trigger> the <trigger id='trigger-2'>blast</trigger> targeted an embassy <role id='role-2-Target'trigno='2'>convoy</role> on the airport road, close to the <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>Umm al Tabool Mosque</role> on Tuesday morning. There were no <trigger id='trigger-3'>injuries</trigger> but an armoured <role id='role-4-Artifact'trigno='4'>vehicle</role> was badly <trigger id='trigger-4'>damaged</trigger>.

text: A <role id='role-1-Attacker'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>man</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>accused</trigger> of trying to <trigger id='trigger-1'>ignite</trigger> <role id='role-1-Instrument'trigno='1'>explosives</role> aboard an American Airlines jet could be <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>one</role> of many <trigger id='trigger-2'>suicide</trigger> recruits from <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>London</role>, according to the chairman of a Brixton mosque where the suspect worshipped. Abdul Haqq Baker, speaking outside the mosque in south London, told reporters Wednesday he believes the suspect, identified on his passport as Richard Reid, could not have acted alone and that more will try to succeed where he failed."I think now they've seen that this particular plan was foiled, the others I fear, are going to be more successful and more extreme in what they do,"Baker said."I really personally believe he was a tester,"he said."They wanted to see how far he would get and then act thereafter."Baker said Reid, 28, was known by the name Abdel Rahim when he joined the mosque in 1998, at about the same time as Zacarias Moussaoui, <role id='role-3-Prosecutor'trigno='3'>who</role> has been <trigger id='trigger-3'>indicted</trigger> in the <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>U. S. </role> on conspiracy charges related to the Sept. 11 hijackings. <role id='role-4-Prosecutor'trigno='4'>Moussaoui</role> is a French citizen <trigger id='trigger-4'>accused</trigger> of being trained as the"20th hijacker"for the attacks on the Pentagon and New York's World Trade Center. Baker says <role id='role-5-Detainee'trigno='5'>Reid</role>, believed to be of Anglo-Jamaican heritage, had converted to Islam while serving time in <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'><trigger id='trigger-5'>jail</trigger></role> for minor offences and attended the mosque for two years. <role id='role-6-Prosecutor'trigno='6'>Reid</role> is <trigger id='trigger-6'>accused</trigger> of trying to detonate C-4 plastic explosives hidden in his shoes on a flight from Paris to Miami last Saturday. A flight attendant said she noticed the smell of smoke, then saw a <role id='role-7-Attacker'trigno='7'>man</role> trying to <trigger id='trigger-7'>light</trigger> one of his shoes with a match. The plane, with nearly 200 people on board, was diverted to Boston's Logan International Airport, escorted by two F-15 fighter jets. <role id='role-8-Detainee'trigno='8'>Reid</role> is being <trigger id='trigger-8'>held</trigger> at the Plymouth correctional facility in <role id='role-8-Place'trigno='8'>Massachusetts</role>.

text: On 7 October 2019, a suicide <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>bomber</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>detonated</trigger> an improvised <role id='role-0-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='0'>explosive device</role> in a rickshaw in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Jalalabad</role> as a minibus carrying Afghan Army recruits passed it. At least fourteen <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>people</role> were <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger> and 37 <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>others</role> were <trigger id='trigger-2'>injured</trigger>. == References ==

text: Investigators: NY Bombing Suspect Bought Parts on eBay Federal investigators say the <role id='role-0-Recipient'trigno='0'>suspect</role> in Saturday's bombings in New York and New Jersey <trigger id='trigger-0'>bought</trigger> <role id='role-0-AcquiredEntity'trigno='0'>components</role> on eBay and used as triggering devices <role id='role-1-AcquiredEntity'trigno='1'>cell phones</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>purchased</trigger> from a <role id='role-1-Giver'trigno='1'>store</role> 500 meters from an address he once listed as his home. The details are contained in <trigger id='trigger-2'>criminal</trigger> complaints made public Tuesday spelling out multiple federal <trigger id='trigger-3'>charges</trigger> against 28-year-old Ahmad Khan Rahami. Most of the <trigger id='trigger-5'>charges</trigger> carry a maximum <trigger id='trigger-4'>sentence</trigger> of life in prison. <role id='role-6-Jailer'trigno='6'>Authorities</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>arrested</trigger> <role id='role-6-Detainee'trigno='6'>Rahami</role> on Monday after an exchange of gunfire with police that left <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>him</role> and two officers <trigger id='trigger-7'>wounded</trigger>. According to the court documents, investigators believe <role id='role-8-Recipient'trigno='8'>Rahami</role> used an eBay account with the username"ahmad rahami"to <trigger id='trigger-8'>buy</trigger> citric acid, a <role id='role-8-AcquiredEntity'trigno='8'>circuit board</role>, electric igniters and hundreds of ball bearings between June 20 and August 10. The <role id='role-9-PassengerArtifact'trigno='9'>items</role> were <trigger id='trigger-9'>shipped</trigger> to a business in Perth Amboy, <role id='role-9-Destination'trigno='9'>New Jersey</role> where Rahami worked until September 12. Ball bearings were found in two pressure cooker bombs placed four blocks apart in the Chelsea neighborhood of New York late Saturday. One of <role id='role-10-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='10'>them</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>exploded</trigger>, <trigger id='trigger-11'>injuring</trigger> 29 <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'><role id='role-10-Target'trigno='10'>people</role></role>, while the <role id='role-12-Artifact'trigno='12'>other</role> was <trigger id='trigger-12'>recovered</trigger> intact. Investigators said the second bomb had"numerous"electric igniters. <role id='role-13-Detainee'trigno='13'>Ahmad Khan Rahami</role> is taken into <trigger id='trigger-13'>custody</trigger> after a shootout with <role id='role-13-Jailer'trigno='13'>police</role> Monday, Sept. 19, 2016. That second device was tested for fingerprints, and the criminal complaint said all 12 prints found were matches for Rahami. The documents say his prints were also found on items inside of a backpack that was discovered late Sunday at a train station in Elizabeth, New Jersey, just outside of New York. The bag contained multiple explosive devices, including <role id='role-14-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='14'>one</role> that <trigger id='trigger-14'>blew up</trigger> as police tried to <trigger id='trigger-21'>disarm</trigger> <role id='role-21-Artifact'trigno='21'>it</role> with a robot. Authorities also tied Rahami to a <role id='role-15-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='15'>bomb</role> that <trigger id='trigger-15'>blew up</trigger> in a trash can in <role id='role-15-Place'trigno='15'>Seaside Park</role>, New Jersey early Saturday. That link involved one of the cell phones that investigators said were shipped last year to a store in Perth Amboy near the address that Rahami provided as his home in a 2012 passport application. They said a second phone shipped to the same place was used in the <role id='role-16-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='16'>bomb</role> that <trigger id='trigger-16'>blew up</trigger> in <role id='role-16-Place'trigno='16'>Chelsea</role>. A third phone, one found with the other Chelsea bomb, was once registered to one of Rahami's family members, the documents said. Investigators also said they used surveillance video to tie Rahami to the Chelsea bombs, with cameras putting him near the explosion site about 37 minutes before the blast and near where the other bomb was found two minutes after the first <role id='role-17-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='17'>one</role> <trigger id='trigger-17'>went off</trigger>. That second video, they said, showed him pulling a suitcase and then a short time later walking without it. The documents contain some pieces of writing from a journal found on <role id='role-18-Detainee'trigno='18'>Rahami</role> when he was <trigger id='trigger-18'>arrested</trigger>. The messages include praise of American-born cleric <role id='role-19-Victim'trigno='19'>Anwar al-Awlaki</role>, who <trigger id='trigger-19'>killed</trigger> by a U. S. drone strike in Yemen in 2011, and"Brother Osama Bin Laden,"the former head of al-Qaida who was killed by U. S. forces in Pakistan in 2011."Inshallah the sounds of the bombs will be heard in the streets. Gun shots to your police. Death To Your OPPRESSION,"one message reads. The FBI said Tuesday it assessed Rahami's activities in 2014 after his father told agents he was concerned about his son's possible involvement with extremists. The <role id='role-20-Investigator'trigno='20'>agency</role> found insufficient evidence to warrant further <trigger id='trigger-20'>investigation</trigger>. Rahami was born in Afghanistan, came to the U. S. at age 7 and became a naturalized American citizen.

text: Accused Boston Bomber Says Satisfied With Defense Lawyers BOSTON — The Boston Marathon bombing suspect, in his first court appearance in more than a year, told a judge on Thursday that he was satisfied with his lawyers'preparations for the January start of <role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>his</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>trial</trigger> over the deadly 2013 attack. <role id='role-1-Defendant'trigno='1'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role>, 21, was dressed in a dark sweater and wore his hair shaggy for his appearance at U. S. District Court, where he will be <trigger id='trigger-1'>tried</trigger> on charges of <trigger id='trigger-2'>killing</trigger> three <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>people</role> and <trigger id='trigger-3'>injuring</trigger> more than <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>260</role> with two homemade <role id='role-3-Instrument'trigno='3'>bombs</role> at the race's crowded finish line on April 15, 2013, as well as <trigger id='trigger-4'>fatally</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-5'>shooting</trigger> a university police <role id='role-5-Target'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>officer</role></role> three days later. The defendant, who had grown a light beard, appeared in a courtroom packed with victims, supporters and curious onlookers. Tsarnaev looked alert and healthy, showing no signs of the injuries suffered during a gunbattle with police on the night of April 18, 2013, that ended with the <trigger id='trigger-6'>death</trigger> of his brother, <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>Tamerlan</role>, also accused with playing a role in the attack. In his prior court appearance, in July 2013, Tsarnaev's left arm was in a cast and his face appeared swollen. U. S. District Judge George O'Toole asked Tsarnaev if he was satisfied with his defense attorneys in a series of questions intended to avoid any post-trial assertions that he was not provided a proper defense."Yes, your honor,"Tsarnaev replied briefly to questions about whether his attorneys were keeping him abreast of court developments. <role id='role-7-Defendant'trigno='7'>He</role> looked somewhat fidgety during the 25-minute <trigger id='trigger-7'>hearing</trigger>. O'Toole also said that many of the court documents filed under seal ahead of the trial will be made public after the jury is seated in January.'Stay strong'Tsarnaev faces the possibility of execution if convicted in a trial that is expected to run for three months. The court plans to weed through more than 1, 000 people to find 12 jurors and six alternates to hear the case. At the hearing's conclusion, Elena Teyer, 45, whose son-in-law <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'><role id='role-8-Target'trigno='8'>Ibragim Todashev</role></role> was <trigger id='trigger-9'>fatally</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-8'>shot</trigger> by FBI <role id='role-9-Killer'trigno='9'><role id='role-8-Attacker'trigno='8'>agents</role></role> in <role id='role-9-Place'trigno='9'><role id='role-8-Place'trigno='8'>Florida</role></role> during an interview about his friendship with Tamerlan Tsarnaev in the weeks after the bombing, shouted support to Tsarnaev in Russian. Outside court, she translated her words for reporters as"Dzhokhar, we know you're innocent. . . stay strong, son."A resident of Savannah, Georgia, Teyer said she had traveled to Boston specifically for the hearing."You know how hard it is when you have no one near you who is going to support you,"Teyer said. Thursday's <trigger id='trigger-10'>hearing</trigger> is the final pre-trial conference in <role id='role-10-Defendant'trigno='10'>Tsarnaev</role>'s case. In the weeks leading up to the trial, prosecutors and defense attorneys are disputing a range of issues including how much they must disclose about the witnesses they plan to call. The <role id='role-11-PassengerArtifact'trigno='11'>Tsarnaev</role> brothers had <trigger id='trigger-11'>moved</trigger> to the <role id='role-11-Destination'trigno='11'>United States</role> from Russia's restive <role id='role-11-Origin'trigno='11'>Chechnya</role> region a decade before the attack. <role id='role-13-Attacker'trigno='13'><role id='role-12-Attacker'trigno='12'>Dzhokhar</role></role> left a scrawled note inside the dry-docked boat where he was captured in Watertown, Massachusetts, a day after the <trigger id='trigger-13'>shootout</trigger>, indicating that the marathon <trigger id='trigger-12'>attack</trigger> had been motivated by U. S. military campaigns in Muslim countries. Tsarnaev's attorneys had asked that the trial be held outside Boston, contending that since hundreds of thousands of spectators attend the Boston Marathon, it would be all but impossible to find an impartial panel of people who had not been present the day of the attack or known someone who had been. O'Toole had previously denied that request, noting the <role id='role-14-JudgeCourt'trigno='14'>court</role> had recently seated juries in other high-profile cases, including the 2013 <trigger id='trigger-14'>trial</trigger> of former mob boss <role id='role-15-Defendant'trigno='15'><role id='role-14-Defendant'trigno='14'>James"Whitey"Bulger</role></role>, who was <trigger id='trigger-15'>found guilty</trigger> of racketeering and murder. On his way into court, one of the <trigger id='trigger-16'>bombing</trigger>'s victims, <role id='role-16-Target'trigno='16'>Marc Fucarile</role>, confronted a small group of protesters who asserted the evidence of the bombing was fabricated. Fucarile grabbed the prosthetic limb that replaced the right leg he lost in the bombing, saying he considered that proof enough. Asked about the incident, Fucarile said,"They have a right to their opinion, same as anybody else."

text: How Many US <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>Troops</role> Were <trigger id='trigger-0'>Killed</trigger> By Iranian IEDs in Iraq? Far fewer than Congress thinks, according to newly declassified documents from U. S. Central Command. Explosively formed penetrators — a particularly deadly form of roadside bomb — <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger> 196 American <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>soldiers</role> in <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>Iraq</role> over a five-and-a-half-year period, according to recently declassified Pentagon documents. That’s about half as many <trigger id='trigger-2'>deaths</trigger> as lawmakers have attributed to the bombs, which U. S. officials say were largely supplied by Iran’s elite Quds Force. The <trigger id='trigger-3'>carnage</trigger> wrought by <role id='role-3-Killer'trigno='3'>EFPs</role> returned to the news over the summer, as opponents of the nuclear deal with Iran cited Tehran’s behind-the-scenes actions against U. S. troops during Operation Iraqi Freedom as a reason to scuttle the agreement. Sen. Ted Cruz, a Texas Republican who is also running for president, and others in Congress have <trigger id='trigger-33'>said</trigger> that <role id='role-33-Participant'trigno='33'><role id='role-33-Participant'trigno='33'><role id='role-4-Killer'trigno='4'>EFPs</role></role></role> had <trigger id='trigger-4'>killed</trigger> more than 500 <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>troops</role>. “I understand that the Joint Personnel Recovery Agency has a classified list of roughly 500 American <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>soldiers</role> who were <trigger id='trigger-5'>murdered</trigger> by Iranian IEDs,” <role id='role-34-Participant'trigno='34'><role id='role-34-Participant'trigno='34'>Cruz</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-34'>said</trigger> at a July 29 <role id='role-6-JudgeCourt'trigno='6'>Senate Armed Services Committee</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>hearing</trigger>. But data from U. S. Central Command, which runs U. S. military operations in the Middle East, suggests the actual <trigger id='trigger-9'>toll</trigger> is far less. According to the first comprehensive accounting, between November 2005 and December 2011, 1, 526 <role id='role-8-Injurer'trigno='8'><role id='role-7-Killer'trigno='7'>EFPs</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>killed</trigger> a total of 196 U. S. <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>troops</role> and <trigger id='trigger-8'>injured</trigger> <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>861</role>. Between October 2006 and September 2007, <role id='role-11-Injurer'trigno='11'><role id='role-10-Killer'trigno='10'>EFPs</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>killed</trigger> 97 U. S. <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'>troops</role> and <trigger id='trigger-11'>wounded</trigger> more than 300 <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>soldiers</role>. <role id='role-13-Attacker'trigno='13'><role id='role-12-Attacker'trigno='12'>EFP</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>attacks</trigger> peaked in March, April and May 2008, near the end of the American troop surge, when 200 of the <role id='role-13-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='13'>bombs</role> were <trigger id='trigger-13'>detonated</trigger>. The deadliest month was April 2008, when <role id='role-14-Killer'trigno='14'>EFPs</role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>killed</trigger> 15 U. S. <role id='role-14-Victim'trigno='14'>soldiers</role>. The Pentagon attributes the presence of EFPs in Iraq to the Quds Force, the special forces arm of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard led by Qasem Soleimani. Various EFP “factories” were found throughout Iraq during Operation Iraqi Freedom. Still, the exact degree to which Iran bears culpability for arming Shia militias in Iraq with EFPs and related equipment is a matter of some dispute. “We weren’t always able to attribute the <trigger id='trigger-15'>casualties</trigger> that we had to Iranian activity, although many times we suspected it was Iranian activity, even though we didn't necessarily have the forensics to support that,” Gen. Joseph Dunford, the incoming chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, <trigger id='trigger-35'>said</trigger> at <role id='role-36-Defendant'trigno='36'><role id='role-35-Participant'trigno='35'><role id='role-35-Participant'trigno='35'>his</role></role></role> July 9 confirmation <trigger id='trigger-36'>hearing</trigger>. During the <trigger id='trigger-37'>hearing</trigger>, <role id='role-37-Defendant'trigno='37'>Dunford</role> said the numbers of American <role id='role-16-Victim'trigno='16'>soldiers</role> <trigger id='trigger-16'>killed</trigger> by <role id='role-16-Killer'trigno='16'>Iran</role> “has been recently quoted as about 500.” <role id='role-38-Identifier'trigno='38'>CENTCOM</role> later <trigger id='trigger-38'>clarified</trigger> that <role id='role-38-IdentifiedRole'trigno='38'>Dunford</role> was referring to total American <trigger id='trigger-17'>deaths</trigger> by EFPs and other Iranian weapons. It is “important to understand that the CENTCOM statistics on <role id='role-18-Attacker'trigno='18'>EFP</role> <trigger id='trigger-18'>detonations</trigger> are a subset of all the Iranian activities estimated to have <trigger id='trigger-19'>killed</trigger> approximately 500 U. S. <role id='role-19-Victim'trigno='19'>troops</role> in <role id='role-19-Killer'trigno='19'>Iraq</role> during OIF,” Maj. Genieve David, a CENTCOM <role id='role-39-Participant'trigno='39'><role id='role-39-Participant'trigno='39'>spokeswoman</role></role>, <trigger id='trigger-39'>said</trigger> in an email. Data about the roughly 300 <trigger id='trigger-20'>deaths</trigger> not caused by EFPs, including the kind of <role id='role-41-IdentifiedObject'trigno='41'><role id='role-21-Instrument'trigno='21'>weapons</role></role> used in the <trigger id='trigger-21'>attacks</trigger>, is <trigger id='trigger-41'>classified</trigger>, <role id='role-40-Participant'trigno='40'><role id='role-40-Participant'trigno='40'>David</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-40'>said</trigger>. A few weeks later, at the July 29 hearing, Gen. Martin Dempsey, the outgoing Joint Chiefs <role id='role-42-Participant'trigno='42'><role id='role-42-Participant'trigno='42'>chairman</role></role>, <trigger id='trigger-42'>said</trigger> “several hundred” American <role id='role-22-Victim'trigno='22'>forces</role> were <trigger id='trigger-22'>killed</trigger> by <role id='role-22-Killer'trigno='22'>EFPs</role>. Phil Novack, a spokesman for Cruz, <trigger id='trigger-43'>told</trigger> <role id='role-43-Participant'trigno='43'><role id='role-43-Participant'trigno='43'>Defense One</role></role> that the Senator's office is working with the Pentagon to get specific numbers. He <trigger id='trigger-44'>said</trigger> <role id='role-44-Participant'trigno='44'><role id='role-44-Participant'trigno='44'>Cruz</role></role> used the 500 number based on Dunford's testimony. Cruz “asked Secretary Carter to <trigger id='trigger-45'>inform</trigger> the <role id='role-45-Participant'trigno='45'><role id='role-45-Participant'trigno='45'>families</role></role> of the 500 service <role id='role-23-Victim'trigno='23'>members</role> who were <trigger id='trigger-23'>killed</trigger> by Iranian <role id='role-23-Killer'trigno='23'>EFPs</role> that their loved <role id='role-24-Victim'trigno='24'>ones</role> were <trigger id='trigger-24'>murdered</trigger> by the same <role id='role-24-Killer'trigno='24'>man</role> <role id='role-25-Defendant'trigno='25'>who</role> will now receive sanctions <trigger id='trigger-25'>relief</trigger>,” <role id='role-46-Participant'trigno='46'><role id='role-46-Participant'trigno='46'>Novack</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-46'>said</trigger> in an email. “Whether the number is 500 lives or 196 is immaterial; the fact remains that General Soleimani — a <role id='role-26-Killer'trigno='26'>man</role> responsible for the <trigger id='trigger-26'>deaths</trigger> of hundreds of American service <role id='role-26-Victim'trigno='26'>members</role> — will receive sanctions <trigger id='trigger-27'>relief</trigger> to the tune of millions of dollars if this deal is approved."The arrival of EFPs on the Iraqi battlefield around 2005 came as a shock to U. S. planners. Along with more run-of-the-mill improvised explosive devices, the deadly bombs drove a crash effort to create and <trigger id='trigger-28'>deploy</trigger> <role id='role-28-Artifact'trigno='28'>vehicles</role> with far better <role id='role-28-Components'trigno='28'>armor</role>. Whereas most roadside bombs send energy and shrapnel in all directions, EFPs work more like cannons. The force of the <trigger id='trigger-29'>blast</trigger> molds a concave metal disc, called a liner, into a “formed penetrator” which is propelled at up to 3, 000 meters per second. The effect is incredibly destructive, even to up-armored Humvees. “You can do as much or more <trigger id='trigger-30'>damage</trigger> with a 5-pound <role id='role-30-Instrument'trigno='30'>EFP</role>, which is aimed, as with a 200-pound conventional IED,” a Pentagon analyst <trigger id='trigger-47'>told</trigger> <role id='role-47-Participant'trigno='47'><role id='role-47-Participant'trigno='47'>Los Angeles Times</role></role> writer Andrew Cockburn in 2007. The analyst speculated that the cost to <trigger id='trigger-31'>construct</trigger> such a <role id='role-31-Artifact'trigno='31'>device</role> was about $30 or less. They’ve been around since at least World War II, when resistance elements in Europe used them against Germans, Cockburn wrote. Among the other Iranian arms introduced to the Iraqi battlefield is the improvised rocket assisted munition, described in one Joint IED Defeat Organization document as “a rocket-fired improvised explosive <role id='role-32-Artifact'trigno='32'>device</role> <trigger id='trigger-32'>made</trigger> from a large metal <role id='role-32-Components'trigno='32'>canister</role> — such as a propane gas tank — filled with explosives, scrap metal and ball bearings and propelled by rockets.” First seen in Iraq in 2007, the IRAM — “essentially an airborne version of a roadside bomb — a flying IED” is” the signature weapon used by Iranian-backed militias that operate with the aid of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Group,” the undated document says.

text: Pressure Cookers, Nails, BBs, and Bags: What We Know About the Boston Bombs More Stories The 140-Year-Old Dream of ‘ Government Without Taxation’The Media Barely Covered One of the Worst Storms to Hit U. S. Soil France’s Jews Look to Pittsburgh ‘ Across a Narrow Bridge’There were only two bombs In the hours following the <trigger id='trigger-0'>explosions</trigger>, an array of outlets — including the Associated Press, The Wall Street Journal, and The New York Times — quoted anonymous law enforcement officials who said that <role id='role-1-Observer'trigno='1'>police</role> had <trigger id='trigger-1'>discovered</trigger> three and even five additional, unexploded <role id='role-1-ObservedEntity'trigno='1'>devices</role> around the <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>Boston</role> area. The reports emerged around the same time that, as first reported by The Boston Globe, a bomb <role id='role-3-Destroyer'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Attacker'trigno='2'>squad</role></role> arranged and <trigger id='trigger-2'>detonated</trigger> a"controlled explosion"on <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>Boylston Street</role></role>, just east of the first two explosions, in order to <trigger id='trigger-3'>destroy</trigger> a <role id='role-3-Artifact'trigno='3'>cache</role> of"suspicious packages"that officials had come across. A similar scene played out in the <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>Boston</role></role> suburb of Newton, where a bomb <role id='role-5-Identifier'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-Observer'trigno='4'>squad</role></role> used <role id='role-4-Instrument'trigno='4'>a robot</role> to <trigger id='trigger-5'><trigger id='trigger-4'>investigate</trigger></trigger> a suspicious <role id='role-5-IdentifiedObject'trigno='5'>object</role> that turned to be <role id='role-5-IdentifiedRole'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-ObservedEntity'trigno='4'>a circuit board</role></role>. Monday night, the Journal quoted law enforcement officials as <trigger id='trigger-7'>saying</trigger> there had been five <role id='role-7-Topic'trigno='7'>devices</role>, then updated its report to clarify that"investigators now doubt the devices were bombs."But during Tuesday morning's <role id='role-6-Place'trigno='6'>press conference</role>, Massachusetts Governor <role id='role-6-Communicator'trigno='6'>Deval Patrick</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>announced</trigger> that law enforcement agents had not in fact discovered <role id='role-6-Topic'trigno='6'>any other bombs</role>."It's important to clarify that two and only two explosive devices were found yesterday. Other parcels have been <trigger id='trigger-8'>examined</trigger>. . . but there were no unexploded bombs,"he told reporters. The bombs may have been based in pressure cookers A <role id='role-10-Communicator'trigno='10'>representative</role> of <role id='role-9-Treater'trigno='9'>Boston Children's Hospital</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>said</trigger> at Tuesday afternoon press briefing that <role id='role-10-Topic'trigno='10'><role id='role-9-Patient'trigno='9'>children</role></role> being <trigger id='trigger-9'>treated</trigger> for injuries"had BBs and nails embedded in their bodies,"which were presumably packed into or around the bombs in order to maximize damage. (Massachusetts Congressman <role id='role-11-Communicator'trigno='11'>Stephen Lynch</role>, reiterating what doctors at multiple hospitals had reported at briefings of their own Monday night, <trigger id='trigger-11'>told</trigger> <role id='role-11-Recipient'trigno='11'>Yahoo News</role> that many victims were struck by what appeared to be metal ball <role id='role-11-Topic'trigno='11'>bearings</role>. ) The exact design of the bombs, of course, remains unclear. Citing an unnamed source familiar with the investigation, the Associated Press reported on Tuesday morning that investigators, upon recovering pieces of <role id='role-12-Artifact'trigno='12'>the exploded bombs</role>, determined that they were <trigger id='trigger-12'>made</trigger> of 6-liter pressure cookers, which were packed with ball bearings and <role id='role-12-Components'trigno='12'>metal nails</role> and stuffed into"black duffel bags."(CNN described them as"backpacks". ) On Tuesday afternoon this information was reported by multiple outlets speaking to sources with knowledge of the Boston investigation. This is what your average pressure cooker looks like: It's a metal container used to quickly cook food using trapped steam. (The cooker's contents are heated using a stove or a built-in heating element, in the case of electric models. ) You can buy one pretty much anywhere. For these reasons it makes an attractive container (to terrible, violent people) for holding, transporting, and detonating explosive materials."Terrorists use pressure cookers as IED containers for 2 main reasons,"Israeli journalist Elizabeth Tsurkov explained via Twitter on Tuesday afternoon."The pressure cooker increases the pressure of the explosion gasses [and] and because the metal casings becomes deadly fragmentation upon detonation."Indeed, there's a long history of terrorists employing pressure cookers abroad. On Tuesday morning Time's Michael Crowley surfaced a 2004 memo issued by the <role id='role-13-Identifier'trigno='13'>Department of Homeland Security</role>, <trigger id='trigger-13'>cataloging</trigger> episodes in which Afghan <role id='role-15-Attacker'trigno='15'><role id='role-14-ManufacturerAssembler'trigno='14'>terrorists</role></role> used <role id='role-14-Components'trigno='14'>pressure cookers</role> to <trigger id='trigger-14'>fabricate</trigger> <role id='role-14-Artifact'trigno='14'>explosive devices</role> and <trigger id='trigger-15'>detonated</trigger> <role id='role-15-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='15'>them</role> in several <role id='role-15-Place'trigno='15'>countries</role> throughout the 2000s. (Such contraptions are especially prevalent in contested regions of Pakistan. ) American soil is no stranger to these contraptions, either. The foiled <role id='role-16-Attacker'trigno='16'>terrorist</role> plot to <trigger id='trigger-16'>detonate</trigger> a <role id='role-16-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='16'>bomb</role> in <role id='role-16-Place'trigno='16'>Times Square</role> on May 1, 2010, involved a pressure cooker. Indeed, nobody in law enforcement or government is making any public connections to any groups or places right now. A Saudi <role id='role-17-Defendant'trigno='17'>man</role> reported to be a"person of interest"has been <trigger id='trigger-17'>cleared</trigger> as a suspect. As President Obama said at the White House Tuesday:"What we don't yet know, however, is who carried out this <trigger id='trigger-18'>attack</trigger>, or why; whether it was planned and executed by a terrorist organization, foreign or domestic, or was the act of a malevolent individual. That's what we don't yet know. And clearly, we're at the beginning of <role id='role-19-Investigator'trigno='19'>our</role> <trigger id='trigger-19'>investigation</trigger>."In a post expanding on the memo, Time's Crowley noted the ease of creating such an explosive device."The ability to make these bombs is hardly unique to al Qaeda and its sympathizers. Details on how to make a pressure cooker bomb can also be found on websites associated with anarchy and other forms of non-religious radicalism,"he said, before linking to such a website. Other evidence suggests that <role id='role-20-Artifact'trigno='20'>the bombs</role> were <trigger id='trigger-20'>made</trigger> with <role id='role-20-Components'trigno='20'>readily-available chemicals</role>. New Scientist asked a bomb <role id='role-21-Investigator'trigno='21'>expert</role> to <trigger id='trigger-21'>study</trigger> the footage of the <trigger id='trigger-22'>explosion</trigger> for clues of the bombs origin. Here's what the expert concluded:"The Boston bombs. . . produced an orange flash followed by white smoke. This suggests the bombs contained neither TNT nor RDX, which produce black smoke, but could have been a home-made chlorate-based device."Update, 5: 04 p. m. : ABC News is reporting that <role id='role-23-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='23'>one</role> of the bombs used gunpowder to <trigger id='trigger-23'>detonate</trigger>. It's unclear how <role id='role-24-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='24'>the bombs</role> <trigger id='trigger-24'>detonated</trigger> In the same report detailing how <role id='role-25-Artifact'trigno='25'>the bombs</role> were <trigger id='trigger-25'>built</trigger>, the Associated Press notes,"law enforcement officials have some of the bomb components but [do] not yet know what was used to <trigger id='trigger-26'>set off</trigger> the <role id='role-26-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='26'>explosives</role>."In that vacuum of knowledge a number of rumors have appeared: 1) the bombs used a timer; 2) the bombs were activated remotely; 3) cell phone service was shut down in downtown Boston to avert other remotely-activated bombs; and 4) a mysterious roof-top figure captured in a single photo has something to do with setting off the bomb. Rumor No. 1 appears to be the strongest. After speaking to an official close to the investigation, CNN knocked down rumors (discussed below) that the bomb had been detonated using a cell phone-activated trigger, and reported that investigators in Boston think the bombs had timers attached to them instead. And, within minutes of CNN's report, the Globe reported that investigators had turned up a <role id='role-27-Instrument'trigno='27'>circuit board</role> they believe was used to <trigger id='trigger-27'>trigger</trigger> the explosions; it was reportedly found near a spot where Gov. Patrick had been seated earlier in the day.
