text: Image caption <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>Naser Jason Abdo</role> planned the <trigger id='trigger-0'>attack</trigger> outside <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Fort Hood</role> so he would not have to get past security A <role id='role-1-Attacker'trigno='1'>US soldier</role> convicted of plotting to <trigger id='trigger-1'>blow up</trigger> a restaurant full of <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>troops</role> in <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>Texas</role> has been sentenced to life in jail. The former Army Pfc, <role id='role-2-Defendant'trigno='2'>Naser Jason Abdo</role>, was found <trigger id='trigger-2'>guilty</trigger> in May of six federal offences, including attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction. The 22-year-old said last year <role id='role-3-Attacker'trigno='3'>he</role> had planned a"massive <trigger id='trigger-3'>attack</trigger>"against <role id='role-3-Target'trigno='3'>soldiers</role> stationed at <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>Fort Hood</role>. <role id='role-4-Detainee'trigno='4'>He</role> went Awol in Kentucky just before his <trigger id='trigger-4'>arrest</trigger> near <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>Fort Hood</role> in 2011. At the time of <role id='role-5-Detainee'trigno='5'>his</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>arrest</trigger>, the <role id='role-5-Jailer'trigno='5'>authorities</role> found bomb-making materials in his <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>motel room</role>. Abdo, a Muslim convert and Texas native, refused to deploy to Iraq and Afghanistan from Fort Campbell in Kentucky, before going missing on 4 July 2011.'Allah gives mercy'He said he was planning a religious mission to secure"justice"for the people of those countries, in a recorded conversation with his mother that was played during his <trigger id='trigger-6'>trial</trigger>. <role id='role-7-Defendant'trigno='7'><role id='role-6-Defendant'trigno='6'>Abdo</role></role> represented himself after <trigger id='trigger-7'>telling</trigger> a <role id='role-7-JudgeCourt'trigno='7'><role id='role-6-JudgeCourt'trigno='6'>judge</role></role> he was not communicating well with his lawyer. Image caption Abdo said he had been inspired by Army psychiatrist Nidal Hasan, who killed 13 people at Fort Hood <role id='role-8-Defendant'trigno='8'>He</role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>appeared</trigger> in <role id='role-8-JudgeCourt'trigno='8'>court</role> with a white cloth bound across his mouth and a black mesh over his hair and face-earlier this year he attempted to spit what he apparently thought was HIV-infected blood on three officers. <role id='role-9-Defendant'trigno='9'>Abdo</role> made a long, meandering <trigger id='trigger-9'>statement</trigger> to the <role id='role-9-JudgeCourt'trigno='9'>court</role> in which he said he would pursue jihad"until the day the dead are called to account for their deeds"."I don't ask the court for mercy because Allah is the one that gives mercy,"he said. He spoke Arabic intermittently during his statement, and then translated for the court. <role id='role-11-Attacker'trigno='11'><role id='role-10-Defendant'trigno='10'>He</role></role> was also <trigger id='trigger-10'>convicted</trigger> of attempted <trigger id='trigger-11'>murder</trigger> of US <role id='role-11-Target'trigno='11'>officers</role> or employees, and four counts of possessing a weapon in furtherance of a federal crime of violence. Abdo told police in a recorded interview he planned the attack"because I don't appreciate what my unit did in Afghanistan". According to authorities, <role id='role-12-Attacker'trigno='12'>he</role> intended to <trigger id='trigger-12'>set off</trigger> a bomb in a <role id='role-12-Place'trigno='12'>Chinese restaurant</role> popular with Fort Hood <role id='role-12-Target'trigno='12'>soldiers</role> and their families. Then Abdo planned to wait outside and shoot any survivors. He believed he would become a martyr when police killed him, they added. Abdo referred to <role id='role-13-Attacker'trigno='13'>Maj Nidal Hasan</role>, an army psychiatrist accused of killing 13 <role id='role-13-Target'trigno='13'>people</role> in a 2009 <trigger id='trigger-13'>shooting</trigger> at <role id='role-13-Place'trigno='13'>Fort Hood</role>, and told the court he remained in the accused's shadow despite"efforts to outdo him".

text: On the evening of 2 September 2019, a <role id='role-1-Instrument'trigno='1'>bomb</role> on a tractor <trigger id='trigger-0'>killed</trigger> 16 <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>people</role> and <trigger id='trigger-1'>injured</trigger> 119 <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>others</role> at a housing compound used by international organisations in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Kabul</role>, Afghanistan. The target of the <trigger id='trigger-2'>attack</trigger> was foreign <role id='role-2-Target'trigno='2'>citizens</role> living in the town; five <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>Nepalis</role>, two Britons and a 43-year-old Romanian diplomat were <trigger id='trigger-3'>killed</trigger> in the attack. Twenty-five other foreign residents were <trigger id='trigger-4'>wounded</trigger>, including another <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>Romanian</role>. On 5 September 2019, at least 12 people, including an American service member and a Romanian <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>soldier</role>, were <trigger id='trigger-5'>killed</trigger> and more than <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>40</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>injured</trigger> when a suicide car <role id='role-7-Attacker'trigno='7'><role id='role-6-Injurer'trigno='6'><role id='role-5-Killer'trigno='5'>bomber</role></role></role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>exploded</trigger> in a heavily fortified area of central <role id='role-7-Place'trigno='7'><role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>Kabul</role></role>, close to the Afghan security offices. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attacks. == References ==

text: (Reuters)-<role id='role-0-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='0'>Bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>blasts</trigger> ripped through churches and luxury <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>hotels</role> in <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Sri Lanka</role></role> on Easter Sunday, <trigger id='trigger-1'>killing</trigger> <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>207</role> and <trigger id='trigger-2'>injuring</trigger> 450 <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>people</role>, in the first major <trigger id='trigger-3'>attack</trigger> on the Indian Ocean <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>island</role> since the end of a civil war 10 years ago. Sri Lankan military stand guard near the <trigger id='trigger-4'>explosion</trigger> <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>site</role> at a church in Batticaloa, Sri Lanka April 21, 2019. REUTERS / Stringer Here is a timeline of the <trigger id='trigger-5'>explosions</trigger> and subsequent events on Sunday. Many of the <trigger id='trigger-6'>attacks</trigger> were carried out by suicide <role id='role-6-Attacker'trigno='6'>bombers</role>, police said. 8. 45 am–<trigger id='trigger-7'>Explosion</trigger> at <role id='role-7-Target'trigno='7'>Shangri La hotel</role> in <role id='role-7-Place'trigno='7'>Colombo</role> 8. 45 am-<trigger id='trigger-8'>Explosion</trigger> at <role id='role-8-Target'trigno='8'>St. Anthony’s Church</role> in <role id='role-8-Place'trigno='8'>Kochchikade</role>, Kotahena, Colombo 8. 45 am–<trigger id='trigger-9'>Explosion</trigger> at <role id='role-9-Target'trigno='9'>St. Sebastian Catholic Church</role> in <role id='role-9-Place'trigno='9'>Negambo</role> 8. 45 am–<trigger id='trigger-10'>Explosion</trigger> at <role id='role-10-Target'trigno='10'>Kingsbury Hotel</role> in <role id='role-10-Place'trigno='10'>Colombo</role> 8. 50 am–<trigger id='trigger-11'>Explosion</trigger> at <role id='role-11-Target'trigno='11'>Cinnamon Grand Hotel</role> in <role id='role-11-Place'trigno='11'>Colombo</role> 9. 05 am–<trigger id='trigger-12'>Explosion</trigger> at <role id='role-12-Target'trigno='12'>Zion Roman Catholic Church</role> in <role id='role-12-Place'trigno='12'>Batticaloa</role> 11. 30 am–Emergency Security Council <trigger id='trigger-13'>meeting</trigger> held by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe 11. 40 am–Government declares <trigger id='trigger-30'>closure</trigger> of schools across the country for two days 12. 15 pm–President <role id='role-14-Communicator'trigno='14'>Maithripala Sirisena</role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>appeals</trigger> for <role id='role-14-Recipient'trigno='14'>people</role> to keep calm 1. 45 pm-<trigger id='trigger-15'>Explosion</trigger> at <role id='role-15-Target'trigno='15'>New Tropical Inn</role> in <role id='role-15-Place'trigno='15'>Dehiwela</role>, near the national zoo. This was the seventh explosion. 2. 15 pm–<trigger id='trigger-16'>Explosion</trigger> at a <role id='role-16-Target'trigno='16'>house</role> in <role id='role-16-Place'trigno='16'>Dematagoda</role>, Colombo, during a police raid (the eighth <trigger id='trigger-17'>explosion</trigger>). Three police <role id='role-18-Victim'trigno='18'>officers</role> were <trigger id='trigger-18'>killed</trigger>. 2. 20 pm–Officials <trigger id='trigger-31'>close down</trigger> the island nation’s zoo in Dehiwela. 2. 30 pm–<role id='role-32-Impeder'trigno='32'>Government</role> <trigger id='trigger-32'>blocks</trigger> major social media networks and messaging services, such as Facebook and WhatsApp. 2. 45 pm–Government declares indefinite island wide <trigger id='trigger-33'>curfew</trigger>. 4. 00 pm–All transport services <trigger id='trigger-34'>stopped</trigger>. 4. 30 pm–Government declares <trigger id='trigger-35'>closure</trigger> of all state universities indefinitely. 5. 00 pm–Special cabinet <trigger id='trigger-36'>meeting</trigger> held, headed by Prime Minister Wickremesinghe. 5. 20 pm–Police announce the <trigger id='trigger-20'>death toll</trigger> had risen to <role id='role-20-Victim'trigno='20'>207</role> with <role text: In January 2015, the <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>Corinthia Hotel</role> in Tripoli was <trigger id='trigger-0'>attacked</trigger> by <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>men</role> affiliated with the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL). The hotel was popular with foreign officials and government workers; it had previously housed the Libyan Prime Minister. == Attack == In the early hours of 27 January 2015, ISIL-affiliated <role id='role-1-Attacker'trigno='1'>men</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>detonated</trigger> a car <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>bomb</role> in the parking <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>garage</role> of the <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>hotel</role>. In the chaos, an estimated 5 <role id='role-13-Transporter'trigno='13'><role id='role-2-Attacker'trigno='2'>gunmen</role></role> stormed past the local guard and <trigger id='trigger-13'>entered</trigger> the <role id='role-13-Destination'trigno='13'>hotel</role>, intent on <trigger id='trigger-2'>killing</trigger> <role id='role-2-Target'trigno='2'>guests</role>. Some of the attackers survived the initial contact, leading to a protracted hostage situation. == Victims == Five <role id='role-4-Target'trigno='4'><role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>foreigners</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-3'>died</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-4'>attack</trigger>: one American, one Frenchman, and three Tajiks (including two women). The American, David Berry, was working as a contractor for an American security firm named Crucible. Five Libyan security <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>personnel</role> are also <trigger id='trigger-11'>reported</trigger> to have <trigger id='trigger-5'>died</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-6'>attack</trigger>. == Perpetrators and motivations == The <trigger id='trigger-7'>attack</trigger> was carried out by <role id='role-7-Attacker'trigno='7'>men</role> belonging to ISIL's"Tripoli Province", who are believed to have been natives of Libya. The <role id='role-12-Communicator'trigno='12'>attackers</role>'<trigger id='trigger-12'>stated</trigger> objective was revenge for the <trigger id='trigger-14'>death</trigger> of <role id='role-14-Victim'trigno='14'><role id='role-8-Attacker'trigno='8'>Abu Anas al-Libi</role></role>, a Libyan Al-Qaeda operative who was involved in the <trigger id='trigger-8'>bombing</trigger> of two American <role id='role-8-Target'trigno='8'>embassies</role> in 1998. <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'><role id='role-9-Detainee'trigno='9'>He</role></role> was <trigger id='trigger-9'>captured</trigger> by American <role id='role-9-Jailer'trigno='9'>forces</role> inside <role id='role-9-Place'trigno='9'>Libya</role> in 2013, and <trigger id='trigger-10'>died</trigger> in an American <role id='role-10-Place'trigno='10'>hospital</role> on 2 January 2015. == See also == * ISIL takeover of Derna == References ==

text: <role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>Juvenile</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>charged</trigger> with bringing bomb to school ST. GEORGE, Utah (News4Utah–Students went back to class at Pine View High School in St. <role id='role-1-PassengerArtifact'trigno='1'>George</role> Tuesday after the school was <trigger id='trigger-1'>evacuated</trigger> Monday after a bomb was found inside the school. The suspect is now linked to another crime at another high school. A juvenile is in custody and <role id='role-9-Communicator'trigno='9'><role id='role-2-Observer'trigno='2'>police</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>say</trigger> after a <trigger id='trigger-2'>search</trigger> of the boys <role id='role-2-ObservedEntity'trigno='2'>home</role>, <role id='role-3-Identifier'trigno='3'>they</role> <trigger id='trigger-3'>discovered</trigger> that <role id='role-7-Researcher'trigno='7'>he</role> was <trigger id='trigger-7'>researching</trigger> <role id='role-7-Subject'trigno='7'>ISIS</role> propaganda online."It was really scary,"<trigger id='trigger-8'>said</trigger> Pine View High School senior <role id='role-8-Communicator'trigno='8'>Olivia Jones</role>, who was one of the <role id='role-6-PassengerArtifact'trigno='6'>students</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>evacuated</trigger>."I saw cops coming from one side and then another side, and grabbed this kid that was literally five feet away from me and they were kind of like aggressive with him, and and brought him to the top of the stadium and patted him down and searched him and he ended up being the suspect,"said Jones."It was an explosive device that was homemade. And the purpose of that device was to cause severe injury, potentially death, and damage,"<trigger id='trigger-10'>said</trigger> <role id='role-10-Communicator'trigno='10'>Lona Trombley</role>, Public Information Officer with St. George Police. Police say that explosive was purposefully left inside a common area at Pine View High School by the suspect."He was in my seminary class. He was super quiet … He kind of kept to himself. My seminary teacher was saying that before they had been evacuated he had been hysterically laughing which was out of the ordinary for him,"said Jones. After St. George police <trigger id='trigger-4'>interviewed</trigger> the <role id='role-4-Participant'trigno='4'><role id='role-4-Participant'trigno='4'>boy</role></role> who took classes at Pineview High, Hurricane police were called."Our investigators went to work and they assisted in serving a search warrant at his residence here in Hurricane and the results of that search warrant were items related to the flag incident were seized from the home,"<trigger id='trigger-11'>said</trigger> Officer <role id='role-11-Communicator'trigno='11'>Ken Thompson</role> with Hurricane City Police Department. That flag incident happened February 15. <role id='role-12-Communicator'trigno='12'>Police</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>say</trigger> Hurricane High School’s US flag was taken down and replaced with an ISIS Flag, and the school was spray painted."Spray painted ‘ ISIS is comi’on the side of the building,"<trigger id='trigger-13'>said</trigger> <role id='role-13-Communicator'trigno='13'>Thompson</role>."This is the first time that something like this has ever happened in our community and it’s a huge relief. People are relieved and glad that it’s been solved,"<trigger id='trigger-14'>said</trigger> <role id='role-14-Communicator'trigno='14'>Thompson</role>. Police say it was students who noticed smoke coming from the backpack and alerted faculty. The <role id='role-5-Defendant'trigno='5'>suspect</role> has been <trigger id='trigger-5'>charged</trigger> with manufacturing and attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction. More charges are pending from Hurricane City Police Department. Video Video

text: Abstract The <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Oklahoma City</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>bombing</trigger> on April 19, 1995 was a watershed moment in American history and indelibly changed the way Americans viewed terrorism and public safety. While the effects of the bombing are well-documented, not as much attention has been paid to the motivations of the bomber, <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>Timothy McVeigh</role>. He was spurred to action by the events of the <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>Waco</role> siege, where the <role id='role-4-Attacker'trigno='4'>FBI</role> engaged in a 51-day <trigger id='trigger-4'>standoff</trigger> with the Branch Davidians, a small religious <role id='role-4-Target'trigno='4'>group</role> suspected of owning illegal weapons. However, this was not the first incident that inspired his later actions. In 1992, the Weaver <role id='role-5-Target'trigno='5'>family</role> entered into their own <trigger id='trigger-5'>standoff</trigger> against federal <role id='role-5-Attacker'trigno='5'>agents</role>, after Randy Weaver failed to show up to court on illegal weapons charges. Over the course of the standoff, his wife, Vicki Weaver, and twelve-year-old son <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>Samuel</role> were <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger>. Both Waco and Ruby Ridge galvanized the far right, who saw it as the government using deadly force against their own citizens, who merely wished to live their lives as they saw fit. McVeigh was further influenced by The Turner Diaries, a novel in which the <role id='role-2-Attacker'trigno='2'>protagonist</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>blows</trigger> up a government <role id='role-2-Target'trigno='2'>building</role> as a part of a revolution against the government. These three factors are analyzed in regards to the influence they had on <role id='role-3-Attacker'trigno='3'>McVeigh</role>’s decision to <trigger id='trigger-3'>attack</trigger> the <role id='role-3-Target'trigno='3'>Murrah building</role>.

text: Boston Marathon Bomber’s Life Hangs in the Balance BOSTON — He’s a charmer. He’s a slacker. He’s bright. He’s a victim of culture shock, a broken family and a domineering older brother. He’s a murderer. He’s a terrorist. That’s the picture presented in recent days of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev as his defense lawyers neared the end of their effort to save their client’s life. As early as Monday, the defense may rest their case and put their faith in the 12-person jury, which will decide whether he should die or live. <role id='role-1-Defendant'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>Tsarnaev</role></role>, 21, was <trigger id='trigger-1'>convicted</trigger> last month of 30 terrorism and other related charges for his role in the April 2013 <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>Boston</role> Marathon <trigger id='trigger-0'>bombing</trigger>. U. S. law requires that the jury must return a unanimous decision in order to execute a person, and it is that chance–that one juror will decide against the death penalty–where Tsarnaev’s lawyers are placing their hopes. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, shown in January 2007, holding the daughter of his grade school teacher Three people <trigger id='trigger-3'>died</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-2'>attack</trigger>, including an 8-year-old <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>boy</role>, and more than <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>260</role> were <trigger id='trigger-4'>wounded</trigger>. <role id='role-5-Killer'trigno='5'>Tsarnaev</role> and his older brother, Tamerlan, <trigger id='trigger-5'>killed</trigger> a police <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>officer</role> several days later just prior to a car chase and <trigger id='trigger-6'>shootout</trigger> that left <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>Tamerlan</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>dead</trigger>. Penalty Phase The two-part trial entered the “penalty” phase April 21, as prosecutors sought to paint <role id='role-8-Attacker'trigno='8'>Tsarnaev</role> as a willing accomplice in the worst terrorist <trigger id='trigger-8'>attack</trigger> on <role id='role-8-Place'trigno='8'>U. S. </role> soil since Sept. 11, 2001. Defense lawyers portrayed their client as a malleable participant, under the sway of Tamerlan, who they said was the mastermind and leader. “The whole goal of the defense is … to make the jury see the defendant as a vulnerable human being,” said Robert Dunham, executive director of the Washington-based Death Penalty Information Center. “The jury doesn’t have to like him,” he said. “The jury doesn’t have to want to have him over to their house for dinner. They just have to decide that putting him away in a dark hole for the rest of his life is an acceptable punishment.” As with the previous phase, the courtroom has been whipsawed by testimony, by turns infuriating, wrenching, maddening or saddening. Prosecutors stunned spectators and jurors in their opening arguments for the death penalty by juxtaposing photographs: of the youngest victim, 8-year-old Martin Richard, and that of Tsarnaev, making an obscene gesture to a video camera in the prison cell where he’s being held. “This is Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, unconcerned, unrepentant and unchanged,” federal prosecutor Nadine Pellegrini told jurors. Courtroom Tears On Monday, less than two weeks later, the courtroom filled with sobbing, when Tsarnaev’s aunt, Patimat Suleimanova, flown from Russia, wracked with tears, tried to speak about her nephew whom she hadn’t seen in more than a decade. During the weeks that the trial has been ongoing, Tsarnaev, who spent his childhood shuttling between Russia and Kyrgyzstan and then his formative years in a three-bedroom, third-floor apartment in Cambridge, Massachusetts, has been largely impassive and at times appearing bored. On Monday, after listening to his aunt, he himself broke down for the first time, rubbing his eyes with his fists and openly weeping. Not long after, as he was being led from the courtroom during a break, he blew a kiss to a cousin who was in attendance. South Boston resident <role id='role-11-Demonstrator'trigno='11'>Joe Kebartas</role>, holding a sign reading"Death Penalty is Murder,"<trigger id='trigger-11'>demonstrates</trigger> outside the federal courthouse where Boston Marathon <trigger id='trigger-9'>bombing</trigger> suspect <role id='role-10-Defendant'trigno='10'><role id='role-9-Attacker'trigno='9'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role></role> has been <trigger id='trigger-10'>convicted</trigger> on all 30 counts, April 8, 2015. More than 40 witnesses appeared during the penalty phase, including some of Tsarnaev’s former school teachers and college friends, some crying openly. During her appeareance in court on April 29, one former teacher, Becki Norris, smiled at Tsarnaev, and he returned the smile. Later, she posted a photograph on Facebook of 12-year-old Tsarnaev holding her newborn daughter. “When you care deeply for someone, that doesn't stop even if they do unfathomably horrible things. We humans are really good at holding two irreconcilable ideas in our psyches at the same time. Yes, he did the unforgivable. And yes, I still love him. And–this one is hard to fathom, I know–he still needs love,” Norris wrote on her Facebook page. Death penalty decision The decision by the Obama administration to seek the death penalty for Tsarnaev has been controversial. Massachusetts state law does not allow for capital punishment, but <role id='role-12-Defendant'trigno='12'>Tsarnaev</role> is being <trigger id='trigger-12'>tried</trigger> in federal <role id='role-12-JudgeCourt'trigno='12'>court</role>. Support for the death penalty in the state has never been strong, and public opinion polls taken by Boston-area media in the months prior to and during the trial have shown dwindling enthusiasm. On the eve of the final phase, the Boston Globe published a front-page letter from Martin Richard’s family, in which they called for sentencing Tsarnaev to life in prison. This undated photo provided by Bill Richard shows his son, <role id='role-14-Victim'trigno='14'>Martin Richard</role>, who was among the at least three people <trigger id='trigger-14'>killed</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-13'>explosions</trigger> at the finish <role id='role-13-Target'trigno='13'>line</role> of the <role id='role-13-Place'trigno='13'>Boston</role> Marathon, Apr. 15, 2013. “As long as the defendant is in the spotlight, we have no choice but to live a story told on his terms, not ours,” the family wrote. “The minute the defendant fades from our newspapers and TV screens is the minute we begin the process of rebuilding our lives and our family.” At the beginning of Tsarnaev’s trial, his defense, led by renowned lawyer Judy Clarke, conceded his guilt, in what appeared to be a strategy focused more on saving his life. “This is the theory: that no person is only the worse thing they’ve done in their life,” said Quin Denvir, a former federal defender who worked with Clarke in gaining a life prison sentence for Theodore Kaczynski, the “Unabomber,” in a federal trial in 1998. “It’s all part of letting the jury seeing the person as a human being, not just the perpetrator of a crime, but as a fully developed human being, with strengths and weaknesses,” Denvir said. In addition to calling relatives and experts on Chechnya’s tortured history, lawyers have called witnesses to argue that the prison where Tsarnaev would live out the rest of his life–the U. S. Penitentiary Administrative Maximum Facility in Colorado–would be harsh and unforgiving. It is “a mechanism to cut off an inmate’s communications with the outside world,” defense witness Mark Bezy testified on Wednesday. Tsarnaev’s parents, Anzor and Zubeidat, were not called to testify. Both now live in Dagestan, the Russian region bordering Chechnya, and have not returned the United States since just after Tsarnaev’s initial court appearance in 2013. Russian Hunger For News With the Tsarnaev family’s ties to Russia and the North Caucasus, there’s been intense interest in the trial for many Russians, according to Alexei Venediktov, the editor-in-chief of Ekho Moskvy, an influential, independent radio station and Web site in Moscow. The proceedings, however, have received virtually no coverage in the Russian news media, nearly all of which is state-controlled. Venediktov told VOA that’s probably because of growing concern from the Kremlin about stability in the long-troubled North Caucasus. “This process carries an unpleasant association, I think, for the leadership, in particular, of the Russian Federation, and therefore, I think, it’s possible there’s been embargo on news,” he said. He also said support is growing in Russia to bring back the death penalty, and were the Boston jury to sentence him to death, it would have a significant impact on the Russian debate. “I think the jury’s verdict will be actively discussed in Russia if it ends up being the death penalty,” he said. Tlisova reported from Boston; Eckel reported from Washington.

text: <trigger id='trigger-0'>Investigation</trigger> of the Belated Production of Documents in the <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Oklahoma City</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>Bombing</trigger> Case"The <trigger id='trigger-1'>bombing</trigger> of the <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building</role> in Oklahoma City, <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>Oklahoma</role>, on April 19, 1995, was, at the time, the most significant <trigger id='trigger-2'>act</trigger> of terrorism that had ever taken place in the <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>United States</role>. Government agencies, led by the <role id='role-3-Researcher'trigno='3'>Federal Bureau of Investigation</role> (FBI), immediately began an extensive <trigger id='trigger-3'>investigation</trigger> to identify and prosecute the <role id='role-3-Subject'trigno='3'>culprits</role>. The <trigger id='trigger-4'>investigation</trigger>, known as OKBOMB, was run by a Task Force that consisted primarily of FBI <role id='role-4-Researcher'trigno='4'>investigators</role> and support personnel and Department of Justice prosecutors. Within a few months, three <role id='role-5-Prosecutor'trigno='5'>individuals</role>-Timothy McVeigh, Terry Nichols, and Michael Fortier-were <trigger id='trigger-5'>indicted</trigger> for crimes relating to the bombing. <role id='role-6-Defendant'trigno='6'>McVeigh</role> and Nichols were <trigger id='trigger-6'>convicted</trigger> after trials, and <role id='role-7-Defendant'trigno='7'>Fortier</role> pled <trigger id='trigger-7'>guilty</trigger> as part of a plea agreement with the government. <role id='role-13-Attacker'trigno='13'><role id='role-8-Defendant'trigno='8'>McVeigh</role></role>, who had devised the plot to <trigger id='trigger-13'>bomb</trigger> the <role id='role-13-Target'trigno='13'>Murrah Building</role> and had planted the bomb, was <trigger id='trigger-8'>sentenced</trigger> to death. On May 8, 2001, one week before McVeigh's scheduled execution date, the Department of Justice and the <role id='role-11-Investigator'trigno='11'>FBI</role> <trigger id='trigger-11'>revealed</trigger> to McVeigh's and <role id='role-11-Defendant'trigno='11'>Nichols</role>'attorneys that over 700 investigative documents had not been disclosed to the defendants before their trials. The <role id='role-10-Investigator'trigno='10'>government</role> acknowledged that it had violated a <trigger id='trigger-10'>discovery</trigger> order in the case, and the Attorney General stayed <role id='role-10-Defendant'trigno='10'>McVeigh</role>'s execution for one month in order to resolve the legal issues arising from the belated disclosure. Following the public revelation of the problem, and after <trigger id='trigger-9'>finding</trigger> and releasing more than 300 additional OKBOMB documents to the defense, the <role id='role-9-Investigator'trigno='9'>FBI</role> came under severe criticism for its handling of the OKBOMB documents."United States. Department of Justice. Office of the Inspector General 2002-03-19

text: A suicide car <role id='role-0-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='0'>bombing</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>occurred</trigger> in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Ghazni</role>, Afghanistan on 7 July 2019. It <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger> 14 <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>people</role> and <trigger id='trigger-2'>injured</trigger> another <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>180</role>. The <role id='role-3-Communicator'trigno='3'>Taliban</role> has <trigger id='trigger-3'>claimed</trigger> responsibility for the attack. == See also == * July 2019 Kabul attack (disambiguation) == References ==

text: Criteria Criteria 1 The act must be aimed at attaining a political, economic, religious, or social goal. In terms of economic goals, the exclusive pursuit of profit does not satisfy this criterion. It must involve the pursuit of more profound, systemic economic change. Criterion 2 There must be evidence of an intention to coerce, intimidate, or convey some other message to a larger audience (or audiences) than the immediate victims. It is the act taken as a totality that is considered, irrespective if every individual involved in carrying out the act was aware of this intention. As long as any of the planners or decision-makers behind the attack intended to coerce, intimidate or publicize, the intentionality criterion is met. Criterion 3 The action must be outside the context of legitimate warfare activities. That is, the act must be outside the parameters permitted by international humanitarian law (particularly the prohibition against deliberately targeting civilians or non-combatants. Doubt Terrorism Proper The existence of a"Yes"for"Doubt Terrorism Proper?"records reservation, in the eyes of GTD analysts, that the incident in question is truly terrorism. Such uncertainty, however, was not deemed to be sufficient to disqualify the incident from inclusion into the GTD. Furthermore, such a determination of doubt is subsequently coded by GTD analysts as conforming to one of four possible alternative designations: 1) Insurgency / Guerilla Action; 2) Internecine Conflict Action; 3) Mass Murder; or 4) Purely Criminal Act.

1973: <role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>IRA</role> gang <trigger id='trigger-0'>convicted</trigger> of <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>London</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>bombings</trigger> Six men and two <role id='role-2-Defendant'trigno='2'>women</role> have been <trigger id='trigger-2'>convicted</trigger> of <trigger id='trigger-3'>exploding</trigger> two IRA car <role id='role-3-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='3'>bombs</role> in <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>London</role> in March this year. All eight were active members of the Provisional IRA. A ninth <role id='role-4-Defendant'trigno='4'>defendant</role>, 18-year-old Roisin McNearney, was <trigger id='trigger-4'>acquitted</trigger>. One <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>person</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>died</trigger> and almost <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>200</role> were <trigger id='trigger-6'>injured</trigger> in the two <role id='role-6-Instrument'trigno='6'>bombs</role>. <role id='role-7-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='7'>One</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>blew</trigger> up outside the Old Bailey criminal <role id='role-7-Place'trigno='7'>court</role>, while the <role id='role-8-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='8'>other</role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>went</trigger> off outside <role id='role-8-Place'trigno='8'>Scotland Yard</role>. Strict security The 10-week trial at Winchester Crown Court has seen some of the strictest security precautions in British legal history. The court was heavily guarded throughout, and as the verdict was delivered, four rows of plain-clothes detectives sat bethind the dock and at least 15 prison officers surrounded the defendants. All doors to the court were bolted. First, the jury returned a not-guilty verdict on Roisin McNearney, a known IRA activist who is believed to have helped the police identify the other conspirators. As <role id='role-9-Defendant'trigno='9'>her</role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>verdict</trigger> was handed down, the other defendants began to hum the Dead March from Saul, and one threw a coin at her, shouting"Take your blood money with you"as she left the dock in tears. A number of threats have already been made to members of her family and she has said she is unlikely ever to be able to return to her native Belfast.'Murderous enterprises'As the eight guilty defendants were led to the cells below the court several gave clenched fist salutes to relatives and friends in the public gallery, who shouted"Keep your chins up"and"All the best". The judge then addressed Miss McNearney, saying,"You have learned a bitter lesson and I hope it has taught you and others like you not to dabble in murderous enterprises."He then ordered that she be given police protection. The two women defendants, Dolours and <role id='role-10-Perpetrator'trigno='10'>Marian Price</role>, were believed to have played the most important role in the <trigger id='trigger-10'>conspiracy</trigger>, along with a third defendant, Hugh Feeney. All three were student teachers in Belfast. The other conspirators were Gerald Kelly, 19; Robert Walsh, 24; Martin Brady, 22; William Armstrong, 29, and Paul Holmes, 19, all from Belfast. A tenth person, William McLarnon, 19, left the dock on the first day of the trial after pleading guilty to all charges.

text: Video: Utah <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>trooper</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>hit</trigger> from behind by runaway <role id='role-0-Instrument'trigno='0'>car</role> in Sardine Canyon A Utah High <role id='role-1-Patient'trigno='1'>Patrolman</role> was <trigger id='trigger-1'>hospitalized</trigger> after a sliding <role id='role-2-Instrument'trigno='2'>car</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>hit</trigger> <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>him</role> from behind in Sardine Canyon on Sunday. (Courtesy of Utah Department of Public Safety) SALT LAKE CITY, Utah (KUTV)-A Utah highway <role id='role-3-Patient'trigno='3'>patrolman</role> was <trigger id='trigger-3'>hospitalized</trigger> after a sliding <role id='role-4-Instrument'trigno='4'>car</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>hit</trigger> <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>him</role> from behind in Sardine Canyon on Sunday. Sergeant Cade Brenchley, a second-generation trooper, was responding to multiple cars that had slid off the road in the canyon. The trooper was walking toward a stranded white car when <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>he</role> was <trigger id='trigger-5'>hit</trigger> from behind by a black runaway <role id='role-5-Instrument'trigno='5'>car</role> that was sliding. When <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>Brenchley</role> was <trigger id='trigger-6'>hit</trigger>, the video shows him launched into the air before landing beside the white car. On Tuesday, Brenchley spoke to the media for the first time since <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>he</role> was <trigger id='trigger-7'>hit</trigger>."I am extremely grateful to be alive,"he said. Brenchley suffered broken ribs and a broken scapula. <role id='role-8-PassengerArtifact'trigno='8'>He</role> was <trigger id='trigger-8'>transported</trigger> to the <role id='role-8-Destination'trigno='8'>Logan Regional Hospital</role>."I remember thinking to myself, I’ve been hit. Holy crap, I’ve been hit,"Brenchley said. His wife and four children joined him during the press conference. They said they are extremely grateful he is okay."It could have taken me away from my kids and we watched the video and by all means it probably should have,"Brenchley said. He is happy to share his story if it means preventing future accidents."We’re all trying to <trigger id='trigger-9'>get</trigger> to our <role id='role-9-Destination'trigno='9'>destination</role>. We’re trying to get there safely, but we’ve got to pay attention to what’s going on around us,"he said. According to a Utah Department of Public Safety news release, this marks the 11th <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'>trooper</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>hit</trigger> on Utah roads this year."Our department is thankful to the multiple bystanders who came to the aid of Sgt. Brenchley after <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>he</role> was <trigger id='trigger-11'>struck</trigger>,"the news release states."The dash cam video shows many <role id='role-12-Participant'trigno='12'><role id='role-12-Participant'trigno='12'>people</role></role> on the scene who stopped to offer aid and <trigger id='trigger-12'>called</trigger> for help on his car radio. Some of the Cache Valley first responders included three of Sgt. Brenchley's cousins."

text: <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>HOUSTON</role>–A <role id='role-0-Detainee'trigno='0'>25-year-old man</role> has been taken into <trigger id='trigger-0'>custody</trigger> for attempting to maliciously damage or destroy property receiving federal financial assistance, announced Acting U. S. Attorney Abe Martinez. A criminal complaint was filed in Houston federal <role id='role-2-JudgeCourt'trigno='2'>court</role> today <trigger id='trigger-2'>charging</trigger> <role id='role-2-Defendant'trigno='2'>Andrew Schneck</role>, of <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>Houston</role>. He made his initial appearance before U. S. Magistrate Judge <role id='role-1-Jailer'trigno='1'>Mary Milloy</role> this morning, at which time <role id='role-1-Detainee'trigno='1'>he</role> was temporarily ordered into <trigger id='trigger-1'>custody</trigger> upon the government’s request pending a detention hearing set for Thursday, Aug. 24 at 2: 00 p. m. According to the complaint, on the evening of Aug. 19, 2017, a Houston park ranger observed Schneck kneeling among the bushes in front of the General Dowling Monument located in Hermann Park in Houston. Schneck was allegedly holding two small boxes with various items inside to include what appeared to be duct tape and wires. After placing the boxes on the ground per the ranger’s request, Schneck then allegedly took a drink from plastic bottle but immediately spit it on the ground. The ranger then noticed a timer and wires in the box and notified the Houston Police Department (HPD), according to the complaint. The clear liquid was field tested as was a white powdery substance found in a small, black aluminum tube which revealed they were most likely nitroglycerin and Hexamethylene triperoxide diamine (HMTD), respectively, according to the charges. HMTD is a high explosive organic compound used as an initiating, or primary explosive. Nitroglycerin has been used as an active ingredient in the manufacture of explosives. ln its pure form, nitroglycerin is a contact explosive, with physical shock causing it to explode, which degrades over time to even more unstable forms. Nitroglycerin is highly dangerous to transport or use. ln its undiluted form, it is one of the world's most powerful explosives. Authorities believe the items in Schneck’s possession on Aug. 19 were capable to produce a viable explosive device, according to the charges. The complaint further <trigger id='trigger-5'>alleges</trigger> that <role id='role-5-Defendant'trigno='5'>Schneck</role> conducts “chemistry experiments” at his <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>Houston</role> residence. The City of Houston receives federal financial assistance for maintenance of Hermann Park where the General Dowling Monument is located. If convicted, Schneck faces a minimum of five and up to 40 years in federal prison and a possible $250, 000 maximum fine. The <role id='role-4-Investigator'trigno='4'>FBI</role> and HPD are conducting the <trigger id='trigger-4'>investigation</trigger>. Assistant U. S. Attorneys <role id='role-3-Prosecutor'trigno='3'>S. Mark McIntyre</role> and Ted Imperato are <trigger id='trigger-3'>prosecuting</trigger> the case. A criminal complaint is a formal accusation of criminal conduct, not evidence. A defendant is presumed innocent unless convicted through due process of law.

text: Manchester Bomber Was Part of Network, British Police Say British police said Wednesday it was “clear” the <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>suicide bomber</role> who <trigger id='trigger-0'>attacked</trigger> a <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>concert</role> in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Manchester</role> did not act alone."It's very clear that this is a <role id='role-1-Defendant'trigno='1'>network</role> that we are <trigger id='trigger-1'>investigating</trigger>,"<role id='role-1-Investigator'trigno='1'>Manchester Chief Constable</role> Ian Hopkins said during a news conference. Hopkins said police had four people in custody, so far, as police conduct armed raids throughout Manchester, though he would not confirm whether police found the alleged bomb maker. A statement Wednesday from Greater Manchester Police said only that the <trigger id='trigger-2'>arrests</trigger> came after <role id='role-2-Jailer'trigno='2'>officers</role> executed warrants in <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>South Manchester</role>. There was no information about how the four men might be involved in the attack. British interior minister Amber Rudd said Wednesday the suicide bomber, who has been identified as Salman Abedi, 22, was"known"by British intelligence services before the bombing. She also told the BBC that"it seems likely, possible, that he wasn't doing this on his own."The <trigger id='trigger-3'>blast</trigger> at the conclusion of a concert by American pop star Ariana Grande at <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>Manchester Arena</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>killed</trigger> <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>22 people</role> and wounded 59 others. The <role id='role-4-Killer'trigno='4'><role id='role-3-Attacker'trigno='3'>attacker</role></role> also died at the site. Police officers arrive at a residential property on Elsmore Road in Fallowfield, Manchester, on May 24, 2017, as investigations continue into the May 22 terror attack at the Manchester Arena. Investigation shifts to Abedi's activities <role id='role-5-Investigator'trigno='5'>Investigators</role> are now trying to <trigger id='trigger-5'>figure</trigger> out what <role id='role-5-Defendant'trigno='5'>Abedi</role> was up to in his last days before the attack Monday. French Interior Minister Gerard Collomb told BFM television on Wednesday that British and French intelligence have information that Abedi had likely traveled to Syria. According to Collomb, Abedi “grew up in Britain and then suddenly, after a trip to Libya and then likely to Syria, became radicalized and decided to carry out this attack.”"In any case, the links with Daesh (Islamic State) are proven,"he said. <role id='role-6-Attacker'trigno='6'>Islamic State</role> is claiming it was behind the attack, but neither British nor U. S. intelligence have confirmed that. Police officers stand guard in central Manchester, Britain, May 24, 2017 after Monday's suicide <trigger id='trigger-6'>attack</trigger> at an <role id='role-6-Target'trigno='6'>Ariana Grande concert</role>. Terror level raised Britain raised its terrorism alert level to critical–the highest step–after the blast, signaling that another attack was highly likely and could be imminent. The change is most visible in the deployment of soldiers to help guard certain areas, including major events such as concerts and football matches, in order to free up police officers. Hopkins said an off-duty police officer was among <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>those</role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>killed</trigger> in the suicide attack, but it will take up to five days for authorities to identify all the victims. “Due to number of victims the Home Office post-mortems are likely to take four to five days. After this we will be in a position to formerly name the victims,” he said. “We have spoken to all of the families of those who lay injured in our hospitals.” British Prime Minister Theresa May said in an address to the nation late Tuesday that authorities will do everything possible to protect the public and asked people to remain vigilant."I do not want the public to feel unduly alarmed. We have faced a serious terrorist threat in our country for many years,"May said. People attend a vigil in Albert Square, Manchester, England, May 23, 2017, the day after the suicide attack at an Ariana Grande concert that left 22 people dead as it ended on Monday night. Maximum carnage Earlier in the day, she spoke more directly about the <trigger id='trigger-7'>attack</trigger> itself, saying the <role id='role-7-Attacker'trigno='7'>bomber</role> chose the"time and <role id='role-7-Target'trigno='7'>place</role> to cause maximum carnage and to kill and injure indiscriminately."Many of the victims were young girls, with the youngest identified so far being just 8-year-old. Video from the arena showed the joy in the audience at the end of the concert turning to confusion and then to panic and a scramble to get out of the building as the realization of what just happened spread. Witness say they saw blood covered bodies on the floor while <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>others</role>, badly <trigger id='trigger-8'>wounded</trigger>, staggered toward the exits of the building. The scene outside the concert hall was also chaotic, with traffic snarled and parents rushing to the scene. Britain's Queen Elizabeth held a moment of silence at a garden party at Buckingham Palace. French President Emmanuel Macron signed a condolence book at the British embassy in Paris. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said the attack only strengthens Germany's resolve to work with the British.

text: The <role id='role-0-Giver'trigno='0'>salesman</role> said the <role id='role-0-Recipient'trigno='0'>customer</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>bought</trigger> three 54-gallon barrels of <role id='role-0-AcquiredEntity'trigno='0'>nitromethane</role> for <role id='role-0-PaymentBarter'trigno='0'>$925</role> each on Oct. 21, 1994, at a drag-car racetrack in Ennis, Texas. Tim Chambers of VP Racing Fuels told jurors the customer had"kind of like a possum face"-a description that matches McVeigh. DENVER-A Texas racing fuel <role id='role-1-Giver'trigno='1'>salesman</role>-found by the FBI from one of Timothy McVeigh's alleged confessions-recalled Monday <trigger id='trigger-1'>selling</trigger> <role id='role-1-PaymentBarter'trigno='1'>$2, 775</role> in nitromethane to a <role id='role-1-Recipient'trigno='1'>customer</role> who claimed to race bikes in Oklahoma City. He remembered the <trigger id='trigger-2'>purchase</trigger> because it was so unusual."Well, for one thing, three drums of <role id='role-3-AcquiredEntity'trigno='3'>nitromethane</role> being <trigger id='trigger-3'>sold</trigger> for cash never happens. . . . That does not happen. It did not happen to me. Another thing, somebody comes up to <role id='role-4-Giver'trigno='4'>you</role> and <role id='role-4-Recipient'trigno='4'>they</role> are <trigger id='trigger-4'>purchasing</trigger> three drums and they are going to take it and split it with their friends on nitro. . . Harley bikes, that just doesn't happen."Harley street bike guys, if <role id='role-5-Recipient'trigno='5'>they</role> are going to <trigger id='trigger-5'>buy</trigger> gas such as <role id='role-5-AcquiredEntity'trigno='5'>nitromethane</role> from <role id='role-5-Giver'trigno='5'>me</role>, <role id='role-6-Recipient'trigno='6'>they</role> will <trigger id='trigger-6'>buy</trigger> a gallon to five gallons. Now, nitro Harley bikes, you couldn't even afford to even put one of those on the street. That just wouldn't happen."FBI agents found Chambers after Playboy and then ABC reported in March that a 66-page defense document outlines McVeigh's confession.

text: Here is a look at some of the critical pieces of evidence presented during the trial. Taken as a whole, the evidence suggests that the plan to <trigger id='trigger-0'>bomb</trigger> the <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>Boston Marathon</role> took shape over three months. A key issue for jurors — both in the guilt phase and later in the penalty phase if Tsarnaev is convicted — will be whether the jurors see Tsarnaev as an equal partner with his older brother, <role id='role-1-Attacker'trigno='1'>Tamerlan Tsarnaev</role>, in the <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>Boston Marathon</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>bombing</trigger> and the <trigger id='trigger-2'>violent events</trigger> that followed. As of Tuesday morning, <role id='role-3-Investigator'trigno='3'>jurors</role> began <trigger id='trigger-3'>reviewing</trigger> evidence and witness testimony, which will play a role in helping them decide <role id='role-3-Defendant'trigno='3'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role>’s guilt on each of the 30 charges he faces. Advertisement January 2013 Tsarnaev, then 19, <trigger id='trigger-4'>talks</trigger> to his close friend, <role id='role-4-Participant'trigno='4'><role id='role-4-Participant'trigno='4'>Stephen Silva</role></role>, about borrowing Silva’s <role id='role-4-Topic'trigno='4'>9mm P95 Ruger</role> semi-automatic pistol. Tsarnaev and Silva both graduated from Cambridge Rindge and Latin School in 2001, and worked as lifeguards together at the Harvard pool. Starting in college, <role id='role-5-Perpetrator'trigno='5'>both</role> became very <trigger id='trigger-5'>involved in selling marijuana</trigger>, and <role id='role-7-Recipient'trigno='7'>Silva</role> had <trigger id='trigger-7'>obtained</trigger> <role id='role-7-AcquiredEntity'trigno='7'>a gun</role>, in part, to help him protect his drug business. A Ruger semi-automatic handgun presented in the trial. US Attorney's Office / REUTERS Jan. 30, 2013 <role id='role-8-Recipient'trigno='8'>Tamerlan</role>, 26, allegedly <trigger id='trigger-8'>buys</trigger> <role id='role-8-AcquiredEntity'trigno='8'>two Fager pressure-cookers</role> at Macy’s at the Square One Mall in Saugus. The remains of a pressure cooker bomb. Josh Reynolds for The Boston Globe / Globe Freelance Feb. 8, 2013 <role id='role-6-Recipient'trigno='6'>Tamerlan Tsarnaev</role> used his credit card to make an online <trigger id='trigger-6'>purchase</trigger> of a remote-controlled <role id='role-6-AcquiredEntity'trigno='6'>car</role> set, batteries, and a transmitter and receiver from NitroRCX. com. Prosecutors said these items were used to help <trigger id='trigger-9'>remotely-detonate</trigger> the <role id='role-9-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='9'>bombs</role> February, 2013 <role id='role-11-Attacker'trigno='11'><role id='role-10-Killer'trigno='10'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role></role> visits Silva and borrows the Ruger pistol — the gun that was later used to <trigger id='trigger-10'>kill</trigger> MIT police officer <role id='role-10-Victim'trigno='10'>Sean Collier</role> and during the <trigger id='trigger-11'>shootout</trigger> with <role id='role-11-Target'trigno='11'>police</role> in Watertown. March 11, 2013 Dzhokhar Tsarnaev creates a secret Twitter account, @ Al-FirdausiA, with the user name Ghuraba and posted six Tweets in three days. The first post on March 11, 2013 reads: “I want the highest levels of Jannah, I want to be able to see Allah every single day for that is the best of pleasures.” He also maintains his original Twitter account that includes mostly typical teenage postings, but some that could be signs of growing radicalization. Advertisement March <role id='role-12-Recipient'trigno='12'>Tamerlan Tsarnaev</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>purchases</trigger> some <role id='role-12-AcquiredEntity'trigno='12'>BBs</role> at Walmart in New Hampshire. March 20, 2013 Both <role id='role-13-Recipient'trigno='13'>brothers</role> went to a firing range in Manchester, N. H. and <trigger id='trigger-13'>rented</trigger> two 9mm <role id='role-13-AcquiredEntity'trigno='13'>handguns</role>, similar to the borrowed Ruger. The Tsarnaev <role id='role-14-PassengerArtifact'trigno='14'>brothers</role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>visit</trigger> the <role id='role-14-Destination'trigno='14'>Manchester Line Firing Range</role> in N. H. a month before the bombing. Share Email to a Friend Embed The Tsarnaev <role id='role-15-PassengerArtifact'trigno='15'>brothers</role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>visit</trigger> the <role id='role-15-Destination'trigno='15'>Manchester Line Firing Range</role> in N. H. a month before the <trigger id='trigger-16'>bombing</trigger>. March 30, 2013 <role id='role-17-Recipient'trigno='17'>Tamerlan Tsarnaev</role> also <trigger id='trigger-17'>bought</trigger> a screwdriver and soldering <role id='role-17-AcquiredEntity'trigno='17'>gun</role> from <role id='role-17-Giver'trigno='17'>Home Depot</role> in Somerville, April 8, 2013 <role id='role-18-Recipient'trigno='18'>Tamerlan</role> <trigger id='trigger-18'>bought</trigger> remote-control <role id='role-18-AcquiredEntity'trigno='18'>car</role> devices from <role id='role-18-Giver'trigno='18'>RC Cars</role> in Malden, which prosecutors say are related to the equipment needed by the <role id='role-19-Attacker'trigno='19'>Tsarnaevs</role> to <trigger id='trigger-19'>remotely trigger</trigger> the <role id='role-19-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='19'>bombs</role>. April 13, 2013 <role id='role-21-Giver'trigno='21'><role id='role-20-Recipient'trigno='20'>Tamerlan Tsarnaev</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-20'>purchases</trigger> <role id='role-20-AcquiredEntity'trigno='20'>ammunition</role> from a store in New Hampshire and <trigger id='trigger-21'>sends</trigger> <role id='role-21-ArtifactMoney'trigno='21'>$900</role> in cash through Moneygram to his and Dzhokhar’s mother, <role id='role-21-Recipient'trigno='21'>Zubeidat</role>, through a location in Somerville. April 14, 2013 Dzhokhar Tsarnaev opens a prepaid cellphone account under the name Jahar Tsarni. He would use this phone while at the Boston Marathon the next day. On the same day, <role id='role-22-Recipient'trigno='22'>Tamerlan Tsarnaev</role> <trigger id='trigger-22'>buys</trigger> two backpacks at a Target in Watertown that were used to carry the bombs. Federal Public Defender Office April 15, 2013 At about 2: 50 p. m. , two homemade pressure-cooker <role id='role-23-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='23'>bombs</role> are <trigger id='trigger-23'>detonated remotely</trigger> by the <role id='role-25-Injurer'trigno='25'><role id='role-24-Killer'trigno='24'><role id='role-23-Attacker'trigno='23'>Tsarnaevs</role></role></role> near the finish <role id='role-23-Target'trigno='23'>line</role> of the Boston Marathon, <trigger id='trigger-24'>killing</trigger> <role id='role-24-Victim'trigno='24'>three</role> and <trigger id='trigger-25'>injuring</trigger> some 260 <role id='role-25-Victim'trigno='25'>others</role>. Seventeen <role id='role-26-Victim'trigno='26'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-26'>lost limbs</trigger>. April 15, 2013 Less than a half hour after the <role id='role-27-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='27'>bombs</role> <trigger id='trigger-27'>went off</trigger>, <role id='role-28-PassengerArtifact'trigno='28'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role> was seen <trigger id='trigger-28'>entering</trigger> the <role id='role-28-Destination'trigno='28'>Whole Foods</role> at Prospect Street in Cambridge and looking over different milk products. <role id='role-29-Recipient'trigno='29'>He</role> <trigger id='trigger-29'>buys</trigger> a carton of whole milk for $3. 49, then returns to parked car in the store lot. He enters the passenger side, suggesting another person, possibly Tamerlan Tsarnaev, was at the wheel. Within seconds, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev gets out of the car and exchanges his purchase for a different type of milk. Advertisement <role id='role-30-PassengerArtifact'trigno='30'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role> <trigger id='trigger-30'>went</trigger> to a Whole Foods grocery <role id='role-30-Destination'trigno='30'>store</role> in Cambridge, where surveillance video showed him pondering what type of milk to buy 23 minutes after the <role id='role-31-Target'trigno='31'>Boston Marathon</role> <trigger id='trigger-31'>bombing</trigger> on April 15, 2013. Share Email to a Friend Embed <role id='role-32-PassengerArtifact'trigno='32'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role> <trigger id='trigger-32'>went</trigger> to a Whole Foods grocery <role id='role-32-Destination'trigno='32'>store</role> in Cambridge, where surveillance video showed him pondering what type of milk to buy 23 minutes after the <role id='role-33-Target'trigno='33'>Boston Marathon</role> <trigger id='trigger-33'>bombing</trigger> on April 15, 2013. April 26, 2013 Days later, the FBI recovered a backpack belonging to Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, which contained tubes of fireworks. In his dorm room, they also found a receipt for a BB gun, which was recovered from the Watertown shootout scene. US Department of Justice Patricia Wen can be reached at wen @ globe. com. Follow her on Twitter at @ GlobePatty.

GEORGE, Utah A 16-year-old southern Utah <role id='role-1-Defendant'trigno='1'>boy</role> \"| inline | intext | n / a \"href =\"https: / / bit. ly / 2GeNJWF \"> <trigger id='trigger-1'>accused</trigger> of bringing a homemade bomb to his high school reportedly told detectives he would have been fine with it if his bomb had detonated and killed or injured his classmates, according to court documents. If someone got hurt, I probably wouldn't care, the Hurricane teen told St. George police detectives, according to an information document filed by the Washington County Attorney's Office. The <role id='role-2-Defendant'trigno='2'>teen</role> was <trigger id='trigger-2'>charged</trigger> Monday with attempted murder and use of a weapon of mass destruction, both first-degree felonies. <role id='role-3-Defendant'trigno='3'>He</role> was also <trigger id='trigger-3'>charged</trigger> with two misdemeanors, graffiti and abuse of a flag, in connection with allegations that <role id='role-4-Destroyer'trigno='4'>he</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>vandalized</trigger> <role id='role-4-Artifact'trigno='4'>another high school</role> in February. Washington County Attorney Brock Belnap said Tuesday the teenager may be tried as an adult under the states Serious Youth Offender Act. The judge will determine whether the youth will be tried in adult court, he said. text: 2 New Arrests in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>London</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>Terror Attack</trigger> <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>London</role> <role id='role-1-Jailer'trigno='1'>police</role> said Friday they have made two more <trigger id='trigger-1'>arrests</trigger> in connection with the <trigger id='trigger-2'>attack</trigger> near Parliament. Counter-terrorism commander Mark Rowley characterized the <trigger id='trigger-3'>arrests</trigger> as “significant,” though he did not provide any details. He said nine <role id='role-4-Detainee'trigno='4'>people</role> are currently <trigger id='trigger-4'>in custody</trigger> and one person has been released. Police officials identified the attacker who <trigger id='trigger-5'>killed</trigger> four <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>people</role> near <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>Parliament</role> as <role id='role-6-Perpetrator'trigno='6'><role id='role-5-Killer'trigno='5'>Khalid Masood</role></role>, a Briton who converted to Islam and had a lengthy criminal record for weapons <trigger id='trigger-6'>possession</trigger> and other charges. Rowley said Masood’s birth name was Adrian Russell Ajao and appealed to the public for any information about him. A woman holds up a sign at a vigil for the victims of Wednesday's <trigger id='trigger-7'>attack</trigger>, at Trafalgar Square in London, March 23, 2017. The Islamic State group has claimed responsibility for an <trigger id='trigger-8'>attack</trigger> by a <role id='role-9-Injurer'trigno='9'><role id='role-8-Attacker'trigno='8'>man</role></role> who plowed an <role id='role-8-Instrument'trigno='8'>SUV</role> into <role id='role-8-Target'trigno='8'>pedestrians</role> and then <trigger id='trigger-9'>stabbed</trigger> a police <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>officer</role>. “We remain keen to hear from anyone who knew Khalid Masood well, understands who his associates were and can provide us with information about places he has recently visited,’’Rowley said. “There might be people out there who did have concerns about Masood but did not feel comfortable for whatever reason in passing those concerns to us.’’Islamic State said Masood, who was 52, was a “soldier” of the extremist group who responded to its call to attack civilians and the military in countries allied with the United States in battling IS. Masood had never been convicted of terrorist offenses, but British security officials said he had been investigated in the past “in relation to concerns about violent extremism.” Authorities say they believe he was acting alone Wednesday when <role id='role-11-Killer'trigno='11'><role id='role-10-Attacker'trigno='10'>he</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>ran down</trigger> <role id='role-10-Target'trigno='10'>pedestrians</role> on <role id='role-10-Place'trigno='10'>Westminster Bridge</role>, a Thames River crossing leading to the Houses of Parliament, crashed his rented vehicle into a gate and <trigger id='trigger-11'>fatally stabbed</trigger> a <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>policeman</role> who tried to stop him. Armed police shot and killed Masood moments later. A <role id='role-13-Place'trigno='13'>property</role> in Birmingham, England, was <trigger id='trigger-13'>searched</trigger> by <role id='role-13-Investigator'trigno='13'>police</role> following Wednesday's <role id='role-12-Place'trigno='12'>London</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>attack</trigger>, March 23, 2017. In the hours after Wednesday’s <trigger id='trigger-14'>attack</trigger> in the heart of <role id='role-14-Place'trigno='14'>London</role>, <role id='role-15-Attacker'trigno='15'>police</role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>conducted raids</trigger> around the <role id='role-15-Place'trigno='15'>country</role> in search of anyone who may have given support to Masood. Eight men and <role id='role-16-Detainee'trigno='16'>women</role> were <trigger id='trigger-16'>arrested</trigger> Thursday on suspicion of planning terrorist acts. The dead assailant, who was older than most Islamist <role id='role-17-Attacker'trigno='17'>attackers</role> involved in recent spectacular <trigger id='trigger-17'>terror attacks</trigger> in <role id='role-17-Place'trigno='17'>Europe</role>, had been a teacher of English and was known as a fanatical bodybuilder. One of the <role id='role-19-Target'trigno='19'>civilians</role> who was <trigger id='trigger-19'>run down</trigger> on the bridge, a 75-year-old <role id='role-18-Victim'trigno='18'>man</role>, <trigger id='trigger-18'>died</trigger> Thursday in a <role id='role-18-Place'trigno='18'>hospital</role>, raising the casualty toll to four victims and Masood. Although Islamic State claimed responsibility for the <trigger id='trigger-20'>attack</trigger>, a statement posted online did not implicate the group in the planning or execution of the attack. An Italian tourist who witnessed the carnage told reporters he saw Masood attack the policeman with two knives. “<role id='role-21-Injurer'trigno='21'>He</role> gave [the <role id='role-21-Victim'trigno='21'>officer</role>] around <trigger id='trigger-21'>10 stabs in the back</trigger>,” the visitor said. Valiant efforts to resuscitate Constable <role id='role-22-Victim'trigno='22'>Keith Palmer</role> at the scene <trigger id='trigger-22'>failed</trigger>. The 48-year-old officer was a 15-year police veteran. One American was among the <trigger id='trigger-23'>dead</trigger>-54-year-old <role id='role-23-Victim'trigno='23'>Kurt Cochran</role> of Utah, who was in London with his wife to celebrate their 25th wedding anniversary. His wife, <role id='role-24-Victim'trigno='24'>Melissa</role>, was among the 30 people <trigger id='trigger-24'>injured</trigger>. <role id='role-25-Injurer'trigno='25'>Masood</role>’s <role id='role-25-Instrument'trigno='25'>vehicle</role> <trigger id='trigger-25'>hit</trigger> the <role id='role-25-Victim'trigno='25'>Cochrans</role> as they crossed Westminster Bridge. The remaining victim of the <trigger id='trigger-26'>attack</trigger> was a British school administrator, <role id='role-26-Target'trigno='26'>Aysha Frade</role>, 43. Candles burn on Westminster Bridge the day after an <trigger id='trigger-27'>attack</trigger> in London, March 23, 2017. Mourners gathered in London’s Trafalgar Square Thursday evening, about one kilometer from the crime scene, for a candlelight vigil. The mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, told the crowd of thousands that” those trying to destroy our shared way of life will never succeed.” Khan said the vigil in the most recognizable public plaza in London was meant to honor the dead and injured, but also “to send a clear, clear message: Londoners will never be cowed by terrorism.” Rowley, head of counterterrorism efforts for London’s <role id='role-28-Jailer'trigno='28'>Metropolitan Police Service</role>, said the eight <role id='role-28-Detainee'trigno='28'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-28'>arrested</trigger> Thursday were picked up during searches at six separate <role id='role-28-Place'trigno='28'>locations</role>, and that <trigger id='trigger-29'>investigations</trigger> were continuing in London, Birmingham and other <role id='role-29-Place'trigno='29'>parts</role> of England. He declined to say whether or how those <trigger id='trigger-30'>detained</trigger> were involved in Wednesday’s <trigger id='trigger-31'>attack</trigger>. “It is still our belief, which continues to be born out by our investigation, that this attacker acted alone and was inspired by international terrorism,” Rowley told reporters. Britain's Prime Minister <role id='role-33-Communicator'trigno='33'>Theresa May</role> <trigger id='trigger-33'>gives a media statement</trigger> outside 10 Downing street in London, March 22, 2017, following a terror <trigger id='trigger-32'>attack</trigger> in the <role id='role-32-Place'trigno='32'>Westminster</role> area of London earlier Wednesday. Prime Minister Theresa May struck a defiant tone in discussing the <trigger id='trigger-34'>attack</trigger> before Parliament Thursday, telling British lawmakers that what London experienced was “an attack on free people everywhere.” “Yesterday an <trigger id='trigger-35'>act of terrorism</trigger> tried to silence our democracy, but today we meet as normal, as generations have done before us and as future generations will continue to do, to deliver a simple message: We are not afraid and our resolve will never waver in the face of terrorism,” she said. May thanked Britain’s friends and allies around the world “who have made it clear that they stand with us at this time.” She said the victims include nationals of France, Romania, South Korea, Germany, Poland, Ireland, China, Italy and Greece, as well as the United States. The United Nations Security Council in New York, chaired by British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson, observed a moment of silence Thursday for the London victims. Tense <role id='role-36-Place'trigno='36'>London</role> Carries on After <role id='role-36-Attacker'trigno='36'>Islamic State</role> <trigger id='trigger-36'>Attack</trigger> Video size width x height pixels Tense <role id='role-37-Place'trigno='37'>London</role> Carries on After <role id='role-37-Attacker'trigno='37'>Islamic State</role> <trigger id='trigger-37'>Attack</trigger> Share this video 0: 02: 20 ▶ 0: 00: 00 / 0: 02: 20 ▶ ▶ Direct link 270p | 6. 3MB 360p | 9. 3MB 720p | 61. 6MB “You may know that today there are victims in London from 11 nations. Which goes to show that an <trigger id='trigger-38'>attack</trigger> on <role id='role-38-Place'trigno='38'>London</role> is an attack on the world,” Johnson said. “I can tell you from my talks here in the United States with the U. S. government and with partners from around the world that the world is uniting to defeat the <role id='role-39-Attacker'trigno='39'>people</role> who launched this <trigger id='trigger-39'>attack</trigger> and defeat their bankrupt and odious ideology.” In London, Parliament’s session began with a minute of silence Thursday. Police officers stood in silence nearby outside the headquarters of the city’s Metropolitan Police.

text: CAIN Web Service Irish Republican Army (IRA) Statement of Apology, 16 July 2002 [CAIN_Home] [KEY_EVENTS] [Key_Issues] [Conflict_Background] PEACE: [Menu] [Summary] [Reading] [Background] [Chronology_1] [Chronology_2] [Chronology_3] [Articles] [Agreement] [Sources] Page Compiled: Martin Melaugh Full text of Irish Republican Army (IRA) statement of apology 16 April 2002"Sunday 21 July marks the 30th anniversary of an IRA operation in Belfast in 1972 which resulted in nine <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>people</role> being <trigger id='trigger-0'>killed</trigger> and <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>many</role> more <trigger id='trigger-1'>injured</trigger>. While it was not our intention to <trigger id='trigger-2'>injure</trigger> or <trigger id='trigger-3'>kill</trigger> <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>non-combatants</role></role>, the reality is that on this and on a number of other occasions, that was the consequence of our actions. It is therefore appropriate on the anniversary of this tragic event, that we address all of the <trigger id='trigger-4'>deaths</trigger> and <trigger id='trigger-5'>injuries</trigger> of <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>non-combatants</role></role> caused by us. We offer our sincere apologies and condolences to their families. There have been fatalities amongst combatants on all sides. We also acknowledge the grief and pain of their relatives. The future will not be found in denying collective failures and mistakes or closing minds and hearts to the plight of <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>those</role> who have been <trigger id='trigger-6'>hurt</trigger>. That includes all of the victims of the <trigger id='trigger-7'>conflict</trigger>, combatants and non-combatants. It will not be achieved by creating a hierarchy of victims in which some are deemed more or less worthy than others. The process of <trigger id='trigger-8'>conflict</trigger> resolution requires the equal acknowledgement of the grief and loss of others. On this anniversary, we are endeavouring to fulfil this responsibility to <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>those</role> <role id='role-9-Injurer'trigno='9'>we</role> have <trigger id='trigger-9'>hurt</trigger>. The IRA is committed unequivocally to the search for freedom, justice and peace in Ireland. We remain totally committed to the peace process and to dealing with the challenges and difficulties which this presents. This includes the acceptance of past mistakes and of the hurt and pain we have caused to others."P O'Neill, Irish Republican Publicity Bureau, Dublin. The <trigger id='trigger-10'>statement</trigger> from the IRA was received by <role id='role-10-Participant'trigno='10'><role id='role-10-Participant'trigno='10'>An Phoblacht</role></role> (Republican News) on Tuesday, 16 July:

text: A woman who lost her mother in the McGurks'bar atrocity relives the horror of that day."I remember at night after my <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>mummy</role> had <trigger id='trigger-0'>died</trigger> listening to my daddy crying and calling for her."These are the words of Pat Arthus who was just 14-years-old when a <role id='role-1-Killer'trigno='1'>loyalist</role> <role id='role-2-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='2'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>ripped</trigger> through a <role id='role-2-Target'trigno='2'>bar</role> in a Catholic <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>area</role> of Belfast and <trigger id='trigger-1'>killed</trigger> her <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>mother</role>. Fifteen people including <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>men</role>, women and children <trigger id='trigger-3'>lost</trigger> their lives in the <trigger id='trigger-4'>explosion</trigger> at The <role id='role-4-Target'trigno='4'>Tramore Bar</role>-better known as McGurk's-in <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>North Queen Street</role> on 4 December 1971. It was one of worst atrocities in the history of the Troubles, but one which some families of the bereaved feel is largely forgotten about. Playing <role id='role-11-Communicator'trigno='11'>Pat Arthus</role> remembers her mother, Kathleen Irvine, <trigger id='trigger-11'>saying</trigger> her prayers on the day of the explosion. Ironically, Mrs Irvine and other local women went to a grotto every day to pray for peace. Pat was playing out in the street when the <role id='role-5-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='5'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>went off</trigger>."I remember running down to the scene. It was just completely flattened,"<role id='role-12-Participant'trigno='12'><role id='role-12-Participant'trigno='12'>she</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>said</trigger>."People just came from everywhere. They were on their hands and knees. They were passing the rubble one by one. They were in a big line."You heard them shouting:'There's one, there's one'."It was just total chaos. Soldiers threw their guns down on the ground to help the people from the New Lodge Road dig."Later, she went home and found her grandmother in the house crying, after learning that Pat's mother and father had been caught up in the bomb. Her <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>father</role> was seriously <trigger id='trigger-6'>injured</trigger> in the blast."After that was like a total blur, because people were coming in and out of the house,"she said."There were that many different stories being told."My granny gave me and my brother wee jobs to do about the house. To go in and make the tea, tidy up, to try and keep us busy."But you were hearing people saying things like they were bringing people out in black bags. It was terrible, it really was."'Own goal'She also recalled the pain of seeing her <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>father</role>, who has since <trigger id='trigger-7'>died</trigger>, cope with the <trigger id='trigger-13'>loss</trigger> of his <role id='role-13-Victim'trigno='13'>wife</role>."I remember my granny, she was 80-odd years of age, going into him,"she said."When I looked into the room she was cradling her son in her arms.'It's all right Johnny,'<role id='role-14-Participant'trigno='14'><role id='role-14-Participant'trigno='14'>she</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>said</trigger>.'It's all right'."This seemed to go on every night, where he cried and he relived the whole explosion. It was a very sad time."Some reports at the time suggested the bar was frequented by political activists, that the bomb belonged to an IRA team in transit and was a republican'own-goal'. But this was rubbished as"ridiculous"by local residents. Pat said:"You were saying to yourself:'<role id='role-8-Killer'trigno='8'>Who</role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>killed</trigger> my <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>mummy</role>? Why did my own <role id='role-9-Killer'trigno='9'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>kill</trigger> my <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>mummy</role>?"At the back of your mind you knew it wasn't our own people that had done it."This was a family-run bar and it was people like my mummy and daddy that went to talk with each other and just pass the time of day for a pint or an orange and then come home again."Seven years after the bomb, a UVF <role id='role-10-Defendant'trigno='10'>man</role> received 15 life <trigger id='trigger-10'>sentences</trigger> after he was convicted of the bombing. On Tuesday night a number of events are being held to mark the 30th anniverary of the atrocity. 1900 GMT Mass at St Patrick's Chapel, Donegall Street. Fifteen wreaths will be placed on the altar to remember dead. Candlelit procession for peace from St Patrick's to corner of Great George's Street for blessing of monument Photographic exhibition at the local recreational centre, covering media reports of the event.
