text: Boston Bombing <role id='role-0-Attacker'trigno='0'>Suspects</role> Planned July 4 <trigger id='trigger-0'>Attack</trigger> Boston law enforcement officials say <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'>Boston</role> Marathon <trigger id='trigger-1'>bombing</trigger> suspect <role id='role-1-Attacker'trigno='1'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role> told the U. S. Federal Bureau of Investigation that he and his brother <role id='role-2-Attacker'trigno='2'>Tamerlan</role> originally considered suicide bombings, and planning <trigger id='trigger-2'>attacks</trigger> on July 4-the United States'Independence Day. Officials say Dzhokhar told them the <role id='role-8-Attacker'trigno='8'>brothers</role> moved up their <trigger id='trigger-8'>attack</trigger> plans because they finished building their homemade <role id='role-8-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='8'>bombs</role> sooner than expected. Both April 15 and July 4 are the dates of large patriotic celebrations in the city of Boston. The New York Times reported that the suspect also told authorities that he and his brother viewed online videos of the sermons of radical American cleric <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>Anwar al-Awlaki</role>, who was <trigger id='trigger-3'>killed</trigger> in September 2011 by a U. S. drone strike. There was no indication that the brothers communicated directly with Awlaki. On Thursday, Boston officials said a funeral home picked up the body of Tamerlan Tsarnaev on behalf of his family. There were no details on where the body was taken or <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>his</role> exact cause of <trigger id='trigger-4'>death</trigger>. <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>Tamerlan</role> was <trigger id='trigger-5'>killed</trigger> in a <role id='role-5-Killer'trigno='5'>police</role> shootout three days after he and <role id='role-9-Attacker'trigno='9'>his younger brother</role> allegedly <trigger id='trigger-9'>set off</trigger> two <role id='role-9-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='9'>bombs</role> at the <role id='role-9-Target'trigno='9'>Boston</role> Marathon finish line. The blasts <trigger id='trigger-6'>killed</trigger> <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>three</role> and <trigger id='trigger-11'>wounded</trigger> <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>264</role>. <role id='role-10-Detainee'trigno='10'>Dzhokhar</role> was <trigger id='trigger-10'>captured</trigger> and is in a prison hospital. Kazakhstan says it is cooperating with U. S. authorities after two Kazakh nationals were arrested for allegedly obstructing the bombing investigation. The Foreign Ministry statement says Kazakhstan condemns any form of terrorism. U. S. federal <role id='role-7-Jailer'trigno='7'>agents</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>arrested</trigger> the two Kazakhs and an <role id='role-7-Detainee'trigno='7'>American</role> for allegedly helping Dzhokhar Tsarnaev destroy evidence. They are not <trigger id='trigger-12'>accused</trigger> of direct involvement in the bombing itself. The three attended a university with Dzhokhar. Some information for this report was provided by AP and AFP.

text: (CNN) A federal appeals <role id='role-0-JudgeCourt'trigno='0'>court</role> ruled on Friday to vacate the death <trigger id='trigger-0'>sentence</trigger> of <role id='role-3-Injurer'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Killer'trigno='2'><role id='role-1-Attacker'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role></role></role></role>, who along with his brother <trigger id='trigger-1'>planted</trigger> homemade <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>bombs</role> near the finish of the 2013 Boston Marathon, <trigger id='trigger-2'>killing</trigger> three <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>spectators</role> and <trigger id='trigger-3'>injuring</trigger> <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>hundreds</role>. The <role id='role-4-JudgeCourt'trigno='4'>court</role> also ruled to set aside three of his 30 <trigger id='trigger-4'>convictions</trigger> but said he will remain in federal prison for the rest of his life. The court ruled Tsarnaev should be given a new penalty phase trial, where a new set of jurors can again decide if <role id='role-5-Defendant'trigno='5'>he</role> should be <trigger id='trigger-5'>sentenced</trigger> to death. Tsarnaev, now 27, will remain incarcerated and is being held at the nation's most secure federal prison in Florence, Colorado."And just to be crystal clear: Because we are affirming the <trigger id='trigger-6'>convictions</trigger> (excluding the three. . . convictions) and the many life <trigger id='trigger-7'>sentences</trigger> imposed on those remaining counts (which Dzhokhar has not challenged), Dzhokhar will remain confined to prison for the rest of his life, with the only question remaining being whether the government will end his life by executing him,"the opinion, authored by Circuit Court Judge <role id='role-20-Communicator'trigno='20'>Ojetta Rogeriee Thompson</role>, <trigger id='trigger-20'>says</trigger>. <role id='role-8-Defendant'trigno='8'>Tsarnaev</role> was <trigger id='trigger-8'>convicted</trigger> in 2015, including for the <trigger id='trigger-9'>deaths</trigger> of Krystle Campbell Lingzi Lu at the marathon and police officer <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>Sean Collier</role>, separately. Around-the-clock coverage Tsarnaev's legal team had pushed to change the venue of the trial to a courthouse that wasn't so close to the site of the bombing, in the heart of a town so affected by the tragedy. The appeals court <role id='role-21-Communicator'trigno='21'>judges</role> agreed, <trigger id='trigger-21'>saying</trigger>,"One could not turn on the radio either without hearing something about these stunningly sad events."The appeals judges ruled that US District Court Judge George O'Toole, who oversaw Tsarnaev's trial,"fell short"of his promise to question jurors thoroughly enough to identify the degree to which they had been exposed to facts of the case through media coverage,"providing sufficient ground to vacate his death sentences."Part of the appeals <role id='role-26-JudgeCourt'trigno='26'>court</role>'s ruling was a decision to reverse three <trigger id='trigger-26'>convictions</trigger> for charges that <role id='role-26-Defendant'trigno='26'>Tsarnaev</role> was carrying a firearm in connection with his possession of a pressure cooker bomb. The ruling tells the district court to enter judgments of acquittal on those charges, put together a new jury and preside over a new trial that strictly focuses on what penalty Tsarnaev should receive for the counts that are eligible for the death penalty. Tsarnaev's attorneys had filed a post-trial motion for judgments of acquittal on these convictions that the district court judge denied. CNN has reached out to Tsarnaev's legal team for comment on the ruling. The ruling also states that the judges make no judgment about whether Boston is a"proper venue"for a sentencing retrial, and says it is a decision that should be left to the US District Court for Massachusetts, where the initial trial was held. The US Attorney's <role id='role-23-Communicator'trigno='23'>office</role> <trigger id='trigger-23'>said</trigger>:"We are currently reviewing the opinion and are declining further comment at this time."<role id='role-27-PassengerArtifact'trigno='27'>Tsarnaev</role> was 19 years old when he and his brother, Tamerlan, who was 26 years old at the time, <trigger id='trigger-27'>went</trigger> to Boston's <role id='role-27-Destination'trigno='27'>Boylston Street</role> shortly before 3 p. m. on April 15, 2013, to carry out their plot Surveillance video showed the <role id='role-28-Transporter'trigno='28'><role id='role-10-Attacker'trigno='10'>brothers</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-28'>carrying</trigger> the pressure cooker <role id='role-28-PassengerArtifact'trigno='28'><role id='role-10-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='10'>bombs</role></role> in backpacks and moving through the crowd near the marathon finish line in what federal prosecutors called a coordinated <trigger id='trigger-10'>attack</trigger>. Tamerlan set off the first bomb, a 6-quart pressure cooker that contained gunpowder, nails and BBs, prosecutors said. The bomb <trigger id='trigger-11'>killed</trigger> <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>Campbell</role>, a 29-year-old restaurant manager, and permanently <trigger id='trigger-12'>injured</trigger> several other <role id='role-12-Victim'trigno='12'>people</role> who lost their legs. The second pressure cooker <role id='role-25-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='25'>bomb</role>, carried in by <role id='role-25-Attacker'trigno='25'>Dzhokhar</role>, <trigger id='trigger-25'>went off</trigger> 12 seconds later and <trigger id='trigger-13'>killed</trigger> two people, Martin and <role id='role-13-Victim'trigno='13'>Lu</role>, a graduate student from China. The bombings sparked a manhunt for days that shut down the city and resulted in wall-to-wall coverage of the search. The <role id='role-24-Killer'trigno='24'>brothers</role>, while on the run, <trigger id='trigger-24'>killed</trigger> Massachusetts Institute of Technology police officer <role id='role-24-Victim'trigno='24'>Sean Collier</role>. After <role id='role-14-Perpetrator'trigno='14'>they</role> <trigger id='trigger-14'>stole</trigger> an SUV, the two were chased by police. <role id='role-15-Victim'trigno='15'>Tamerlan</role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>died</trigger> in an explosive firefight with <role id='role-15-Killer'trigno='15'>police</role> in nearby <role id='role-15-Place'trigno='15'>Watertown</role>. <role id='role-16-Detainee'trigno='16'>Dzhokhar</role> was <trigger id='trigger-16'>arrested</trigger> a day later. Victims, families to relive another trial The decision to order a new trial will be difficult for the families of victims, Boston Mayor Marty Walsh said after the decision came down on Friday."I think the concern that some families have had from the very beginning was that this day was going to come, where they would have to relive another trial, and you know they shouldn't have to relive another trial,"<role id='role-22-Communicator'trigno='22'>Walsh</role> <trigger id='trigger-22'>said</trigger>."The only thing that I'll say is a positive. . . this guy will never see the light of day again. He's going to live within those four walls. He got exactly what he deserved."Shortly after <role id='role-17-Defendant'trigno='17'>Tsarnaev</role> was found <trigger id='trigger-17'>guilty</trigger> on all counts, the parents of 8-year-old <role id='role-18-Victim'trigno='18'>Martin Richard</role>, who was <trigger id='trigger-18'>killed</trigger> in the bombing, publicly pleaded for prosecutors not to pursue the death <trigger id='trigger-19'>sentence</trigger> in the penalty phase of the trial."We hope our two remaining children do not have to grow up with the lingering, painful reminder of what the defendant took from them, which years of appeals would undoubtedly bring,"the parents wrote in a column in The Boston Globe."As long as the defendant is in the spotlight, we have no choice but to live a story told on his terms, not ours. The minute the defendant fades from our newspapers and TV screens is the minute we begin the process of rebuilding our lives and our family."CNN has <trigger id='trigger-29'>reached out</trigger> to the Richard <role id='role-29-Participant'trigno='29'><role id='role-29-Participant'trigno='29'>family</role></role> for comment on Friday's ruling.

text: ONE day in March an American drone circled above Pakistan's North Waziristan tribal area, zeroed in on a gathering of village men, some of whom were armed, and unleashed three missiles in quick succession. It turned out to be a meeting to settle a dispute over a chromite mine. Most of the <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>40</role> or so <trigger id='trigger-0'>killed</trigger> were civilians, according to accounts, though a dozen Taliban also <trigger id='trigger-1'>died</trigger> in the attack, including a local commander, <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>Sherabat Khan</role>. The Taliban nowadays often adjudicate quarrels in the tribal areas, a wild buffer zone that runs along Pakistan's border with Afghanistan. The attack illustrated two problems with the drone war in the tribal regions: the risk of civilian casualties, and Pakistan's ambiguous attitude towards America's use of drones. Pakistan's army chief, <role id='role-6-Communicator'trigno='6'>Ashfaq Kayani</role>, <trigger id='trigger-6'>called</trigger> the strike a “complete violation of human rights” . For Pakistan, the difficulty went beyond civilian casualties. Khan was a lieutenant of a notable warlord, Gul Bahadur. But Pakistan considers Mr Bahadur to be a “good Taliban” , ie, one who has agreed to fight only in Afghanistan, not on Pakistani soil. After the strike, he threatened to tear up the deal. Relations between the governments in Islamabad, Pakistan's capital, and Washington, DC, are deeply troubled by the issue of drones. Though it publicly denounces the drone strikes, Pakistan certainly does not want all of them stopped. Indeed, the co-operation of Pakistani intelligence is crucial to employing the drones. But the army wants the number of strikes reduced, concentrating on targets both countries can agree on. America has told Pakistan bluntly it must either flush the Taliban and other jihadists out of their safe havens in North Waziristan, or it will continue with what amounts to an assassination campaign there. Pakistan says it cannot launch a ground offensive in North Waziristan because its armed forces are already stretched. The drone attacks, a supposedly “secret” programme started by the CIA in 2004, have been ramped up over the past three years, with a record 118 strikes last year and 50 so far in 2011. The drones started under President Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler. There were just nine strikes from 2004 to the end of 2007. According to Pakistani officials, it was supposed to be a highly selective programme for eliminating terrorist leaders in the tribal areas, under an understanding that gave the Americans the use of at least one remote Pakistani air base for the drones. The drones also take off from Afghanistan, but are operated thousands of miles away by a “pilot” at a desk in America, watching a video feed from the aircraft. A successful hit is known in the CIA as a “bugsplat” . It is all horribly like a video game. The New America Foundation, a Washington think-tank, found that up to 2, 551 <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>people</role> have been <trigger id='trigger-5'>killed</trigger> in the strikes since 2004. Based on press reports, it estimates that 80% of them were militants, rising to a pretty astonishing 95% in 2010. In recent months, there has been a move away from <trigger id='trigger-2'>blowing up</trigger> <role id='role-2-Target'trigno='2'>compounds</role> to targeting vehicles, where militants can more easily be hit without <trigger id='trigger-3'>killing</trigger> <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>civilians</role>. Even for compounds, smaller missiles are used to try to limit the damage to the separate male living quarters. Perceptions on the ground, however, are often different. The foundation's own poll in the tribal areas last year found only 16% believe the drones accurately target militants. But many locals privately support the strikes against extremists who have overrun their homeland. Accepting the figure for the success rate in killing militants nevertheless means that fully 500 or so Pakistani <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>civilians</role> have been <trigger id='trigger-4'>killed</trigger> since 2004. Unlike, say, in the war in Afghanistan, there is no investigation of civilian casualties, and no compensation paid. Transparency and accountability are absent, and some question the legal basis of the attacks. The programme is a charade because the CIA never admits to it and Pakistan pretends that it does not co-operate. A legal action launched this month, initially in Pakistan, with the backing of Reprieve, a campaigning group, seeks the arrest of a former CIA lawyer, John Rizzo, who boasted in a magazine interview this year that he used to approve a monthly list of some 30 individuals to be targeted by the drones. Whatever the outcome of that case, a debate will grind on about whether the strikes are harming al-Qaeda and related groups, or spurring on Afghanistan's powerful insurgency. According to the New America Foundation, out of the 2, 600-odd deaths, 35 were recognised militant chiefs, or just 1. 3% of the total. Among the successes was the fearsome leader of the Pakistani Taliban, Baitullah Mehsud, who was the country's number one public enemy. Still, the vast majority of targets have been low-level fighters. All the while, the number of suicide attacks in Afghanistan, many launched from Pakistan, has soared over the past year or more.

text: Three American Service <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>Members</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>Killed</trigger> in <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Afghanistan</role></role> IED Roadside <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>Bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>Explosion</trigger> Three U. S. service <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>members</role> were <trigger id='trigger-2'>killed</trigger> Tuesday by a roadside bomb in Afghanistan, the U. S. <role id='role-13-Participant'trigno='13'><role id='role-13-Participant'trigno='13'>military</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-13'>said</trigger>. Three other service <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>members</role> were <trigger id='trigger-3'>wounded</trigger> by the <role id='role-3-Instrument'trigno='3'>improvised explosive device</role> (IED), <role id='role-4-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='4'>which</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>detonated</trigger> near the city of Ghazni in the <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>center</role> of the country, <trigger id='trigger-14'>reported</trigger> The <role id='role-14-Communicator'trigno='14'>Associated Press</role>. A U. S. <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>contractor</role> was also <trigger id='trigger-5'>wounded</trigger>. The identities of <role id='role-15-IdentifiedRole'trigno='15'><role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>those</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>killed</trigger> were not <trigger id='trigger-15'>revealed</trigger>, pending <trigger id='trigger-7'>communication</trigger> with their <role id='role-7-Participant'trigno='7'><role id='role-7-Participant'trigno='7'>families</role></role>. The <trigger id='trigger-8'>injured</trigger> service <role id='role-10-Patient'trigno='10'><role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>members</role></role> and <trigger id='trigger-9'>injured</trigger> <role id='role-9-Victim'trigno='9'>contractor</role> are receiving <trigger id='trigger-10'>treatment</trigger>, <trigger id='trigger-16'>reported</trigger> <role id='role-16-Communicator'trigno='16'>Reuters</role>. No other details of were provided. The <trigger id='trigger-11'>deaths</trigger> came days after Sergeant <role id='role-12-Victim'trigno='12'>Leandro Jasso</role> of the elite 75th Ranger Regiment was <trigger id='trigger-12'>killed</trigger> in an exchange of gunfire with al Qaeda militants in Nimruz Province.

text: VERY FEW of those who were around in Belfast on Bloody Friday even after a lapse of 30 years, can forget the scenes they witnessed then-and fewer still can want to remember. This was terror in the raw unleashed on a still unhardened population. As the <role id='role-0-Instrument'trigno='0'>bombs</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>went off</trigger> in sequence, now in one part of the city, now in another, rumour took over, naked fear and anxiety. Warnings were given, perhaps deliberately erroneous, maybe not, maybe hoax calls, perhaps not but the effect was the same. Groups of office and shop workers ordered to evacuate threatened premises, gathered at street corners only to run in shrieking droves as a bomb went off nearer the place in which they had sought refuge. The smell of fear exceeded only by the whiff of powder, enveloping smoke, the jangle of ambulances and fire engines and screaming police cars, and office alarms crying heedlessly to the air, the smell of smoke and dust, sound of shattering glass, the cries of fear and horror, the stench of burning timber, burning rubber, burning metal, burning flesh. And most of all the horror of Oxford Street Bus Station where commuter deaths brought the savagery of the city to surrounding towns and villages as people waited for those who had gone to work or to shop to return. Nine did not and many others returned home broken and injured and not only physically. The final horror of the television news reels of body parts being shovelled into polythene bags by those whose insufficiently recognised task it was to clear up the carnage. If it has taken the Provisional IRA 30 years to face up to the enormity of what they did on that day and on many other days, and to apologise for the hurt caused, it has not come a day too soon. Or indeed too late either, in what we are now seeing the beginning of a real effort to promote the process of healing, to bind up the wounds and to enable the community to face the future together. Acceptance of responsibility is always a good starting point. Regrets for hurts done is the next stage. Forgiveness for wounds received perhaps the next, and acceptance that no side has a monoply of victimhood, or virtue or validity is perhaps the closure. The IRA statement starts as an apology for the hurts inflicted on innocent victims on a particular occasion. These will not be additionally reassured by being classified as non-competence, but it goes much further than that. Bloody Friday is as good a symbol as any of the universality of suffering at the futility of violence. There are those who will carp at the exclusion of those implicitly typified as combatants-presumably policemen, soldiers and prison officers and others unfortunate enough to be designated as legitimate targets. Many of these too, even allowing the doubtful premise of legitimacy were shot down in ambush, in cold blood in the domestic situation, but so, republicans will argue were many of their victims too. The statement does go on to recognise the hurt of all victims, combatant and non-combatant, and it would be ungenerous not to recognise the impulse for reconciliation which lies behind these words-or the effort that has been required to bring it about. Thirty years ago even innocent victims were dismissed as the unfortunate casualties of war, in the wrong place at the wrong time. Things have moved a long way when all can be seen as victims, when the hurts of all can be recognised. When the IRA first announce a ceasefire, they were castigated for not including some phrase of regret, some words of apology. This was further highlighted when some weeks later Gusty Spence announced the loyalist ceasefire in terms which included an apology for hurts inflicted which was quite moving at the time. Subsequent loyalist activity has not eradicated the value of that statement in that context. Neither should current disturbances or uncertainties be used to denigrate the IRA statement. Some elements of unionism will remain implacable no matter what republicans say or do. Others will demand additional deeds rather than words. Others still will argue a lack of moral equivalency, that illegality can never be legitimised or terrorism condoned. The important thing now is how that statement and the sentiments behind it, which should be recognised as genuine and not merely a rhetorical or political ploy are accepted by those who have been on the receiving end by the relatives of victims and survivors, many of whom have been horribly mutilated. In general, such people have proved to be much more willing to forgive than those who have suffered by proxy. Those who experienced Bloody Friday in Belfast may welcome the statement more than those who viewed it from afar. In any case, to recall the events shows how far society has moved on towards peace since then. For the long suffering populace of Northern Ireland, like the mothers in O'Casey's play"on either side of a scales of sorrow, weighed down by the bodies of our suffering sons", this is a significant and a very welcome statement.

text: 2 New <role id='role-11-Attacker'trigno='11'>Suspects</role> Sought in <role id='role-11-Target'trigno='11'>Bangkok</role> <trigger id='trigger-11'>Bombing</trigger> BANGKOK — Thai authorities investigating this month’s deadly <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Bangkok</role> <role id='role-0-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='0'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>attack</trigger> on Monday announced finding more bomb-making materials in a raid on an apartment in the capital and <trigger id='trigger-1'>arrest</trigger> warrants for two new suspects–a 26-year-old Thai woman and a foreign <role id='role-1-Jailer'trigno='1'>man</role>. A photograph of the woman, identified as Wanna Suansan, in a hijab and a sketch of the unnamed male suspect were shown on a special broadcast on all Thai television channels at noon. The disclosure came after police raided an apartment building Sunday, initially telling reporters nothing suspicious had been found. But on the Monday broadcast, national police Lt. General Prawut Thavornsiri said fertilizer, explosives detonators and digital watches were seized during Sunday's search of multiple units in an apartment complex in the Min Buri district of Bangkok. Police claim reward Police on Monday also announced that a 3 million baht (about $83, 000) reward offered to the public for information leading to the <trigger id='trigger-2'>arrest</trigger> of the bombing <role id='role-2-Jailer'trigno='2'>suspects</role> would instead be paid to the police, after a 28-year-old foreign man was apprehended in a Saturday raid. The <role id='role-3-Defendant'trigno='3'>suspect</role> faces <trigger id='trigger-3'>charges</trigger> of possessing explosives. “This was the work of the Thai officials, there were no tip-offs,” the national police chief, General Somyot Pumpanmuang, told reporters as he displayed bundles of the reward cash he said was from his personal funds and a donation from an anonymous businessman friend of his. Officials said they found explosives, chemicals, ball bearings and other elements to make pipe bombs in a unit on the eastern outskirts of Bangkok where they apprehended the foreigner. FILE-Thai police stand on the balcony outside of an apartment building in Nong Jok on the outskirts of Bangkok, Aug. 29, 2015. Thai police say <role id='role-4-Jailer'trigno='4'>they</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>arrested</trigger> a <role id='role-4-Detainee'trigno='4'>suspect</role> in the blast at the Erawan Shrine in this apartment building. The components were said to be similar to those used in <role id='role-5-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='5'>devices</role> that <trigger id='trigger-5'>detonated</trigger> at the <role id='role-5-Target'trigno='5'>Erawan Shrine</role> on August 17 and in the <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>Chao Phraya River</role>, adjacent to the Sathorn Pier, the following day. The <trigger id='trigger-7'>blast</trigger> at the Hindu <role id='role-7-Target'trigno='7'>shrine</role>, popular with Chinese and other Asian tourists, <trigger id='trigger-6'>killed</trigger> 20 <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>people</role> and <trigger id='trigger-13'>wounded</trigger> more than 100 <role id='role-13-Victim'trigno='13'>others</role>–the worst single mass casualty <trigger id='trigger-12'>attack</trigger> in <role id='role-12-Place'trigno='12'>Thailand</role>. The subsequent explosion at the pier caused no <trigger id='trigger-14'>injuries</trigger>. Uighur deportation It is unclear whether the shrine bombing has any connection to Thailand’s deportation in July of more than 100 ethnic Uighurs to China, army commander-in-chief General Udomdej Sitabutr said Monday. Thai authorities have been hesitant to link the attack to international terrorism. Instead, authorities have insisted since Saturday that it is likely connected to a human <trigger id='trigger-8'>smuggling</trigger> organized crime <role id='role-9-Perpetrator'trigno='9'>ring</role> or a <role id='role-8-Perpetrator'trigno='8'>gang</role> bent on <trigger id='trigger-9'>revenge</trigger> for crackdowns by police. Analysts have given those explanations little credence and human rights groups have expressed concern about how the lack of legitimate political, security and judicial authority in a country under military government could undermine public trust in the investigation’s outcome. The head of the Thai military junta, Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha, has cautioned against concluding that the <role id='role-10-Target'trigno='10'>shrine</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>bombing</trigger> was linked to international terrorism or mentioning any possible connection to Turkey. Thai police Lieutenant General Prawut Thavornsiri speaks to the media at the Royal Thai Police headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, Aug. 30, 2015. In recent days speculation had increased about the <trigger id='trigger-15'>bombing’s</trigger> possible link to China's ethnic Uighur minority or their co-religious sympathizers in Turkey. Thailand's deportation of the Uighurs led to an attack on the Thai consulate in Istanbul where windows were smashed. The Turkish Embassy in Bangkok denied that the arrested suspect is a citizen of Turkey, Lt. General Prawut told reporters on Sunday. Authorities also made conflicting statements Saturday and Sunday on whether they believed the man was the suspect caught on closed circuit television images leaving a package at the popular Hindu shrine in central Bangkok just prior to the explosion. Criticized The junta also came under criticism after airing a photograph of a suicide vest while its officials discussed evidence found on Saturday they said was related to the bombings. It was quickly pointed out that the picture of the vest had come from a 2013 blog online of the U. S. Transportation Security Administration. That disclosure prompted Thai authorities to acknowledge the photograph had no connection to their case and they demanded the media and public refrain from further disseminating the picture.

text: The impact <trigger id='trigger-0'>shattered</trigger> <role id='role-0-Artifact'trigno='0'>windows</role>, <trigger id='trigger-1'>damaged</trigger> <role id='role-1-Artifact'trigno='1'>cars</role> and sent <role id='role-5-PassengerArtifact'trigno='5'>crowds</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>running</trigger> from the <role id='role-5-Origin'trigno='5'>scene</role> at an hour when Chelsea, always a popular destination, was filled with residents and tourists. “It was the biggest blast I ever would imagine, lights flashing, glass shattering,” said a <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>woman</role> who was <trigger id='trigger-6'>injured</trigger> in the explosion. The force of the explosion, she said, flung her into the air. “It happened so fast I was thrown up and landed down, I didn’t know where it had come from,” said the woman, who would give only her first name, Helena, as she hobbled out of <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>Bellevue Hospital Center</role> about 4 a. m. after <role id='role-3-Patient'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>she</role></role> was <trigger id='trigger-3'>treated</trigger> for <trigger id='trigger-2'>injuries</trigger> to her <role id='role-2-BodyPart'trigno='2'>eye</role> and legs. “I realized there was blood streaming down my face, and I couldn’t see out of my eye.” Luke McConnell, who was visiting from Colorado, was headed toward a restaurant on West 27th Street when the blast <trigger id='trigger-7'>occurred</trigger>. “I felt it, like a concussive wave, heading towards me.” “Then there was a cloud of white smoke that came from the left side of 23rd Street near Sixth,” he said. “There was no fire, just smoke.” Witnesses said they could feel the explosion from several blocks away. <role id='role-8-Participant'trigno='8'><role id='role-8-Participant'trigno='8'>Daniel Yount</role></role>, 34, <trigger id='trigger-8'>said</trigger> he was standing on the roof of a building at 25th Street and the Avenue of the Americas with friends. “We felt the shock waves go through our bodies,” <role id='role-9-Participant'trigno='9'><role id='role-9-Participant'trigno='9'>he</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>said</trigger>. It was a startling scene, full of dark possibilities, for a city that endured the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, but has so far been spared the kind of mayhem that has terrorized city after city around the world in the 15 years since. The closest <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>New York</role> has come to an <trigger id='trigger-4'>attack</trigger> was in 2010, when the police found a crude <role id='role-4-Instrument'trigno='4'>car bomb</role> of propane, gasoline and fireworks inside a sport utility vehicle in <role id='role-4-Target'trigno='4'>Times Square</role>. Although the device had apparently started to detonate, there was no explosion. On Saturday night in Chelsea, the device found on West 27th Street also caused no harm. Images shared on social media and confirmed as authentic by a senior police official showed a silver-colored piece of cookware with wires and a cellphone attached. The official said the Police Department’s bomb squad was taking the device to a department facility in the Bronx, where robots would <trigger id='trigger-10'>inspect</trigger> <role id='role-10-ObservedEntity'trigno='10'>it</role>.

text: <role id='role-0-ManufacturerAssembler'trigno='0'>ISIS</role> Is Reportedly <trigger id='trigger-0'>Packing</trigger> <role id='role-0-Artifact'trigno='0'>Drones</role> With <role id='role-0-Components'trigno='0'>Explosives</role> Now An unconfirmed report from Syria suggests that ISIS has started using small drones packed with explosives as weapons. The first attack was a failure, but if the report is accurate, then it signals a dangerous new terror threat. The report showed pictures of the remains of a homemade attack drone. <role id='role-2-Artifact'trigno='2'>It</role> was apparently <trigger id='trigger-2'>shot down</trigger>, along with a second <role id='role-3-Artifact'trigno='3'>drone</role> that <trigger id='trigger-3'>exploded</trigger>, by Kurdish YPF ("People's Defence Units") fighters in Syria. The caption says that both drones carried explosives, and that no YPF fighters were injured in the incident. Unlike many jihadi groups, ISIS has proven itself tech-savvy — the organization is known for its use of social media, for instance. This latest development is not surprising, as it follows a long history of drone usage. In late 2014, during the battle for Kobane, ISIS started using footage taken from dronesin their propaganda videos. Around the same time, ISIS started using quadrotors for battlefield reconnaissance. A number of them, mainly DJI quadrotors, were reportedly shot down or captured by Kurdish fighters, according to a news report from December 2014. These drones were apparently used as artillery spotters, finding targets and correcting the fall or fire for mortar crews. By early this year, ISIS drones had become important enough to be targeted by U. S. airstrikes. A CENTCOM report in March mentions that"Near Fallujah, an airstrike <trigger id='trigger-1'>destroyed</trigger> an ISIL remotely piloted aircraft and an ISIL <role id='role-1-Artifact'trigno='1'>vehicle</role>.""We observed it flying for approximately 20 minutes. We observed it land. We observed the enemy place it in the trunk of a car and <role id='role-4-Attacker'trigno='4'>we</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>struck</trigger> <role id='role-4-Target'trigno='4'>the car</role>,"according to Pentagon spokesman Colonel Steve Warren. Warren described the drone as"a model airplane"and"commercially available, remotely piloted aircraft, really something anyone can get."Another ISIS drone ("remotely piloted vehicle") was <trigger id='trigger-5'>destroyed</trigger> in an airstrike in June, and a <role id='role-5-Artifact'trigno='5'>third</role> in August. Friends of YPG YPJ In fact, ISIS tactical drones seem to be appearing all over this year. In September the Levant Front (or Jabhat al-Shamiyya) released pictures of a camera-carrying Talon <role id='role-6-Artifact'trigno='6'>drone</role> they <trigger id='trigger-6'>brought down</trigger>, which they say was flown by ISIS. The X-UAV Talon is available in kit form for about $100; <role id='role-7-Artifact'trigno='7'>it</role> is <trigger id='trigger-7'>made</trigger> of <role id='role-7-Components'trigno='7'>plywood</role> with a six-foot wingspan and has a large fuselage compartment for cameras or other payloads. In October, Iraqi <role id='role-8-Destroyer'trigno='8'>police</role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>shot down</trigger> a fixed-wing ISIS <role id='role-8-Artifact'trigno='8'>drone</role> near Ramadi. Again it was of the small, hand-launched variety, though a different model, and the Iraqis say it was photographing military units. Even al-Qaeda has released pictures and video of what is claims was a <trigger id='trigger-9'>downed</trigger> ISIS <role id='role-9-Artifact'trigno='9'>drone</role>. This flurry of drone activity is a reflection of just how easy it has become to acquire and fly drones. Just as home computers were once confined to dedicated hobbyists but found a wider market, drones have broken into the mainstream with models that require no piloting or technical skills to fly. This gives ISIS access to aerial reconnaissance that would otherwise be impossible in the face of the air superiority of Syrian, Russian, and Western forces. The pictures of the ISIS attack drone were posted by a user called"Catelyn Carrigan"on the Facebook page of the group"Friends of the YPG YPJ"with the headline"<role id='role-10-Destroyer'trigno='10'>YPG</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>Shoots Down</trigger> 2 ISIS <role id='role-10-Artifact'trigno='10'>Drones</role>."The location of the new pictures is given as"Southern Kobanê, Qracoezag province near the bridge."We received no response to queries for more information on the pictures. This would not be the first terrorist <role id='role-11-Instrument'trigno='11'>drone</role> <trigger id='trigger-11'>strike</trigger>. Hamas and Hezbollah, for example, both have used fixed-wing kamikaze drones with explosive warheads, but those were larger, modified versions of military Mirsad and Ababbil drones supplied by Iran. The ISIS <role id='role-12-Artifact'trigno='12'>drones</role> do not rely on imported military technology, but can be <trigger id='trigger-12'>assembled</trigger> in a <role id='role-12-Place'trigno='12'>garage</role>, for cheap. Some eagled-eyed redditors believe the drone in question today is the Skwalker X7 or X8, which costs $179 for the kit. As we've recently noted, small drones make effective battlefield weapons. The Switchblade by American company AeroVironment and the Israeli Hero-30 have both proven lethal, giving a foot soldier the power to launch his own airstrike to locate and hit a target from several miles away from behind cover. These military drones boast jam-proof communications, sophisticated terminal guidance, and advanced warheads. But even a crude, home-made version might be deadly in a terrorist attack against a soft target. During the recent terror <trigger id='trigger-13'>attacks</trigger> in <role id='role-13-Place'trigno='13'>Paris</role>, <role id='role-13-Attacker'trigno='13'>the attackers</role> were unable to gain access to the Stade de France, which was packed with fans for a soccer game. But drones cannot be stopped by walls or fences. While they can only carry a small amount of explosive compared to a suicide bomber, they can be deployed in significant numbers, and they can be directed with great accuracy against vulnerable targets. Of course, security forces are already looking at how to mitigate the threat from small drones, and various defensive measures are already in place, from nets to electronic detectors and jammers. Commercial drones can be stopped easily enough by jamming their control frequencies, or even hacking them to take over the drone, but purpose-built attack drones will be much harder to combat. Small drones can be built for a few thousand dollars in any home workshop. 3D printed drones are no longer a novelty, and how-to guides can be shared easily over the internet. It is far too late to stop this technology from proliferating. ISIS first drone attack may have failed, but it is not likely to be the last. It may be time to get serious about defending against small drones. David Hambling's new book Swarm Troopers: How small drones will conquer the world is out this month.

text: On 28 July 2019, a suicide car <role id='role-0-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='0'>bombing</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>occurred</trigger> in the Kabul <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>office</role> of the Vice Presidential candidate Amrullah Saleh, <trigger id='trigger-1'>killing</trigger> over <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>20</role> and <trigger id='trigger-2'>injuring</trigger> over <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>50</role> including slightly <trigger id='trigger-3'>wounding</trigger> <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>Saleh</role>. Four <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>gunmen</role> then stormed the building and laid siege for hours before being <trigger id='trigger-4'>killed</trigger>. == Casualties == Twenty <role id='role-5-Victim'trigno='5'>people</role> were <trigger id='trigger-5'>killed</trigger>, and 50 <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>others</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>wounded</trigger>, including <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>Amrullah Saleh</role> who was slightly <trigger id='trigger-7'>injured</trigger> in the blast. == Responsibility of the attack == There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack but ISIL and the Taliban both frequently carry out attacks in this region. == See also == * 1 July 2019 Kabul attack == References ==

text: Suspected New York <role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>Bomber</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>Wounded</trigger> in <trigger id='trigger-1'>Shootout</trigger> with <role id='role-1-Attacker'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Injurer'trigno='0'>Police</role></role> The <role id='role-5-Target'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'><role id='role-3-Injurer'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Attacker'trigno='2'>suspect</role></role></role></role> in Saturday night's <trigger id='trigger-2'>bombing</trigger> in <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>New York City</role> that <trigger id='trigger-3'>wounded</trigger> 29 <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>people</role> is in a hospital recovering from <role id='role-5-Instrument'trigno='5'>bullet</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>wounds</trigger> after a <trigger id='trigger-5'>shootout</trigger> with <role id='role-5-Attacker'trigno='5'>police</role>. <role id='role-6-Prosecutor'trigno='6'>Prosecutors</role> have <trigger id='trigger-6'>charged</trigger> 28-year-old <role id='role-8-Injurer'trigno='8'><role id='role-7-Attacker'trigno='7'><role id='role-6-Defendant'trigno='6'>Ahmad Khan Rahami</role></role></role> with five counts of attempted murder stemming from the <trigger id='trigger-7'>shootout</trigger> that <trigger id='trigger-8'>wounded</trigger> two <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'><role id='role-7-Target'trigno='7'>officers</role></role>. <role id='role-9-Jailer'trigno='9'>Police</role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>arrested</trigger> <role id='role-9-Detainee'trigno='9'>Rahami</role> in <role id='role-9-Place'trigno='9'>Linden</role>, New Jersey — outside Manhattan — hours after police sent out a city-wide bulletin with his picture, saying he was wanted for questioning. A bar owner in Linden called police Monday morning to complain that a man was sleeping in a doorway of his business. <role id='role-10-Identifier'trigno='10'>Officers</role> <trigger id='trigger-10'>recognized</trigger> the <role id='role-10-IdentifiedObject'trigno='10'>man</role> as <role id='role-20-Attacker'trigno='20'><role id='role-11-Injurer'trigno='11'><role id='role-10-IdentifiedRole'trigno='10'>Rahami</role></role></role>, who <trigger id='trigger-20'>opened fire</trigger>, <trigger id='trigger-11'>wounding</trigger> two <role id='role-11-Victim'trigno='11'>policemen</role> before he was injured. None of the wounds are considered life-threatening. Police <role id='role-12-Jailer'trigno='12'>officers</role> walk near the site where <role id='role-12-Detainee'trigno='12'>Ahmad Khan Rahami</role>, sought in connection with a bombing in New York, was <trigger id='trigger-12'>taken into custody</trigger> in <role id='role-12-Place'trigno='12'>Linden</role>, New Jersey, U. S. , Sept. 19, 2016. The FBI is not saying how they zeroed in on Rahami as the bombing suspect. But <role id='role-13-Identifier'trigno='13'>investigators</role> reportedly <trigger id='trigger-13'>saw</trigger> <role id='role-13-IdentifiedObject'trigno='13'>him</role> on surveillance video at the bomb site in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood, and near a second bomb allegedly left several blocks away. The second explosive was found before it could detonate. Investigators also reportedly found fingerprints on a bomb fragment. Video size width x height pixels Following Terror Suspect Capture, New York Remains Vigilant Share this video 0: 02: 12 ▶ 0: 00: 00 / 0: 02: 12 ▶ ▶ Direct link 270p | 6. 3MB 360p | 9. 9MB 720p | 56. 3MB Other bombs The FBI wants to question Rahami about another bombing Saturday morning in Seaside Park, New Jersey, south of New York, that forced the cancellation of a charity road race. No one was injured. Other <role id='role-14-IdentifiedObject'trigno='14'>bombs</role> were <trigger id='trigger-14'>found</trigger> in a garbage can at a train <role id='role-14-Place'trigno='14'>station</role> Sunday morning in Elizabeth, New Jersey. <role id='role-15-Instrument'trigno='15'>One</role> of the <role id='role-16-Artifact'trigno='16'>bombs</role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>exploded</trigger> while a <role id='role-16-Instrument'trigno='16'>robot</role> was trying to <trigger id='trigger-16'>disarm</trigger> it. Again, no one was hurt. FILE-Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) <role id='role-18-Observer'trigno='18'>officials</role> label and <trigger id='trigger-18'>collect evidence</trigger> near the <role id='role-18-Place'trigno='18'>site</role> of an <trigger id='trigger-17'>explosion</trigger> which took place on Saturday night in the <role id='role-17-Place'trigno='17'>Chelsea</role> neighborhood of Manhattan, New York, Sept. 18, 2016. <role id='role-21-Defendant'trigno='21'>Rahami</role>'s <trigger id='trigger-21'>alleged</trigger> motive for the bombings is unknown. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said Rahami is the only suspect so far. The mayor on Monday said there is every reason to believe the bombings were acts of terrorism, and the FBI is looking for any links to foreign terror groups. Obama: We have to be vigilant Speaking in New York, President Barack Obama said the <trigger id='trigger-19'>investigation</trigger> is moving rapidly and that everyone is working together to get to the bottom of what happened. He said terrorists and extremists want to <trigger id='trigger-22'>hurt</trigger> innocent <role id='role-22-Victim'trigno='22'>people</role>, inspire fear and disrupt life. President Barack Obama speaks about last Saturday's bombing in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood in New York, Sept. 19, 2016."We have to be vigilant and aggressive, both on preventing senseless acts of violence but also making sure that we find those who carry out such acts and bring them to justice,” he said. “We all have a role to play as citizens in making sure that we don't succumb to that fear."One New Yorker told VOA that the bombing was unsettling, but not surprising."There is a security to this city. Sure there are days where I have my doubts about that, but because I do feel this camaraderie in the city, I do feel relatively safe."Suspect called friendly Suspected bomber Rahami was born in Afghanistan and is a naturalized U. S. citizen. He and his family run a fried-chicken restaurant in Linden that has a steady number of loyal customers. But it also had trouble with the city of Linden for what neighbors said was round-the-clock noise and crowds at the eatery. Some of the restaurant's customers say they are shocked that Rahami is a suspect, calling him friendly. They say he let local bands practice in the back of the restaurant, and gave them free food. New York City Afghan community leader Masjid Dar al Taqwa condemned the bombings."Everyone. . . is shocked and saddened by what has happened,"he told VOA."They condemn all forms of violence. They just want to live peacefully."

text: Afghanistan: Roadside <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>IED</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>blast</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-0'>kills</trigger> multiple <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>civilians</role> in <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'><role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Ghazni province</role></role> August 23 Roadside <role id='role-2-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='2'>IED</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>blast</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-3'>kills</trigger> at least seven <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>civilians</role> in <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>Ghazni province</role></role> on August 23; similar attacks likely Event On Sunday, August 23, at least seven <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>civilians</role> were <trigger id='trigger-4'>killed</trigger> after an improvised explosive <role id='role-6-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='6'>device</role> (IED) <trigger id='trigger-6'>detonated</trigger> in central <role id='role-6-Place'trigno='6'><role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>Ghazni province</role></role>. According to media sources, a civilian vehicle <trigger id='trigger-5'>struck</trigger> the roadside <role id='role-5-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='5'>device</role> at around 10: 00 (local time) on Sunday morning in the <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>Jaghatu district</role>. No group has claimed immediate responsibility for the blast. Similar attacks targeting civilians and security forces are likely across the country. Advice Those in Ghazni province are advised to monitor developments in their own particular area of operations through a range of multi-source intelligence advisories and should heed all instructions issued by local authorities or their home governments. The security environment in Afghanistan remains complex. Professional security advice and support should be sought prior to travel.

text: May 24, 1988: Timothy McVeigh, Terry Nichols and Michael Fortier enlist in the U. S. Army. April 1991: McVeigh drops out of eligibility test for Army Special Forces. Dec. 31, 1991: McVeigh receives honorable discharge. October 1994: McVeigh uses soup <role id='role-0-Components'trigno='0'>cans</role> to show how <role id='role-0-ManufacturerAssembler'trigno='0'>he</role> would <trigger id='trigger-0'>arrange</trigger> explosives in a V shape inside a truck for maximum destruction. April 17, 1995: <role id='role-1-Recipient'trigno='1'>McVeigh</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>rents</trigger> a <role id='role-1-AcquiredEntity'trigno='1'>Ryder truck</role> in Junction City, Kansas. April 18, 1995: <role id='role-2-ManufacturerAssembler'trigno='2'>McVeigh</role> and Nichols <trigger id='trigger-2'>mix</trigger> the fertilizer and fuel oil <role id='role-2-Components'trigno='2'>bomb</role> at <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>Geary Lake</role>, near Junction City. April 19, 1995: At 9: 02 a. m. , a 4, 000-pound truck <role id='role-3-Instrument'trigno='3'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-3'>destroys</trigger> the nine-story <role id='role-3-Artifact'trigno='3'>Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building</role> in downtown <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>Oklahoma City</role>, killing 168 people, including 19 children, and <trigger id='trigger-4'>injuring</trigger> <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>850</role>. The blast <trigger id='trigger-5'>damages</trigger> 312 <role id='role-5-Artifact'trigno='5'>buildings</role>, 14 of which had to be <trigger id='trigger-7'>demolished</trigger>. • At about 10: 20 a. m. , Oklahoma Highway Patrol Trooper Charlie Hanger stops McVeigh on Interstate 35 near Billings for driving with no tag on his yellow 1977 Mercury, and <role id='role-6-Detainee'trigno='6'>McVeigh</role> is <trigger id='trigger-6'>jailed</trigger> for carrying a concealed weapon.

text: Stephen Parker Award Origins and History of the Stephen Parker Memorial Trust Stephen Parker was a student of the City of Belfast School of Music who played French Horn in the City of Belfast Youth Orchestra under the direction of Mr Leonard Pugh. Stephen was fourteen and a half years old when he bacame a victim of what has come to be known in the history of Northern Ireland as the Bloody Friday outrage on July 21st, 1972. <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>He</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>died</trigger> as he endeavoured to warn others of the presence of an unexploded car bomb. An innocent victim of a terrorist outrage in a purely residential area of the City. The Stephen Parker Memorial Trust was born out of this tragic situation. Knowing how much Stephen appreciated his place in the CBYO, his parents decided that his memorial had to be capable of contributing in the long term towards"the life and welfare of his beloved orchestra."A substantial sum of money donated at the time of Stephen's death was invested and has been further added to over the years. Each year 75% of the annual income of this investment is awarded as a prize to"the member or members of the City of Belfast Youth Orchestra who make the best all round progress during the year."Students are then free to use this award to further their musical study through assisting with lessons or masterclasses or contributing towards the purchase of equipment. The residual amount is reinvested to maintain the value of the prize. Stephen was a trier and his parents felt it appropriate that"evidence of having tried very hard"ought to be the major factor in deciding eligibility for his memorial prize. Each year the trustees of the memorial meet to decide upon a winner based on evidence provided by the Orchestra staff. The winner is announced and the recipient presented with the award during the Orchestra's Summer Concert. The Stephen Parker Memorial Trust is administered by the Belfast Education and Library Board. Anyone wishing to make a donation to the trust can do so care of: Mrs Rowena Eames Head of Music Services City of Belfast School of Music 99 Donegall Pass Belfast BT7 1DR This year's winner of the Stephen Parker Award Malachy Frame with conductor of CBYO, Paul McBrie Previous Winners 2011 Malachy Frame2010 Susanna Gawn2009 Emma King2008 David Douglas2007 Christopher Rooney2006 Charles Reilly2005 Sarah Brown2004 Michael Trainor2003 David McCann2002 Ciaran McCabe2001 Scott Foster2000 Jonathan Corry / Michael McHale1999 Jonathan Coffey1998 Peter Black1997 Roger McCann1996 Kate Openshaw1995 Natalie Thompson1994 Anne Harper1993 S Nesbitt1992 Robin Clinton1991 M C Lowry1990 A Carney1989 C Taylor1988 J Fleming1987 Ruth Montgomery1986 Nigel Ireland1985 Cheryl Agnew1984 Marianne Ho / Ruth Kilpatrick1983 Janet McMaster / Margaret Flanagan1982 David McMaster1981 Rosin McCrisken1980 Kathryn Clements / Jennifer McCreery1979 Eleanor Wilkinson1978 Pauline Fitzpartick1977 Paul McCrisken1976 Jeremy Adair1975 Hazel Mulligan / Dominic McHugh1974 Noleen Bell / John Anderson1973 Charles Wood

text: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) — A <role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>teenager</role> who <role id='role-0-Prosecutor'trigno='0'>authorities</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>accused</trigger> of trying to <trigger id='trigger-1'>blow up</trigger> a homemade backpack <role id='role-1-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='1'>bomb</role> at a southern <role id='role-1-Place'trigno='1'><role id='role-1-Target'trigno='1'>Utah high school</role></role> after watching Islamic State propaganda been sentenced to four years of probation. The Spectrum newspaper in St. George reports that that the 17-year-old <role id='role-2-Defendant'trigno='2'>boy</role> was <trigger id='trigger-2'>sentenced</trigger> in <role id='role-2-JudgeCourt'trigno='2'>adult court</role> Thursday. The boy's attorney, Edward Flint, said his <role id='role-3-Target'trigno='3'>client</role> snapped after being <trigger id='trigger-3'>bullied</trigger> at school. Judge G. Michael Westfall disagreed, saying the <role id='role-6-Killer'trigno='6'>boy</role>'s planning of the event was troubling. He says if the <role id='role-4-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='4'>bomb</role> would have <trigger id='trigger-4'>detonated</trigger>, it would have <trigger id='trigger-6'>killed</trigger> many <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>people</role>. The <role id='role-5-Detainee'trigno='5'>teenager</role> was <trigger id='trigger-5'>arrested</trigger> in March 2018 after the incident at Pine View High in St. George. He told police he wanted to cause fear in his community. The Associated Press is not naming the defendant because he is a minor. ___ Information from: The Spectrum, http: / / www. thespectrum. com

text: Nicolás Maduro warns of psychological warfare against Venezuela. M. GUTIÉRREZ / EFE Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has countered reports of an incipient epidemic in the country by accusing the opposition of engaging in underhand tactics. “They tried to impose a campaign of psychological warfare on Venezuela, a combination of alarmism and war,” said Maduro. “There is no other term for this but psychological warfare.” What’s more, the Bolivarian leader–who is the political heir of the deceased former president Hugo Chávez–went further and asked the World Health Organization to help investigate alleged attempts to introduce “some sort of virus” into the country as part of “biological warfare.” Patients at the Maracay Hospital are dying in the space of 72 hours due to massive hemorrhaging The latest cause for concern involves Maracay Hospital, located around two hours from Caracas, where it emerged last Thursday that some patients were displaying worrying symptoms. “We don’t know what it is we are facing,” said Angel Sarmiento, president of the Medical Association of Aragua, the state where the hospital is located. “We don’t know if it is a virus or a bacteria.” The physician added that patients were dying in the space of 72 hours due to a massive hemorrhage, and he recommended that people avoid going to that hospital. The government reacted to this statement by calling Sarmiento “a fascist” and “a terrorist.” The governor of Aragua, Tareck El Aissami, filed a complaint against him before the Attorney’s Office, claiming that there are no dangerous bacteria at the hospital and discrediting Sarmiento because he is a member of the opposition. But the Medical Federation of Venezuela has come out in support of Sarmiento. “How long will this routine go on? Every time someone tells this government the truth in connection with a disease, an economic problem or a security issue, that person automatically becomes a coup-plotter,” said Douglas Nátera, president of the federation. Health Minister Nancy Pérez, who has held that portfolio for just a few days, made a public statement on Wednesday to address the growing social alarm. “The main thing is that there is no strange virus right now. The moment some <trigger id='trigger-0'>disease</trigger> crops up, the <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>people</role> of <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Venezuela</role> will know about it, because it is not state policy to conceal information but rather to disclose it and to take the necessary measures.” For every <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>patient</role> diagnosed with <trigger id='trigger-1'>Chikungunya</trigger>, there could be as many as 1, 000 more Yet the minister admitted to 45, 745 confirmed cases of dengue fever and 398 more of the Chikungunya virus, which causes acute joint pains and is also spread by mosquitoes. Another 1, 200 patients are under observation. But Rafael Arreaza, a surgeon and former director of Venezuela’s Social Security service, questioned the minister’s figures and filed a complaint against the government with the Ombudsman. Arreaza said that for every <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>patient</role> diagnosed with <trigger id='trigger-2'>Chikungunya</trigger>, there could be as many as 1, 000 more, and that the lack of lab material is preventing health workers from knowing the true magnitude of the problem. This former health official also said that 12 of the <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>victims</role> who died were showing similar symptoms, suggesting the need to find out whether the <trigger id='trigger-3'>virus</trigger> is mutating. In the face of this mounting pressure, President Maduro said he will take national and international legal action against any physician but also against any journalist, media outlet or individual who contributes to disseminating this theory through words or images.

text: DJI responds to <role id='role-0-Instrument'trigno='0'>drone</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>attacks</trigger>: “We have limited ability to control what people do with our products” The world’s largest drone manufacturer, DJI, has issued a statement after two of their <role id='role-1-Artifact'trigno='1'>drones</role> <trigger id='trigger-1'>armed</trigger> with <role id='role-1-Components'trigno='1'>explosives</role> were used in an apparent <trigger id='trigger-2'>assassination</trigger> attempt against Venezuelan <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>president</role> Nicolás Maduro last week. The drones in question appeared to be Matrice 600s; commercial-level UAVs intended for aerial photography and costing around $5000 each. The Venezuelan government claims that each <role id='role-3-Artifact'trigno='3'>Matrice</role> was <trigger id='trigger-3'>packed</trigger> with a kilo of <role id='role-4-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='4'><role id='role-3-Components'trigno='3'>C4</role></role> and were intended to <trigger id='trigger-4'>kill</trigger> <role id='role-4-Target'trigno='4'>Maduro</role> and other important Venezuelan political figures. https: / / www. wetalkuav. com / wp-content / uploads / 2018 / 08 / 1024x576_MP4_4439375926361635711. mp4 A video of the <role id='role-5-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='5'>drone</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>exploding</trigger> from media at the event DJI spoke with Dezeen magazine and told them that"DJI makes products purely for peaceful purposes.""While we build some prudent safety and security features into our products, we have limited ability to control what people do with them."They stated that the overwhelming majority of DJI drone operators use their drones peacefully, and they"deplore any use of our products to bring harm to anyone.""As with any technology, if people decide to misuse our products in any way, they have to be responsible for their actions,"they said. Two DJI <role id='role-6-Instrument'trigno='6'>Matrice 600’s</role> were seemingly used in an <trigger id='trigger-6'>attack</trigger> against President <role id='role-6-Target'trigno='6'>Nicolás Maduro</role> in Venezuela last week. <role id='role-7-Attacker'trigno='7'>Who</role> was responsible for the <role id='role-7-Instrument'trigno='7'>drone</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>attacks</trigger> and why did they fail? It is, as yet, unclear <role id='role-8-Attacker'trigno='8'>who</role> exactly was reponsible for the <trigger id='trigger-8'>attacks</trigger>. One group calling themselves ‘ Soldiers in T-shirts ‘ claimed responsibility on Twitter. Maduro alleged Venezuela’s ultra-right in alliance with Colombia’s ultra-right and their outgoing president, Juan Manuel Santos were behind the assassination attempt. The Venezuelan government has used the <trigger id='trigger-9'>attacks</trigger> as justification for a further crackdown on political opponents and have <trigger id='trigger-10'>arrested</trigger> at least 6 <role id='role-10-Detainee'trigno='10'>people</role>. Neither drone ultimately made it to their intended targets. According to Venezuela’s Attorney General, this was because they were deflected from reaching their intended course through protective radio emissions eminating from Venzuelan intelligence personnel (similar to drone killing devices we’ve written about previously). Video footage from multiple angles since the <trigger id='trigger-11'>attack</trigger> suggest that one <role id='role-12-Instrument'trigno='12'>drone</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>exploded</trigger> above the soldiers on parade (causing 7 injuries) while the <role id='role-11-Instrument'trigno='11'>other</role> crashed into the window of an apartment, causing the apartment to catch fire (this was initially reported in some outlets as the result of gas explosion). The website Bellingcat has an excellent rundown of all evidence related to the drone attack including video footage and photos from multiple angles, if you’re interested. A <role id='role-14-Target'trigno='14'><role id='role-13-Victim'trigno='13'>soldier</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-13'>injured</trigger> by the <trigger id='trigger-14'>exploding</trigger> <role id='role-14-Instrument'trigno='14'><role id='role-13-Instrument'trigno='13'>drone</role></role> at the Venezualan National Guard celebration parade in <role id='role-14-Place'trigno='14'>Caracas</role> Despite some claims in media, it seems unlikely the <role id='role-15-Attacker'trigno='15'>government</role> would stage an <trigger id='trigger-15'>attack</trigger> against itself. As the Economist noted,"Dictators depend on projecting an image of omnipotence … in the television footage, Mr Maduro looked befuddled; the massed ranks of the National Guard broke discipline and ran off in panic."In essence, the attacks made Maduro look weak, not strong. False flag operations have happened throughout history but thus far, this does not appear to be one of them. Story continues on page 2

text: Mariana Zuñiga Special for USA TODAY CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuelan election officials said 8 million people voted Sunday to create a constitutional assembly endowing President Nicolás Maduro with virtually unlimited powers, a vote total decried by domestic and foreign critics as a sham. Venezuela’s National Electoral Council's estimated turnout Sunday was more than double that of political opponents and independent experts. Opposition leaders also said 12 <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>people</role> were <trigger id='trigger-3'>killed</trigger> in violence in the face of a massive presence of <role id='role-3-Killer'trigno='3'>troops</role> around the country on Sunday. The government confirmed <role id='role-4-Victim'trigno='4'>nine</role> <trigger id='trigger-4'>deaths</trigger>. Maduro, who faces a worsening economic crisis despite Venezuela's enormous oil reserves, seeks to establish a friendly assembly that would bypass the opposition-controlled Congress to rewrite the country’s 1999 constitution. Opponents accuse him of trying to create a single-party, authoritarian system like that in Cuba. Electoral Council President <role id='role-23-Communicator'trigno='23'>Tibisay Lucena</role> <trigger id='trigger-23'>announced</trigger> just before midnight Sunday that turnout was 41. 53%, or 8, 089, 320 people. The count was met with mockery and anger from members of the opposition, who said they believed between 2 million and 3 million people voted. Julio Borges, president of the opposition-led National Assembly, said only 7% of the electorate had voted — a silent <trigger id='trigger-5'>protest</trigger> of <role id='role-5-Target'trigno='5'>Maduro</role>'s power grab, which would slam the brakes on democracy. The <role id='role-7-Communicator'trigno='7'>opposition</role> had <trigger id='trigger-7'>urged</trigger> <role id='role-7-Recipient'trigno='7'>voters</role> to boycott the vote, but millions of Venezuelans <role id='role-6-Recipient'trigno='6'>who</role> hold government jobs were <trigger id='trigger-6'>ordered</trigger> to cast ballots or risk being fired. Others feared loss of social benefits like subsidized food. “I’m here because I’m hoping for housing,” admitted hairdresser Luisa Marquez, 46, as she waited in line to vote. Opinion polls had indicated that more than two-thirds of the nation opposed the president's move. The opposition said 7 million had voted against constitutional changes in a referendum it had organized a week ago. A midday check of 10 polling places here in the capital Sunday showed most of them empty or nearly empty. “Venezuela has screamed with its silence,” said Borges, who put the day's death toll at 12. The public prosecutor's office confirmed <role id='role-24-Victim'trigno='24'>nine</role> <trigger id='trigger-24'>deaths</trigger>. Maduro's vision of a new constitution to consolidate his power has drawn ire in Washington. Last week, the Trump administration imposed sanctions on 13 senior Venezuelan officials, and the White House and some U. S. lawmakers said stiffer sanctions could follow. <role id='role-8-Communicator'trigno='8'>Mexico</role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>said</trigger> it would support U. S. sanctions, and <role id='role-9-Communicator'trigno='9'>the Organization of American States</role> and the European Parliament have also <trigger id='trigger-9'>expressed</trigger> support for <role id='role-9-Topic'trigno='9'>the opposition</role>. Late Sunday, the U. S. <role id='role-10-Participant'trigno='10'><role id='role-10-Participant'trigno='10'>State Department</role></role> officially <trigger id='trigger-10'>condemned</trigger> the Venezuelan government for holding the vote, saying Maduro's bid to consolidate power would “undermine the Venezuelan people’s right to self-determination.” U. N. Ambassador <role id='role-11-Communicator'trigno='11'>Nikki Haley</role> has <trigger id='trigger-11'>called</trigger> the vote a “sham election.” In Venezuela, opposition leaders refused to put up candidates, arguing that the election has been structured to ensure that Maduro’s ruling socialist party dominates. Thus virtually all the more than 5, 000 candidates for 545 assembly seats are Maduro supporters. The <role id='role-12-Communicator'trigno='12'>opposition</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>vowed</trigger> to protest despite a ban on public gatherings issued by Maduro. In some parts of the capital, <role id='role-13-Demonstrator'trigno='13'>people</role> took to the streets in <trigger id='trigger-13'>protest</trigger> against the vote, but <role id='role-14-Target'trigno='14'>they</role> were soon <trigger id='trigger-14'>repelled</trigger> by <role id='role-14-Attacker'trigno='14'>security forces</role> throwing <role id='role-14-Instrument'trigno='14'>tear gas</role>. During a <trigger id='trigger-15'>protest</trigger>, opposition <role id='role-16-Attacker'trigno='16'><role id='role-0-Injurer'trigno='0'>supporters</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-16'>set</trigger> an <role id='role-16-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='16'><role id='role-0-Instrument'trigno='0'>explosive</role></role> that <trigger id='trigger-0'>injured</trigger> seven police <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>officers</role>, the public prosecutor's office said. After the <trigger id='trigger-17'>blast</trigger>, <role id='role-1-Destroyer'trigno='1'>police</role> set <trigger id='trigger-1'>fire</trigger> to four <role id='role-1-Artifact'trigno='1'>motorcycles</role> belonging to journalists. Read more: After months of fatal <trigger id='trigger-18'>protests</trigger>, Venezuela braces for controversial vote Sunday Why this vote in Venezuela is so important Maduro has struggled with a rapidly deteriorating economy and strengthening political opposition. Some voters said they believed the new assembly might improve life in Venezuela. “I’m voting today because I want peace to be restored,” said seamstress Carmen Martinez, 44. But she said she was less certain the assembly will solve the nation's economic ills."I’m going to have hope, but I doubt this could solve that problem,"she said. Months of violence leading up to the vote showed little signs of ending, with media reporting that a leading assembly <role id='role-19-Victim'trigno='19'>candidate</role> and an opposition activist were <trigger id='trigger-19'>killed</trigger> before voting even began. <role id='role-20-Target'trigno='20'>José Felix Pineda</role>, a lawyer running in the election, was <trigger id='trigger-20'>shot</trigger> in his home Saturday night, a senior Venezuelan minister told the BBC. Maduro has denied links to violent paramilitaries that have run roughshod across the country, blaming the opposition for unrelenting violence that has left more than 100 <role id='role-21-Victim'trigno='21'>people</role> <trigger id='trigger-21'>dead</trigger>. Maduro himself voted with little fanfare early in the morning. “We’ve stoically withstood the terrorist, <trigger id='trigger-2'>criminal</trigger> violence,” he said. “Hopefully the world will respectfully extend its arms toward our country.” Opposition leader <role id='role-22-Communicator'trigno='22'>Henrique Capriles</role> <trigger id='trigger-22'>called</trigger> on <role id='role-22-Recipient'trigno='22'>Venezuelans</role> to protest on Monday. Contributing: The Associated Press. Contributing: John Bacon in McLean, Va.

text: <role id='role-0-Defendant'trigno='0'>Teen</role> who brought explosives to Pine View High <trigger id='trigger-0'>sentenced</trigger> to jail time, probation Student escorted off the football field at Pine View High School after the <role id='role-1-Origin'trigno='1'>school</role> was <trigger id='trigger-1'>evacuated</trigger> following the discovery of a suspicious package, St. George, Utah, March 5, 2018 | Photos sent to St. George News ST. GEORGE, Utah — A <role id='role-3-Defendant'trigno='3'><role id='role-2-Transporter'trigno='2'>teen</role></role> who <trigger id='trigger-2'>brought</trigger> <role id='role-2-PassengerArtifact'trigno='2'>explosives</role> to Pine View High School has been <trigger id='trigger-3'>sentenced</trigger> to jail time. Martin Farnsworth, 17, was ordered to serve 415 days in detention with credit for time served (which he has already served). <role id='role-6-Defendant'trigno='6'><role id='role-5-Patient'trigno='5'><role id='role-4-Patient'trigno='4'>He</role></role></role> also was <trigger id='trigger-6'>given</trigger> 48 months probation, 250 hours of community service, and court-ordered <trigger id='trigger-4'>treatment</trigger> and any recommended <trigger id='trigger-5'>medication</trigger> by 5th District Court Judge Michael Westfall. He was also ordered to have no access to the internet or explosive materials or bomb-making components. <role id='role-7-Defendant'trigno='7'>He</role> pleaded guilty in March to a <trigger id='trigger-7'>charge</trigger> of intent to commit <trigger id='trigger-8'>injury</trigger> with an incendiary device, a first-degree felony. <role id='role-9-Defendant'trigno='9'>He</role> was originally <trigger id='trigger-9'>charged</trigger> with attempted murder and possession of a weapon of mass destruction, as well as <trigger id='trigger-13'>misdemeanor</trigger> graffiti charges. The case was originally filed in juvenile court, but Farnsworth was later transferred to the adult court system. <role id='role-10-Detainee'trigno='10'>Farnsworth</role> was <trigger id='trigger-10'>arrested</trigger> last year after <role id='role-10-Jailer'trigno='10'>police</role> said he brought a backpack loaded with a bomb to Pine View High. Prosecutors said <role id='role-11-Attacker'trigno='11'>he</role> lit a fuse, but the <role id='role-11-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='11'>bomb</role> did not <trigger id='trigger-11'>detonate</trigger>. Police also accused him of researching information about the terror group ISIS online. He was also accused of replacing an American flag at a school in Hurricane with a pro-ISIS flag."If I didn’t get caught from this, if people got hurt and I could get away from it? I would have laid low for a little while, kind of see what people’s reactions were, whether there were comments about it, etc. Then later on try to hang an ISIS flag somewhere like on a school or maybe on the freeway, make it look like ISIS is here. Then maybe after that try to <trigger id='trigger-12'>contact</trigger> ISIS, but <role id='role-12-Participant'trigno='12'><role id='role-12-Participant'trigno='12'>I</role></role> don’t really know how to do that. I need to do more research on that,"he told police, according to a court filing FOX 13 reported on last year. A psychologist testified on his behalf that Farnsworth was diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder. Copyright 2020 Scripps Media, Inc. All rights reserved.
