text: 'Pure Carnage'Recalled at Boston Marathon Trial A <role id='role-1-Participant'trigno='1'><role id='role-1-Participant'trigno='1'>survivor</role></role> of the deadly 2013 <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Boston</role> Marathon <trigger id='trigger-0'>bombings</trigger> Thursday <trigger id='trigger-1'>described</trigger> the moments after the attack as"pure carnage."Race spectator Jeff Bauman, <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>who</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>lost</trigger> both legs in the <trigger id='trigger-3'>explosions</trigger> near the finish line of the race, testified on the second day of the <trigger id='trigger-4'>trial</trigger> of <role id='role-4-Defendant'trigno='4'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role> in a Boston <role id='role-4-Place'trigno='4'>courthouse</role>. Bauman hobbled to the witness stand on prosthetic legs, then <trigger id='trigger-5'>told</trigger> the <role id='role-5-Participant'trigno='5'><role id='role-5-Participant'trigno='5'>jury</role></role> that he bumped into Tsarnaev's older brother Tamerlan along the race course moments before the <trigger id='trigger-6'>blasts</trigger> <trigger id='trigger-7'>killed</trigger> three <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>people</role> and <trigger id='trigger-8'>injured</trigger> another <role id='role-8-Victim'trigno='8'>264</role>. Defense lawyers sought Thursday to limit graphic testimony of the bombing victims, but Judge <role id='role-9-Communicator'trigno='9'>George O'Toole</role> <trigger id='trigger-9'>ruled</trigger> the <role id='role-9-Recipient'trigno='9'>jury</role> should hear witness descriptions of the aftermath of the <trigger id='trigger-10'>attack</trigger>. <role id='role-11-Participant'trigno='11'><role id='role-11-Participant'trigno='11'>Prosecutors</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-11'>allege</trigger> the <role id='role-11-Topic'trigno='11'>Tsarnaevs</role> were trying to avenge U. S. wars in Muslim countries. By blaming the older brother, defense lawyers hope to <trigger id='trigger-13'>convince</trigger> the <role id='role-13-Participant'trigno='13'><role id='role-13-Participant'trigno='13'><role id='role-12-JudgeCourt'trigno='12'>jury</role></role></role> to not <trigger id='trigger-12'>sentence</trigger> <role id='role-12-Defendant'trigno='12'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role> to death. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev's lawyer, Judy Clarke, <trigger id='trigger-14'>told</trigger> the <role id='role-14-Participant'trigno='14'><role id='role-14-Participant'trigno='14'>jury</role></role> Wednesday the 21-year-old native <role id='role-15-Attacker'trigno='15'><role id='role-14-Topic'trigno='14'>Chechen</role></role> participated with Tamerlan in <trigger id='trigger-15'>setting off</trigger> the <role id='role-15-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='15'>bombs</role>, but said <role id='role-16-Communicator'trigno='16'>Tamerlan</role> masterminded the plot and deeply <trigger id='trigger-16'>influenced</trigger> his <role id='role-16-Recipient'trigno='16'>brother</role> to take part in it. <role id='role-17-Killer'trigno='17'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role> inadvertently <trigger id='trigger-17'>killed</trigger> his <role id='role-17-Victim'trigno='17'>brother</role>, running over him with a car, as they attempted to <trigger id='trigger-18'>elude</trigger> police days after <role id='role-19-Identifier'trigno='19'>authorities</role> had <trigger id='trigger-19'>identified</trigger> <role id='role-19-IdentifiedObject'trigno='19'>them</role> as <role id='role-19-IdentifiedRole'trigno='19'>suspects</role> in the bombings. In his testimony, <role id='role-20-Participant'trigno='20'><role id='role-20-Participant'trigno='20'>Bauman</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-20'>said</trigger> he thought <role id='role-20-Topic'trigno='20'>Tamerlan</role> looked"very suspicious. He was alone. . . was not watching the race. He was not having fun."<role id='role-21-Participant'trigno='21'><role id='role-21-Participant'trigno='21'>Bauman</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-21'>said</trigger> he noticed an unattended bag that hid <role id='role-22-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='22'>one</role> of the two home-made pressure cooker bombs that defense <role id='role-23-Participant'trigno='23'><role id='role-23-Participant'trigno='23'>attorneys</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-23'>acknowledge</trigger> the Tsarnaev <role id='role-22-Attacker'trigno='22'>brothers</role> <trigger id='trigger-22'>detonated</trigger>. After the <trigger id='trigger-24'>blasts</trigger>, Bauman, at the race to watch his future wife run, said,"I looked down and saw my legs. It was pure carnage. . . I could see my bones and flesh sticking out."He later described Tamerlan Tsarnaev for authorities as <role id='role-25-Investigator'trigno='25'>they</role> began to <trigger id='trigger-25'>search</trigger> for bombing <role id='role-25-Defendant'trigno='25'>suspects</role>. Protester outside the John Joseph Moakley federal courthouse where <trigger id='trigger-26'>trial</trigger> for Boston Marathon bombing suspect <role id='role-26-Defendant'trigno='26'>Dzhokhar Tsarnaev</role> is being held, <role id='role-26-Place'trigno='26'>Boston</role>, Massachusetts, March 5, 2015. (CarolynPresutti / VOA) Wednesday, jurors heard testimony from three other survivors of the bombing <role id='role-27-Victim'trigno='27'>who</role> were severely <trigger id='trigger-27'>wounded</trigger> in the attack — two of whom each lost a leg."My bones were literally laying next to me on the sidewalk,"said 27-year-old survivor Rebekah Gregory, <role id='role-28-Victim'trigno='28'>who</role> also suffered multiple shrapnel <trigger id='trigger-28'>injuries</trigger> to one of her arms. Tsarnaev has pleaded not guilty to the 30 counts against him, including the fatal shooting of a Massachusetts Institute of Technology police officer days after the <trigger id='trigger-29'>bombings</trigger> as the <role id='role-30-PassengerArtifact'trigno='30'>Tsarnaevs</role> tried to <trigger id='trigger-30'>flee</trigger>. Dzhokhar Tsarnaev and his late <role id='role-31-PassengerArtifact'trigno='31'>brother</role> are ethnic Chechens who had lived in the former Soviet republic of Kyrgyzstan and the volatile Dagestan region of Russia before <trigger id='trigger-31'>coming</trigger> to the <role id='role-31-Destination'trigno='31'>U. S. </role> with their parents and two sisters about a decade before the <trigger id='trigger-32'>bombings</trigger>. Some information for this report comes from AP, AFP and Reuters.

text: Birmingham pub bombings: Lawyer renews call for inquests Published duration 14 November 2014 image copyright Getty Images image caption The two bombs went off 10 minutes apart in pubs a few yards from each other A lawyer for the family of one of the 21 people killed in the Birmingham pub bombings is calling for inquests to be held for the victims. There have been no inquests since two <role id='role-0-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='0'>bombs</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>exploded</trigger> at the Mulberry Bush and the <role id='role-0-Target'trigno='0'>Tavern</role> in the Town in November 1974, which also injured 182 people. Human rights lawyer Kevin Winters said he will be writing to West Midlands Police and the relevant coroner. Inquests would allow access to certain material never before disclosed. <role id='role-1-Detainee'trigno='1'>Six men</role>, later dubbed the Birmingham Six, were <trigger id='trigger-1'>jailed</trigger> in 1975 but their convictions were quashed in 1991. Families of the victims have criticised police, accusing them of withholding information over the years and say 40 years on from the bombings they still do not have the answers they need. Calls for a fresh <trigger id='trigger-2'>investigation</trigger> into what happened were denied by <role id='role-2-Investigator'trigno='2'>West Midlands Police</role> in April. Speaking exclusively to BBC Radio WM ahead of the 40th anniversary next week, Mr Winters, who has represented families of victims of the Troubles in Northern Ireland, said inquests would have been put off because of legal proceedings against the Six but"uniquely we now know the wrong people were put behind bars."image caption Twenty-one people were killed when bombs exploded at the Mulberry Bush and Tavern in the Town on 21 November 1974 Brother and sister Julie and Brian Hambleton, who lost their sister <role id='role-3-Victim'trigno='3'>Maxine</role> in the <trigger id='trigger-3'>bombings</trigger>, have been leading a campaign to try to find out more about what happened. Ms Hambleton, who met Mr Winters this week to ask him to represent them, said she does not understand why inquests have never been held, even after 1991."Why hasn't anyone stepped up before now and said anything? ,"Ms Hambleton said. image copyright (C) British Broadcasting Corporation image caption <role id='role-4-Defendant'trigno='4'>Julie Hambleton</role> said she feels she has not been given the answers she needs about her sister's death As well as establishing inquest <trigger id='trigger-4'>hearings</trigger>, Mr <role id='role-4-Prosecutor'trigno='4'>Winters</role> said he would be pursuing several others avenues of action. This may include action against authorities under European Human Rights legislation, looking at"serious issues"about the previous flawed West Midlands Police investigation and within that"the deliberate peddling of the view that they had caught the perpetrators". image caption Human rights lawyer Kevin Winters has been asked to represent the Hambletons"There's an on-going duty on behalf of the authorities, and especially West Midlands Police, to actually get to the bottom of what happened,"Mr Winters said."These families have received a very poor service in terms of justice and truth and closure-they've got nothing near it at all."He said the families also had no recourse to remedies available to those affected by the Troubles in Ireland. Inquests would provide families with access to certain"disclosure materials"that he said had been kept from them."In my view, and our view, there is a basis for an inquest and we're now going to be writing to West Midlands Police and the relevant coronial services in England through our agencies in London to invite a new inquest."In response, Chief Constable Chris Sims said:"Nothing would give me more satisfaction than to bring those responsible for this atrocity to justice."However, we have found no new evidence that would assist us in bringing anyone to justice for the pub bombings."It is always possible that brand new and significant information could become available to us."Let me be clear-this case is not closed."

text: <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>US</role> <trigger id='trigger-0'>Arrests</trigger> Focus on Terrorism Fight NEW YORK — Disturbing allegations were contained in court papers describing the latest homegrown terror plot thwarted by the FBI and the New York Police Department. Noelle Velentzas and <role id='role-1-Detainee'trigno='1'>Asia Siddiqui</role> were <trigger id='trigger-1'>arrested</trigger> at their Queens homes early Thursday following a sting operation using an undercover officer wearing a wire. The officer searching the homes recovered items including three gas tanks, a pressure cooker, fertilizer, jihadist literature and handwritten notes on the recipes for bomb making, court papers say. Velentzas had been"obsessed with <role id='role-2-Instrument'trigno='2'>pressure cookers</role> since the <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>Boston</role> Marathon <trigger id='trigger-2'>attacks</trigger> in 2013''and made jokes alluding to explosives after receiving one as a gift, according to a criminal complaint citing one of the secret recordings made by the undercover agent who befriended the pair. Fighting'homegrown violent extremists'The women’s arrests show U. S. authorities “are committed to doing everything in our ability to detect, disrupt and deter <trigger id='trigger-3'>attacks</trigger> by homegrown violent extremists,''<role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>U. S</role>. Attorney Loretta Lynch said in a statement. “As alleged, the defendants in this case carefully studied how to <trigger id='trigger-4'>construct</trigger> an explosive <role id='role-4-Artifact'trigno='4'>device</role> to launch an <trigger id='trigger-5'>attack</trigger> on the <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>homeland</role>.''In this courtroom sketch, <role id='role-20-Defendant'trigno='20'>Muhanad Mahmoud Al Farekh</role>, with beard, <trigger id='trigger-20'>appears</trigger> in <role id='role-20-JudgeCourt'trigno='20'>federal court</role> in <role id='role-20-Place'trigno='20'>New York</role> April 2, 2015. Authorities say <role id='role-6-Killer'trigno='6'>he</role> planned to <trigger id='trigger-6'>kill</trigger> American <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>soldiers</role>. <role id='role-8-Detainee'trigno='8'>Their</role> <trigger id='trigger-8'>arrests</trigger> came the same day as another U. S. citizen was brought from Pakistan to New York to face <trigger id='trigger-9'>charges</trigger> <role id='role-9-Defendant'trigno='9'><role id='role-7-Killer'trigno='7'>he</role></role> supported a conspiracy to <trigger id='trigger-7'>kill</trigger> <role id='role-7-Victim'trigno='7'>Americans</role>. Texas-born <role id='role-10-Detainee'trigno='10'>Muhanad Mahmoud Al Farekh</role> appeared Thursday in Brooklyn federal <role id='role-10-Place'trigno='10'>court</role> and was <trigger id='trigger-10'>held</trigger> without bail. The <role id='role-11-Detainee'trigno='11'>women</role> also were <trigger id='trigger-11'>held</trigger> without bail after a brief court appearance, where they spoke only to say they understood the charges against them. Velentzas, 28, wore a hijab and a dark dress, and Siddiqui, 31, had on a green T-shirt with a long-sleeved black shirt underneath and a dark long skirt. Siddiqui’s lawyer, Thomas Dunn, said his client"will enter a plea of not guilty, if and when there is an indictment."Velentzas'attorney had no comment. The complaint cites a poem written by Siddiqui that appeared in a magazine published by al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula. It declared there is"no excuse to sit back and wait for the skies [to] rain martyrdom,''investigators wrote in court papers. Velentzas called al-Qaida’s founder, the late Osama bin Laden, one of her heroes, and said she and Siddiqui were"citizens of the Islamic State,"investigators said. Research methods According to the complaint, the women"researched and acquired some of the components of a car bomb, like the one used in the 1993 <role id='role-12-Target'trigno='12'>World Trade Center</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>bombing</trigger>; a fertilizer <role id='role-12-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='12'>bomb</role>, like the one used in the 1995 <trigger id='trigger-13'>bombing</trigger> of the federal <role id='role-13-Target'trigno='13'>building</role> in <role id='role-13-Place'trigno='13'>Oklahoma City</role>; and a pressure cooker bomb, like the one used in the 2013 <role id='role-14-Place'trigno='14'>Boston</role> Marathon <trigger id='trigger-14'>bombing</trigger>,''authorities wrote. After two <role id='role-15-Place'trigno='15'>New York City</role> police <role id='role-15-Victim'trigno='15'>officers</role> were <trigger id='trigger-15'>gunned</trigger> down in a patrol car in December, Velentzas told the undercover <role id='role-16-Victim'trigno='16'>officer</role> that the <trigger id='trigger-16'>deaths</trigger> showed it was easy to <trigger id='trigger-17'>kill</trigger> a police <role id='role-17-Victim'trigno='17'>officer</role>, the complaint said. After the undercover officer mentioned that 25, 000 officers had turned out for the first of the funerals for the two officers, Velentzas “complimented''the officer for coming up with an attractive target and considered whether the other funeral was an appropriate target, it added. The complaints suggests that <role id='role-18-Jailer'trigno='18'>authorities</role> decided to make the <trigger id='trigger-18'>arrests</trigger> after <role id='role-18-Detainee'trigno='18'>Siddiqui</role> came into “possession of multiple propane gas tanks, as well as instructions for how to <trigger id='trigger-19'>transform</trigger> propane tanks into explosive <role id='role-19-Artifact'trigno='19'>devices</role>,” and told the undercover she was “disinclined” to talk about her plans. “It is very, very important to note: There was never any imminent threat to our fellow New Yorkers,''Mayor Bill de Blasio said when asked about the case. The plot, he added,"was undercut before it could turn into something dangerous.''Siddiqui’s neighbors said she and her brother lived in the basement of a red-brick three floor house owned by their parents, who didn't live there. “She was quiet, and I never thought she could do this,''said Mohammad Shahidul Haque, a retired hospital lab tech. Other plot reportedly hatched in Canada As for Al Farekh, he and two other co-conspirators were students at the University of Manitoba in Winnipeg, Canada, in 2007 when authorities say they started watching al-Qaida propaganda and hatching a plan to become martyrs abroad, an FBI agent wrote in a January complaint. Al Farekh and the two others flew to Karachi, Pakistan, on round-trip tickets in March 2007 after selling their belongings, disconnecting their phones and buying mountain boots that authorities say are commonly worn by al-Qaida fighters in Pakistan and Afghanistan, the complaint says. His lawyer did not comment. President Barack Obama has nominated Lynch to become the nation’s next attorney general, though her confirmation has been held up in the U. S. Senate.

text: Republican News · Thursday 6 December 2001 McGurk's bomb relatives call for inquiry BY LAURA FRIEL Calls for an inquiry accompanied the 30th anniversary commemoration of the 15 <role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>people</role> who <trigger id='trigger-0'>died</trigger> and <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>16</role> who were seriously <trigger id='trigger-1'>injured</trigger> in the <role id='role-2-Place'trigno='2'>McGurk's bar</role> <trigger id='trigger-2'>bombing</trigger> of 1971. Relatives of the victims, who held a memorial service in Belfast this week, are calling for an <trigger id='trigger-4'>investigation</trigger> into allegations of crown force collusion in the UVF <role id='role-3-ExplosiveDevice'trigno='3'>bomb</role> <trigger id='trigger-3'>attack</trigger>. Thirty years ago this week, on 4 December 1971, a UVF gang placed a bomb in the hallway of McGurk's bar in North Queens Street. Amongst the dead, which included children and pensioners, were several members of the bar owner, Patrick McGurk's family, who were upstairs in the living area at the time of the <trigger id='trigger-23'>explosion</trigger>. The <role id='role-5-Artifact'trigno='5'>building</role> <trigger id='trigger-5'>collapsed</trigger>, trapping many of the victims under the rubble. Alex McLaughlin, whose <role id='role-6-Victim'trigno='6'>father</role> was <trigger id='trigger-6'>killed</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-7'>attack</trigger>, said there was a massive Crown force presence in the area in the week prior to the <trigger id='trigger-24'>bombing</trigger> in contrast to the night of the <trigger id='trigger-8'>atttack</trigger>."Two days earlier, three men had escaped from Crumlin Road jail and the RUC had swamped the area looking for them,"said Alex."It seems strange that <role id='role-9-Transporter'trigno='9'>loyalists</role> would choose that time to <trigger id='trigger-9'>drive</trigger> from <role id='role-9-Origin'trigno='9'>Tigers Bay</role> into a Catholic <role id='role-9-Destination'trigno='9'>area</role> to plant a <role id='role-9-PassengerArtifact'trigno='9'>bomb</role>."Despite an eyewitness account identifying the bombing crew and the fact that the bombing was claimed by <role id='role-10-Attacker'trigno='10'>loyalists</role> in the immediate aftrermath of the <trigger id='trigger-10'>attack</trigger>, the British authorities blamed the IRA. Journalists were briefed by senior members of the British Army, who claimed forensic evidence confirmed republicans were responsible for the <trigger id='trigger-11'>explosion</trigger>. In her study,"Ireland: the Propaganda War,"Liz Curtis describes how the British Army and RUC, with the assistance of much of the press, successfully diverted attention from the evidence of loyalist involvement and used the atrocity to discredit their principle enemy, the IRA."The McGurk's <role id='role-12-Place'trigno='12'>bar</role> <trigger id='trigger-12'>bombing</trigger> had caused more <trigger id='trigger-13'>casualties</trigger> than any single previous incident,"said Curtis,"loyalists were responsible but never stood publicly condemned for it beyond nationalist areas."In 1978, a self-confessed UVF member, <role id='role-15-Killer'trigno='15'><role id='role-14-Defendant'trigno='14'>Robert Campbell</role></role>, was <trigger id='trigger-14'>convicted</trigger> of the bombing together with the 1976 sectarian <trigger id='trigger-15'>killing</trigger> of <role id='role-15-Victim'trigno='15'>John Morrow</role>, a workman mistaken for a Catholic. Pat Arthurs, who was 14 years of age when her <role id='role-16-Victim'trigno='16'>mother</role> was <trigger id='trigger-16'>killed</trigger> in the bombing, has described how the'disinformation'peddled by the RUC and British army left her confused and made it more difficult for her family to come to terms with the loss. Pat's father, who was also in McGurk's, survived the <trigger id='trigger-17'>attack</trigger>. In her heart, Pat always knew the bombing had been carried out by loyalists but there was always a doubt. And then there was the stigma."I had to grow up with people saying that maybe my mother or father had something to do with the murder of 15 people,"said Pat. Mary Irvine, whose <role id='role-18-Victim'trigno='18'>mother</role> was <trigger id='trigger-18'>killed</trigger> in the <trigger id='trigger-19'>bombing</trigger>, said that while everyone else seemed to have forgotten about what happened, the people of the New Lodge Road and local community have supported relatives and survivors for thirty years. Mary particularly remembered the late Paddy McManus, a local Sinn Fein Councillor"who had kept the memory of what happened in McGurk's alive."Almost a thousand people packed St. Patrick's Chapel on Donegall Street for a memorial mass this week. Following the service fifteen wreaths, one for each victim, were carried by relatives leading a silent candlelit procession to a new memorial at Great George's Street. At the site where so <role id='role-20-Victim'trigno='20'>many</role> had <trigger id='trigger-20'>died</trigger>, Fr David White condemned'careless reporting'which had added to the grief."The <trigger id='trigger-21'>bombing</trigger> of <role id='role-21-Place'trigno='21'>Paddy McGurk's</role> was a callous and cowardly sectarian act,"said Fr White,"and the enormous pain inflicted by the <trigger id='trigger-22'>death</trigger> of so <role id='role-22-Victim'trigno='22'>many</role> was intensified when the army and police personnel, together with the media, rushed to blame republicans."

text: MISSISSAUGA, Ontario — Investigators on Friday were looking for two people who detonated a pail filled with projectiles inside a crowded Indian restaurant near Toronto late Thursday, wounding 15 people, three of them critically. Chief Jennifer Evans of the Peel Regional Police called the bombing “horrendous,” but said there was no immediate indication that it was related to terrorism or a hate crime. The blast took place around 10: 30 p. m. at the Bombay Bhel restaurant in Mississauga, Ontario, a large city just west of Toronto. Sgt. Matt Bertram said the assailants had entered the restaurant and put down what appeared to be a pail or a paint can, which then exploded as the two fled down the street. Rafael Concaceicao, a student from São Paulo, Brazil, told the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation that he was on the patio of a nearby restaurant when he heard the explosion at Bombay Bhel. He rushed to help, he said.

President Nicolas Maduro remembered the fateful day and said that"like a phoenix,"the Venezuelan people resurfaced to proudly stand today. As Venezuelans commemorate the 82nd anniversary of the Bolivarian National Armed Forces, Aug. 4 also marks a critical day in the country’s recent history. One year ago, in a <trigger id='trigger-9'>speech</trigger> during the 81st anniversary, President <role id='role-9-Communicator'trigno='9'><role id='role-0-Victim'trigno='0'>Nicolas Maduro</role></role> was the target of a failed <trigger id='trigger-0'>assassination</trigger> attempt."They not only came for me, but they also came for everyone, for the people, and for our country, wanting to undermine the peace and sovereignty of the nation,"<role id='role-10-Communicator'trigno='10'>the president</role> said Sunday remembering the frustrated attempt in a <trigger id='trigger-10'>speech</trigger> from the Military Academy in Caracas."But God intervened and like the phoenix, we resurfaced from the ashes of a terrorist <trigger id='trigger-11'>attack</trigger> and today a year later I can say that we are standing,"he added, affirming, once again, the masterminds were the Colombian and United States government. On Aug. 4, 2018, an explosive-loaded drone <trigger id='trigger-3'>detonated</trigger> before reaching a stage where President <role id='role-4-Communicator'trigno='4'>Maduro</role> was <trigger id='trigger-4'>delivering</trigger> a speech during a military parade in the capital. At that time, the Venezuelan right-wing opposition and its allies, one of which was the U. S. National Security Advisor John Bolton, said the <trigger id='trigger-5'>explosion</trigger> was"a montage."“After the brief moment of confusion, <role id='role-6-Identifier'trigno='6'>we</role> <trigger id='trigger-6'>knew</trigger> it was an attack. There were many speculations and lies afterward in the networks but we insisted that it had been an <trigger id='trigger-1'>assassination</trigger> attempt,” Mariela Lopez, a freelance videographer for HispanTV and Xinhua, remembered; as her images, taken in the precise moment of the explosion and the security team's response, were shown around the world. Despite the evidence, global mainstream media <trigger id='trigger-12'>ridiculed</trigger> the drone attack using qualifiers such as"presumed","supposed","confusing event"and"alleged drones". On Aug. 5, 2018, for instance, CNN Spanish titled an article"the world reacts to the alleged attack against Nicolas Maduro."New videos obtained by CNN provide insight into last year's drone <trigger id='trigger-7'>attack</trigger> against #Venezuela's sitting president Nicolas #Maduro. It may be the world's first known attempt to kill a head of state with a retail drone. @ npwcnn reports: https: / / t. co / A0qJ1Vd3cf — Michael Rios (@ MikeRiosNews) March 14, 2019 However, as time went on truth surfaced and on March 2019, CNN revealed unpublished images of how such <trigger id='trigger-13'>attack</trigger> was prepared on a Colombian farm, information which was provided by one of whom were involved in the attempted attack. The report agreed with the government's assertions about the attack. CNN then published an interview with a Venezuelan dissident who organized the <trigger id='trigger-14'>attack</trigger>. <role id='role-15-Identifier'trigno='15'><role id='role-2-Perpetrator'trigno='2'>He</role></role> <trigger id='trigger-15'>admitted</trigger> that the objective was to <trigger id='trigger-2'>assassinate</trigger> <role id='role-2-Victim'trigno='2'>Maduro</role>, an outcome which involved expecting some"collateral damages.""[Killing other people] was the risk we had to take,"the attack organizer said in response to questions and explained that the drones were purchased online and imported to a Colombian farm, where plotters were training day and night in the handling of the devices. The Venezuelan conspirator also assured that U. S. government officials had three meetings with the plotters after the assassination attempt occurred. In those meetings, according to CNN, these officials only"took notes"on the background of the plan and its failure. On June 11, Venezuela’s Attorney General, Tarek William Saab, informed that 38 <role id='role-8-Defendant'trigno='8'>suspects</role> have been <trigger id='trigger-8'>indicted</trigger> in the case of the frustrated assassination attempt and as investigations continue, of the 38 linked so far, 31 are deprived of liberty and seven received substitutive measures.

text: primary subject Accompanying Timothy McVeigh in the Ryder truck used to deliver the bomb to the Murrah Federal Building on 19 April 1995; Stepping out of the Ryder truck at ground zero minutes before the blast Speeding away from downtown Oklahoma City immediately after the <trigger id='trigger-0'>detonation</trigger> of the truck bomb; Being seen in the company of Timothy McVeigh a various times and locations prior to 19 April 1995. Boston Logan International Airport. At that time, he resided with two Iraqi men (brothers) who provided food catering services for the commercial airlines at Boston Logan during the time leading up to and including September 11, 2001. Something is terribly wrong with the FBI’s handling of the 1995 <trigger id='trigger-2'>bombing</trigger> and the events leading up to and including <trigger id='trigger-1'>the attacks of September 11, 2001. </trigger> Something at the highest levels of government that continue through the present. Full article at www. homelandsecurityus. com / archives / 4633

text: German police are searching for a suspect after an abandoned bag loaded with potential explosives was discovered Monday at the central train station in Bonn, Spiegel Online reported Wednesday. The German daily Frankfurter Allegemeine Zeitung, citing unnamed high level sources, reported that authorities determined the bomb was extremely dangerous, comparable to the 2004 <trigger id='trigger-0'>attack</trigger> in <role id='role-0-Place'trigno='0'>Madrid</role>, in which 10 <role id='role-0-Instrument'trigno='0'>bombs</role> placed on regional trains <trigger id='trigger-1'>claimed</trigger> 191 <role id='role-1-Victim'trigno='1'>lives</role>. The station was temporarily closed. Two Somali-born <role id='role-4-Defendant'trigno='4'><role id='role-2-Detainee'trigno='2'>men</role></role>, <trigger id='trigger-2'>detained</trigger> Tuesday in connection with the find, were later <trigger id='trigger-4'>released</trigger> for lack of evidence, Cologne police said, according to Spiegel. The first suspect, identified as Omar D. , was <trigger id='trigger-3'>arrested</trigger> on Tuesday around 1: 30 p. m. in a Bonn Internet <role id='role-3-Place'trigno='3'>café</role> along with his companion <role id='role-3-Detainee'trigno='3'>Abdifatah W</role>. , Spiegel Online reported Tuesday. According to Spiegel, Omar D. was <trigger id='trigger-5'>detained</trigger> in 2008 at the <role id='role-5-Place'trigno='5'>Cologne / Bonn airport</role> after boarding a plane to Amsterdam, along with another Somali <role id='role-5-Detainee'trigno='5'>native</role>, both suspected of planning to join the armed jihad. <role id='role-6-Defendant'trigno='6'>Both</role> were <trigger id='trigger-6'>released</trigger> shortly after <role id='role-7-Detainee'trigno='7'>their</role> <trigger id='trigger-7'>arrest</trigger> at that time. Spiegel Online reported that the bag at the train station contained butane gas and ammonium nitrate, as well as a metal pipe, an alarm clock and batteries. Investigators initially described the bag's contents as"potentially explosive material."Police are working from a description of the man a 14-year-old boy said he saw deposit the bag at Track 1 of the train station, Spiegel Online reported. Parts of the station were closed as authorities fired a water cannon at the bag to disable it.
